verses.text: ) So then, there is need of spiritual "wisdom," that we may perceive things spiritual, that we may see things hidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:42
verses.text: That Spirit "revealeth" all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:43
verses.text: He is going to set forth the mysteries of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:44
verses.text: Now the knowledge of the mysteries of God, the Spirit alone comprehends, who also searcheth the deep things of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:45
verses.text: It is not said, "that Angel, or Archangel, or any other created power, may give," that is, confer upon you a spiritual gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:46
verses.text: And if this be of revelation, then is the discovery of arguments consequently vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:47
verses.text: For he that hath learned God, and knoweth God, shall no longer dispute concerning any thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:48
verses.text: He will not say, This is impossible, and That is possible, and How did the other thing come to pass? If we learn God, as we ought to know Him; if we learn God from Him from whom we ought to learn Him, that is from the Spirit Himself; then shall we no longer dispute concerning any thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:49
verses.text: And hence it is that he says,  "Having the eyes of your heart enlightened in the knowledge of Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:50
verses.text: He that hath learned what God is, will have no misgiving about His promises, and disbelief about what hath been already brought to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:51
verses.text: He prays, then, that there may be given them "a spirit of wisdom and revelation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:52
verses.text: Yet still he also establishes it, as far as he can himself, by arguments, and from "already" existing facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:53
verses.text: For, whereas he was about to mention some things which had already come to pass, and others which had not as yet happened; he makes those which have been brought to pass, a pledge of those which have not: in some such way, I mean, as this,  "That ye may know," saith he, "what is the hope of His calling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:54
verses.text: It is as yet, he means, hidden, but not so to the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:55
verses.text: "And," again, "what is the riches of the glory of His inheritance in the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:56
verses.text: This too is as yet hidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:57
verses.text: But what is clear? that through His power we have believed that He hath raised Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:58
verses.text: For to persuade souls, is a thing far more miraculous than to raise a dead body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:59
verses.text: I will endeavor to make this clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:60
verses.text: Hearken then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:61
verses.text: Christ said to the dead, "Lazarus, come forth," (John xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:62
verses.text: ) and straightway he obeyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:63
verses.text: Peter said, "Tabitha, arise," (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:64
verses.text: ) and she did not refuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:65
verses.text: He Himself shall speak the word at the last day, and all shall rise, and that so quickly, that "they which are yet alive, shall in no wise precede them that are fallen asleep," ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:66
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:67
verses.text: ) and all shall come to pass, all run together "in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:68
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:69
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:70
verses.text: ) But in the matter of believing, it is not thus, but how is it? Hearken then to Him again, how He saith, "How often would I have gathered thy children together, and ye would not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:71
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:72
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:73
verses.text: ) You perceive that this last is the more difficult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:74
verses.text: Accordingly, it is upon this that he builds up the whole argument; because by human calculations it is far more difficult to influence the choice, than to work upon nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:75
verses.text: And the reason is this, it is because He would thus have us become good of our own will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:76
verses.text: Thus with good reason does he say,  "The exceeding greatness of His power to us-ward who believe".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:77
verses.text: Yes, when Prophets had availed nothing, nor Angels, nor Archangels, when the whole creation, both visible and invisible, had failed, (the visible lying before us, and without any power to guide us, and much also which is invisible,) then He ordered His own coming, to show us that it was a matter which required Divine power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:78
verses.text: "The riches of the glory,"  That is, the unutterable glory; for what language shall be adequate to express that glory of which the saints shall then be partakers? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:79
verses.text: But verily there is need of grace in order that the understanding may perceive it, and admit even so much as at least one little ray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:80
verses.text: Some things indeed they knew even before; now he was desirous that they should learn more, and know it more clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:81
verses.text: Seest thou how great things He hath wrought? He hath raised up Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:82
verses.text: Is this a small thing? But look again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:83
verses.text: He hath set Him at His right hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:84
verses.text: And shall any language then be able to represent this? Him that is of the earth, more mute than the fishes, and made the sport of devils, He hath in a moment raised up on high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:85
verses.text: Truly this is indeed the "exceeding greatness of His power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:86
verses.text: And behold, whither He hath raised Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:87
verses.text: "In the heavenly places;"  He hath made Him far above all created nature, far above all rule and authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:88
verses.text: "Far above all rule," he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:89
verses.text: Need then indeed is there of the Spirit, of an understanding wise in the knowledge of Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:90
verses.text: Need then is there indeed of revelation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:91
verses.text: Reflect, how vast is the distance between the nature of man and of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:92
verses.text: Yet from this vile estate hath He exalted Him to that high dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:93
verses.text: Nor does He mount by degrees, first one step, then another, then a third.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:94
verses.text: Amazing! He does not simply say, "above," but, "far above;" for God is above those powers which are above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:95
verses.text: And thither then hath He raised Him, Him that is one of us, brought Him from the lowest point to the supremest sovereignty, to that beyond which there is no other honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:96
verses.text: Above "all" principality, he says, not, i-e:, over one and not over another, but over all,  "Rule and authority and power, and dominion, and every name that is named".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:97
verses.text: Whatever there be in Heaven, He has become above all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:98
verses.text: And this is said of Him that was raised from the dead which is worthy of our admiration; for of God the Word, it cannot possibly be, because what insects are in comparison of man, this the whole creation is in comparison of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:99
verses.text: If all mankind are to be counted as spittle and were counted as the turn of a balance, consider the invisible powers as insects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:100
verses.text: But of Him that was one of us, this is great and surprising indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:101
verses.text: For He raised Him up from the very lowest parts of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:102
verses.text: If all the nations are as a drop, how small a portion then of that drop is a single man! Yet Him hath He made higher than all things, "not only in this world, but also in that which is to come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:103
verses.text: Therefore powers there are whose names are to us unintelligible, and unknown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:104
verses.text: "And He put all things in subjection under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:105
verses.text: Not simply so set Him above them as to be honored above them, nor by way of comparison with them, but so that He should sit over them as His slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:106
verses.text: Amazing! Awful indeed are these things; every created power hath been made the slave of man by reason of God the Word dwelling in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:107
verses.text: For it is possible for a man to be above others, without having others in subjection, but only as preferred before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:108
verses.text: But here it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:109
verses.text: No, "He put all things in subjection under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:110
verses.text: And not simply put them in subjection, but in the most abject subjection, that below which there can be none.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:111
verses.text: Therefore he adds, "under His feet".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:112
verses.text: "And gave Him to be Head over all things to the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:113
verses.text: Amazing again, whither hath He raised the Church? as though he were lifting it up by some engine, he hath raised it up to a vast height, and set it on yonder throne; for where the Head is, there is the body also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:114
verses.text: There is no interval to separate between the Head and the body; for were there a separation, then were it no longer a body, then were it no longer a head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:115
verses.text: "Over all things," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:116
verses.text: What is meant by "over all things?" He hath suffered neither Angel nor Archangel nor any other being to be above Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:117
verses.text: But not only in this way hath He honored us, in exalting that which is of ourselves, but also in that He hath prepared the whole race in common to follow Him, to cling to Him, to accompany His train.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:118
verses.text: "Which is His body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:119
verses.text: In order then that when you hear of the Head you may not conceive the notion of supremacy only, but also of consolidation, and that you may behold Him not as supreme Ruler only, but as Head of a body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:120
verses.text: "The fulness of Him that filleth all in all" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:121
verses.text: As though this were not sufficient to show the close connection and relationship, what does he add? "The fullness of Christ is the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:122
verses.text: And rightly, for the complement of the head is the body, and the complement of the body is the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:123
verses.text: Mark what great arrangement Paul observes, how he spares not a single word, that he may represent the glory of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:124
verses.text: "The, complement," he says, i-e:, the head is, as it were, filled up by the body, because the body is composed and made up of all its several parts, and he introduces Him as having need of each single one and not only of all in common and together; for unless we be many, and one be the hand, and another the foot, and another some other member, the whole body is not filled up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:125
verses.text: It is by all then that His body is filled up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:126
verses.text: Then is the head filled up, then is the body rendered perfect, when we are all knit together and united.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:127
verses.text: Perceivest thou then the "riches of the glory of His inheritance? the exceeding greatness of His power towards them that believe? the hope of your calling?"  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:128
verses.text: Let us reverence our Head, let us reflect of what a Head we are the body,—a Head, to whom all things are put in subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:129
verses.text: According to this representation we ought to be better, yea, than the very angels, and greater than the Archangels, in that we have been honored above them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:130
verses.text: God "took not hold of Angels," as he says in writing to the Hebrews, "but He took hold of the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:131
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:132
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:133
verses.text: ) He took hold of neither principality nor power, nor dominion, nor any other authority, but He took up our nature, and made it to sit on His right hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:134
verses.text: And why do I say, hath made it sit? He hath made it His garment, and not only so, but hath put all things in subjection under His feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:135
verses.text: How many sorts of death supposest thou? How many souls? ten thousand? yea, and ten thousand times told, but nothing equal to it wilt thou mention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:136
verses.text: Two things He hath done, the greatest things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:137
verses.text: He hath both Himself descended to the lowest depth of humiliation, and hath raised up man to the height of exaltation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:138
verses.text: He saved him by His blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:139
verses.text: He spoke of the former first, how that He so greatly humbled Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:140
verses.text: He speaks now of what is stronger than that—a great thing, the crown of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:141
verses.text: Surely, even had we been counted worthy of nothing, it were enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:142
verses.text: Or, had we been counted worthy even of this honor, it were enough, without the slaying of the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:143
verses.text: But where there are the two, what power of language must it not transcend and surpass? The very resurrection is not great, when I reflect on these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:144
verses.text: It is of Him that he says, "The God of our Lord Jesus Christ," not of God the Word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:145
verses.text: Let us feel awed at the closeness of our relation, let us dread lest any one should be cut off from this body, lest any one should fall from it, lest any one should appear unworthy of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:146
verses.text: If any one were to place a diadem about our head, a crown of gold, should we not do every thing that we might seem worthy of the lifeless jewels? But now it is not a diadem that is about our head, but, what is far greater, Christ is made our very Head, and yet we pay no regard to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:147
verses.text: Yet Angels reverence that Head, and Archangels, and all those powers above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:148
verses.text: And shall we, which are His body, be awed neither on the one account nor the other? And what then shall be our hope of salvation? Conceive to yourself the royal throne, conceive the excess of the honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:149
verses.text: This, at least if we chose, might more avail to startle us, yea, even than hell itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:150
verses.text: For, even though hell were not, that we having been honored with such an honor, should be found base and unworthy of it, what punishment, what vengeance must not this carry with it? Think near whom thy Head is seated, (this single consideration is amply sufficient for any purpose whatever,) on whose right hand He is placed, far above all principality, and power, and might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:151
verses.text: Yet is the body of this Head trampled on by the very devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:152
verses.text: Nay, God forbid it should be thus; for were it thus, such a body could be His body no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:153
verses.text: Thy own head the more respectable of thy servants reverence, and dost thou subject thy body to be the sport of them that insult it? How sore punishment then shalt thou not deserve? If a man should bind the feet of the emperor with bonds and fetters, will he not be liable to the extremity of punishment? Dost thou expose the whole body to fierce monsters, and not shudder?  However, since our discourse is concerning the Lord's body, come, and let us turn our thoughts to it, even that which was crucified, which was nailed, which is sacrificed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:154
verses.text: If thou art the body of Christ, bear the Cross, for He bore it: bear spitting, bear buffetings, bear nails.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:155
verses.text: Such was that Body; that Body "did no sin, neither was guile found in His mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:156
verses.text: ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:157
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:158
verses.text: ) His hands did every thing for the benefit of them that needed, His mouth uttered not a word of those things which are not convenient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:159
verses.text: He heard them say, "Thou hast a devil," and He answered nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:160
verses.text: Further, our discourse is concerning this Body, and as many of us as partake of that Body and taste of that Blood, are partaking of that which is in no wise different from that Body, nor separate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:161
verses.text: Consider that we taste of that Body that sitteth above, that is adored by Angels, that is next to the Power that is incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:162
verses.text: Alas! how many ways to salvation are open to us! He hath made us His own body, He hath imparted to us His own body, and yet not one of these things turns us away from what is evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:163
verses.text: Oh the darkness, the depth of the abyss, the apathy! "Set your mind," saith he, "on the things that are above, where Christ is, seated on the right hand of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:164
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:165
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:166
verses.text: ) And after all this, some set their affections upon money, or licentiousness, others are carried captive by their passions!  Do ye not see, that even in our own body, when any part is superfluous and useless, it is cut off, is cut away? It is of no use that it has belonged to the body, when it is mutilated, when it is mortified, when it is decayed, when it is detrimental to the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:167
verses.text: Let us not then be too confident, because we have been once made members of this body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:168
verses.text: If this body of ours, though but a natural body, nevertheless suffers amputation, what dreadful evil shall it not undergo, if the moral principle should fail? When the body partakes not of this natural food, when the pores are stopped up, then it mortifies; when the ducts are closed, then it is palsied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:169
verses.text: So is it with us also, when we stop our ears, our soul becomes palsied; when we partake not of the spiritual food, when, instead of corrupt bodily humors, evil dispositions impair us, all these things engender disease, dangerous disease, disease that wastes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:170
verses.text: And then there will be need of that fire, there will be need of that cutting asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:171
verses.text: For Christ cannot endure that we should enter into the bride-chamber with such a body as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:172
verses.text: If He led away, and cast out the man that was clothed in filthy garments, what will He not do unto the man who attaches filth to the body; how will He not dispose of him?  I observe many partaking of Christ's Body lightly and just as it happens, and rather from custom and form, than consideration and understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:173
verses.text: When, saith a man, the holy season of Lent sets in, whatever a man may be, he partakes of the mysteries, or, when the day of the Lord's Epiphany comes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:174
verses.text: And yet it is not the Epiphany, nor is it Lent, that makes a fit time for approaching, but it is sincerity and purity of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:175
verses.text: With this, approach at all times; without it, never.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:176
verses.text: "For as often," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:177
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:178
verses.text: ) saith he, "as ye do this, ye proclaim the Lord's death," i-e:, "ye make a remembrance of the salvation that has been wrought for you, and of the benefits which I have bestowed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:179
verses.text: Consider those who partook of the sacrifices under the old Covenant, how great abstinence did they practise? How did they not conduct themselves? What did they not perform? They were always purifying themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:180
verses.text: And dost thou, when thou drawest nigh to a sacrifice, at which the very Angels tremble, dost thou measure the matter by the revolutions of seasons? and how shalt thou present thyself before the judgment-seat of Christ, thou who presumest upon His body with polluted hands and lips? Thou wouldest not presume to kiss a king with an unclean mouth, and the King of heaven dost thou kiss with an unclean soul? It is an outrage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:181
verses.text: Tell me, wouldest thou choose to come to the Sacrifice with unwashen hands? No, I suppose, not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:182
verses.text: But thou wouldest rather choose not to come at all, than come with soiled hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:183
verses.text: And then, thus scrupulous as thou art in this little matter, dost thou come with soiled soul, and thus dare to touch it? And yet the hands hold it but for a time, whereas into the soul it is dissolved entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:184
verses.text: What, do ye not see the holy vessels so thoroughly cleansed all over, so resplendent? Our souls ought to be purer than they, more holy, more brilliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:185
verses.text: And why so? Because those vessels are made so for our sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:186
verses.text: They partake not of Him that is in them, they perceive Him not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:187
verses.text: But we do;—yes, verily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:188
verses.text: Now then, thou wouldest not choose to make use of a soiled vessel, and dost thou approach with a soiled soul? Observe the vast inconsistency of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:189
verses.text: At the other times ye come not, no, not though often ye are clean; but at Easter, however flagrant an act ye may have committed, ye come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:190
verses.text: Oh! the force of custom and of prejudice! In vain is the daily Sacrifice, in vain do we stand before the Altar; there is no one to partake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:191
verses.text: These things I am saying, not to induce you to partake any how, but that ye should render yourselves worthy to partake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:192
verses.text: Art thou not worthy of the Sacrifice, nor of the participation? If so, then neither art thou of the prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:193
verses.text: Thou hearest the herald, standing, and saying, "As many as are in penitence, all pray".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:194
verses.text: As many as do not partake, are in penitence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:195
verses.text: If thou art one of those that are in penitence, thou oughtest not to partake; for he that partakes not, is one of those that are in penitence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:196
verses.text: Why then does he say, "Depart, ye that are not qualified to pray," whilst thou hast the effrontery to stand still? But no, thou art not of that number, thou art of the number of those who are qualified to partake, and yet art indifferent about it, and regardest the matter as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:197
verses.text: Look, I entreat: a royal table is set before you, Angels minister at that table, the King Himself is there, and dost thou stand gaping? Are thy garments defiled, and yet dost thou make no account of it?—or are they clean? Then fall down and partake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:198
verses.text: Every day He cometh in to see the guests, and converseth with them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:199
verses.text: Yes, at this moment is he speaking to your conscience; "Friends, how stand ye here, not having on a wedding garment?" He said not, Why didst thou sit down? no, before he sat down, He declared him to be unworthy, so much as to come in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:200
verses.text: He saith not, "Why didst thou sit down to meat," but, "Why camest thou in?" And these are the words that He is at this very moment addressing to one and all of us that stand here with such shameless effrontery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:201
verses.text: For every one, that partaketh not of the mysteries, is standing here in shameless effrontery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:202
verses.text: It is for this reason, that they which are in sins are first of all put forth; for just as when a master is present at his table, it is not right that those servants who have offended him should be present, but they are sent out of the way: just so also here when the sacrifice is brought forth, and Christ, the Lord's sheep, is sacrificed; when thou hearest the words, "Let us pray together," when thou beholdest the curtains drawn up, then imagine that the Heavens are let down from above, and that the Angels are descending!  As then it is not meet that any one of the uninitiated be present, so neither is it that one of them that are initiated, and yet at the same time defiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:203
verses.text: Tell me, suppose any one were invited to a feast, and were to wash his hands, and sit down, and be all ready at the table, and after all refuse to partake; is he not insulting the man who invited him? were it not better for such an one never to have come at all? Now it is just in the same way that thou hast come here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:204
verses.text: Thou hast sung the Hymn with the rest: thou hast declared thyself to be of the number of them that are Worthy, by not departing with them that are unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:205
verses.text: Why stay, and yet not partake of the table? I am unworthy, thou wilt say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:206
verses.text: Then art thou also unworthy of that communion thou hast had in prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:207
verses.text: For it is not by means of the offerings only, but also by means of those canticles that the Spirit descendeth all around.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:208
verses.text: Do we not see our own servants, first scouring the table with a sponge, and cleaning the house, and then setting out the entertainment? This is what is done by the prayers, by the cry of the herald.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:209
verses.text: We scour the Church, as it were, with a sponge, that all things may be set out in a pure church, that there may be "neither spot nor wrinkle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:210
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:211
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:212
verses.text: ) Unworthy, indeed, both our eyes of these sights, and unworthy are our ears! "And if even a beast," it is said, "touch the mountain, it shall be stoned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:213
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:214
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:215
verses.text: ) Thus then they were not worthy so much as to set foot on it, and yet afterwards they both came near, and beheld where God had stood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:216
verses.text: And thou mayest, afterwards, come near, and behold: when, however, He is present, depart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:217
verses.text: Thou art no more allowed to be here than the Catechumen is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:218
verses.text: For it is not at all the same thing never to have reached the mysteries, and when thou hast reached them, to stumble at them and despise them, and to make thyself unworthy of this thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:219
verses.text: One might enter upon more points, and those more awful still; not however to burden your understanding, these will suffice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:220
verses.text: They who are not brought to their right senses with these, certainly will not be with more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:221
verses.text: That I may not then be the means of increasing your condemnation, I entreat you, not to forbear coming, but to render yourselves worthy both of being present, and of approaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:222
verses.text: Tell me, were any king to give command and to say, "If any man does this, let him partake of my table;" say, would ye not do all ye could to be admitted? He hath invited us to heaven, to the table of the great and wonderful King, and do we shrink and hesitate, instead of hastening and running to it? And what then is our hope of salvation? We cannot lay the blame on our weakness; we cannot on our nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:223
verses.text: It is indolence and nothing else that renders us unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:224
verses.text: So far have I spoken of myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:225
verses.text: But may He that pricketh the heart, He that giveth the Spirit of compunction, pierce your hearts, and plant the seeds in the depth of them, that so through His fear ye may conceive, and bring forth the spirit of salvation, and come near with boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:226
verses.text: For, "thy children," it is said, "are like olive plants round about thy table".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:227
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:228
verses.text: cxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:229
verses.text: ) O, then, let there be nothing old, nothing wild, nothing harsh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:230
verses.text: For of such sort are the young plants that are fit for fruit, for the beautiful fruit, fruit I mean of the olive-tree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:231
verses.text: And thriving they are, so as all to be round about the table, and come together here, not in vain or by chance, but with fear and reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 4:232
verses.text: For thus shall ye behold with boldness even Christ Himself in heaven, and shall be counted worthy of that heavenly kingdom, which may God grant we may all attain, in Jesus Christ, our Lord with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and for ages of ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:2
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:3
verses.text: Verses –  "And you did He quicken, when ye were dead through your trespasses and sins, wherein aforetime ye walked, according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, of the spirit that now worketh in the sons of disobedience; among whom we also all once lived, in the lusts of our flesh, doing the desires of the flesh, and of the mind; and were by nature children of wrath even as the rest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:4
verses.text: There is, we know, a corporal, and there is also a spiritual, dying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:5
verses.text: Of the first it is no crime to partake, nor is there any peril in it, inasmuch as there is no blame attached to it, for it is a matter of nature, not of deliberate choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:6
verses.text: It had its origin in the transgression of the first-created man, and thenceforward in its issue it passed into a nature, and, at all events, will quickly be brought to a termination; whereas this spiritual dying, being a matter of deliberate choice, has criminality, and has no termination.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:7
verses.text: Observe then how Paul, having already shown how exceedingly great a thing it is, in so much that to heal a deadened soul is a far greater thing than to raise the dead, so now again lays it down in all its real greatness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:8
verses.text: "And you," saith he "when ye were dead through your trespasses and sins, wherein aforetime ye walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, of the spirit that now worketh in the sons of disobedience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:9
verses.text: You observe the gentleness of Paul, and how on all occasions he encourages the hearer, not bearing too hard upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:10
verses.text: For whereas he had said, Ye have arrived at the very last degree of wickedness, (for such is the meaning of becoming dead,) that he may not excessively distress them, (because men are put to shame when their former misdeeds are brought forward, cancelled though they be, and no longer attended with danger,) he gives them, as it were, an accomplice, that it may not be supposed that the work is all their own, and that accomplice a powerful one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:11
verses.text: And who then is this? The Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:12
verses.text: He does much the same also in the Epistle to the Corinthians, where, after saying, "Be not deceived, neither fornicators, nor idolaters," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:13
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:14
verses.text: ) and after enumerating all the other vices, and adding in conclusion, "shall inherit the kingdom of God;" he then adds, "and such were some of you;" he does not say absolutely, "ye were," but "some of you were," that is, thus in some sort were ye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:15
verses.text: Here the heretics attack us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:16
verses.text: They tell us that these expressions ("prince of all the power of the air," etc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:17
verses.text: ) are used with reference to God, and letting loose their unbridled tongue, they fit these things to God, which belong to the Devil alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:18
verses.text: How then are we to put them to silence? By the very words they themselves use; for, if He is righteous, as they themselves allow, and yet hath done these things, this is no longer the act of a righteous being, but rather of a being most unrighteous and corrupted; and corrupted God cannot possibly be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:19
verses.text: Further, why does he call the Devil "the prince" of the world? Because nearly the whole human race has surrendered itself to him and all are willingly and of deliberate choice his slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:20
verses.text: And to Christ, though He promises unnumbered blessings, not any one so much as gives any heed; whilst to the Devil, though promising nothing of the sort, but sending them on to hell, all yield themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:21
verses.text: His kingdom then is in this world, and he has, with few exceptions, more subjects and more obedient subjects than God, in consequence of our indolence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:22
verses.text: "According to the power," saith he, "of the air, of the spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:23
verses.text: Here again he means, that Satan occupies the space under Heaven, and that the incorporeal powers are spirits of the air, under his operation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:24
verses.text: For that his kingdom is of this age, i-e:, will cease with the present age, hear what he says at the end of the Epistle; "Our wrestling is not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities, against powers, against the world rulers of this darkness;" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:25
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:26
verses.text: ) where, lest when you hear of world-rulers you should therefore say that the Devil is uncreated, he elsewhere (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:27
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:28
verses.text: ) calls a perverse time, "an evil world," not of the creatures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:29
verses.text: For he seems to me, having had dominion beneath the sky, not to have fallen from his dominion, even after his transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:30
verses.text: "That now worketh," he says, "in the sons of disobedience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:31
verses.text: You observe that it is not by force, nor by compulsion, but by persuasion, he wins us over; "disobedience" or "untractableness" is his word, as though one were to say, by guile and persuasion he draws all his votaries to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:32
verses.text: And not only does he give them a word of encouragement by telling them they have an associate, but also by ranking himself with them, for he says,  "Among whom we also all once lived".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:33
verses.text: "All," because he cannot say that any one is excepted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:34
verses.text: "In the lusts of our flesh, doing the desires of the flesh, and of the mind, and were by nature children of wrath, even as the rest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:35
verses.text: That is, having no spiritual affections.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:36
verses.text: Yet, lest he should slander the flesh, or lest it should be supposed that the transgression was not great, observe how he guards the matter,  "Doing," he says, "the desires of the flesh and of the mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:37
verses.text: That is, the pleasurable passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:38
verses.text: We provoked God to anger, he saith, we provoked Him to wrath, we were wrath, and nothing else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:39
verses.text: For as he who is a child of man is by nature man, so also were we children of wrath even as others; i-e:, no one was free, but we all did things worthy of wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:40
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:41
verses.text: "But God, being rich in mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:42
verses.text: Not merely merciful, but rich in mercy; as it is said also in another place; "In the multitude of thy mercies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:43
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:44
verses.text: lxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:45
verses.text: ) And again, "Have mercy upon me, according to the multitude of thy tender mercies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:46
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:47
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:48
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:49
verses.text: "For His great love, wherewith He loved us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:50
verses.text: Why did He love us? For these things are not deserving of love, but of the sorest wrath, and punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:51
verses.text: And thus it was of great mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:52
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:53
verses.text: "Even when we were dead through our trespasses He quickened us together with Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:54
verses.text: Again is Christ introduced, and it is a matter well worthy of our belief, because if the Firstfruits live, so do we also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:55
verses.text: He hath quickened both Him, and us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:56
verses.text: Seest thou that all this is said of Christ incarnate? Beholdest thou "the exceeding greatness of His power to us-ward who believe?" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:57
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:58
verses.text: ) Them that were dead, them that were children of wrath, them hath he quickened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:59
verses.text: Beholdest thou "the hope of his calling?"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:60
verses.text: "He raised us up with Him and made us sit with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:61
verses.text: Beholdest thou the glory of His inheritance? That "He hath raised us up together," is plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:62
verses.text: But that He "hath made us sit with Him in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus," how does this hold? It holds as truly, as that He hath raised us together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:63
verses.text: For as yet no one is actually raised, excepting that inasmuch as as the Head hath risen, we also are raised, just as in the history, when Jacob did obeisance, his wife also did obeisance to Joseph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:64
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:65
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:67
verses.text: ) And so in the same way "hath He also made us to sit with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:68
verses.text: For since the Head sitteth, the body sitteth also with it, and therefore he adds "in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:69
verses.text: Or again, if it means, not this, it means that by the laver of Baptism He hath "raised us up with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:70
verses.text: How then in that case hath He made "us to sit with Him?" Because, saith he, "if we suffer we shall also reign with Him," ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:71
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:72
verses.text: ) if we be dead with Him we shall also live with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:73
verses.text: Truly there is need of the Spirit and of revelation, in order to understand the depth of these mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:74
verses.text: And then that ye may have no distrust about the matter, observe what he adds further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:76
verses.text: "That in the ages to come, He might show the exceeding riches of His grace, in kindness towards us, in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:77
verses.text: Whereas he had been speaking of the things which concerned Christ, and these might be nothing to us, (for what, it might be said, is it to us, that He rose) therefore he shows that they do moreover extend to us, inasmuch as He is made one with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:78
verses.text: Only that our concern in the matter he states separately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:79
verses.text: "Us," saith he, "who were dead through our trespasses He raised up with Him, and made us sit with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:80
verses.text: Wherefore, as I was saying, be not unbelieving, take the demonstration he adduces both from former things, and from His Headship, and also from His desire to show forth His goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:81
verses.text: For how will He show it, unless this come to pass? And He will show it in the ages to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:82
verses.text: What? that the blessings are both great, and more certain than any other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:83
verses.text: For now the things which are said may to the unbelievers seem to be foolishness; but then all shall know them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:84
verses.text: Wouldest thou understand too, how He hath made us sit together with Him? Hear what Christ Himself saith to the disciples, "Ye also shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:85
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:86
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:87
verses.text: ) And again, "But to sit on My right hand and on My left hand is not Mine to give, but it is for them for whom it hath been prepared of My Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:88
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:89
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:90
verses.text: ) So that it hath been prepared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:91
verses.text: And well saith he, "in kindness towards us in Christ Jesus," for to sit on His right hand is honor above all honor, it is that beyond which there is none other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:92
verses.text: This then he saith, that even we shall sit there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:93
verses.text: Truly this is surpassing riches, truly surpassing is the greatness of His power, to make us sit down with Christ, Yea, hadst thou ten thousand souls, wouldest thou not lose them for His sake? Yea, hadst thou to enter the flames, oughtest thou not readily to endure it? And He Himself too saith again, "Where I am, there shall also My servant be".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:94
verses.text: (John.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:95
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:96
verses.text: ) Why surely had ye to be cut to pieces every day, ought ye not, for the sake of these promises cheerfully to embrace it? Think, where He sitteth? above all principality and power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:97
verses.text: And with whom it is that thou sittest? With Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:98
verses.text: And who thou art? One dead, by nature a child of wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:99
verses.text: And what good hast thou done? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:100
verses.text: Truly now it is high time to exclaim, "Oh the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and the knowledge of God!" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:101
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:102
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:103
verses.text: "For by grace," saith he "have ye been saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:104
verses.text: In order then that the greatness of the benefits bestowed may not raise thee too high, observe how he brings thee down: "by grace ye have been saved," saith he,  "Through faith;"  Then, that, on the other hand, our free-will be not impaired, he adds also our part in the work, and yet again cancels it, and adds,  "And that not of ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:105
verses.text: Neither is faith, he means, "of ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:106
verses.text: Because had He not come, had He not called us, how had we been able to believe? for "how," saith he, "shall they believe, unless they hear?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:107
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:108
verses.text: ) So that the work of faith itself is not our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:109
verses.text: "It is the gift," said he, "of God," it is "not of works".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:110
verses.text: Was faith then, you will say, enough to save us? No; but God, saith he, hath required this, lest He should save us, barren and without work at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:111
verses.text: His expression is, that faith saveth, but it is because God so willeth, that faith saveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:112
verses.text: Since, how, tell me, doth faith save, without works? This itself is the gift of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:113
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:114
verses.text: "That no man should glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:115
verses.text: That he may excite in us proper feeling touching this gift of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:116
verses.text: "What then?" saith a man, "Hath He Himself hindered our being justified by works?" By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:117
verses.text: But no one, he saith, is justified by works, in order that the grace and loving-kindness of God may be shown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:118
verses.text: He did not reject us as having works, but as abandoned of works He hath saved us by grace; so that no man henceforth may have whereof to boast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:119
verses.text: And then, lest when thou hearest that the whole work is accomplished not of works but by faith, thou shouldest become idle, observe how he continues,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:120
verses.text: "For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God afore prepared that we should walk in them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:121
verses.text: Observe the words he uses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:122
verses.text: He here alludes to the regeneration, which is in reality a second creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:123
verses.text: We have been brought from non-existence into being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:124
verses.text: As to what we were before, that is, the old man, we are dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:125
verses.text: What we are now become, before, we were not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:126
verses.text: Truly then is this work a creation, yea, and more noble than the first; for from that one, we have our being; but from this last, we have, over and above, our well being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:127
verses.text: "For good works, which God afore prepared that we should walk in them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:128
verses.text: Not merely that we should begin, but that we should walk in them, for we need a virtue which shall last throughout, and be extended on to our dying day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:129
verses.text: If we had to travel a road leading to a royal city, and then when we had passed over the greater part of it, were to flag and sit down near the very close, it were of no use to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:130
verses.text: This is the hope of our calling; for "for good works" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:131
verses.text: Otherwise it would profit us nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:132
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:133
verses.text: Thus here he rejoices not that we should work one work, but all; for, as we have five senses, and ought to make use of all in their proper season, so ought we also the several virtues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:134
verses.text: Now were a man to be temperate and yet unmerciful, or were he to be merciful and yet grasping, or were he to abstain indeed from other people's goods, and yet not bestow his own, it would be all in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:135
verses.text: For a single virtue alone is not enough to present us with boldness before the judgment-seat of Christ; no, we require it to be great, and various, and universal, and entire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:136
verses.text: Hear what Christ saith to the disciples, "Go, ye and make disciples of all the nations,—teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I commanded you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:137
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:138
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:139
verses.text: ) And again, "Whosoever shall break one of these least commandments, shall be called least in the kingdom of Heaven," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:140
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:141
verses.text: ) that is, in the resurrection; nay, he shall not enter into the kingdom; for He is wont to call the time also of the resurrection, the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:142
verses.text: "If he break one," saith He, "he shall be called least," so that we have need of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:143
verses.text: And observe how it is not possible to enter without works of mercy; but if even this alone be wanting, we shall depart into the fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:144
verses.text: For, saith He, "Depart, ye cursed, into the eternal fire, which is prepared for the Devil and his angels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:145
verses.text: Why and wherefore? "For I was an hungered, and ye gave me no meat; I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:146
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:147
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:148
verses.text: ) Beholdest thou, how without any other charge laid against them, for this one alone they perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:149
verses.text: And for this reason alone too were the virgins also excluded from the bride-chamber, though sobriety surely they did possess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:150
verses.text: As the Apostle saith "and the sanctification, without which no man shall see the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:151
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:152
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:153
verses.text: ) Consider then, that without sobriety, it is impossible to see the Lord; yet it does not necessarily follow that with sobriety it is possible to see Him, because often-times something else stands in the way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:154
verses.text: Again, if we do all things ever so rightly, and yet do our neighbor no service, neither in that case shall we enter into the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:155
verses.text: Whence is this evident? From the parable of the servants entrusted with the talents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:156
verses.text: For, in that instance, the man's virtue was in every point unimpaired, and there had been nothing lacking, but forasmuch as he was slothful in his business, he was rightly cast out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:157
verses.text: Nay, it is possible, even by railing only, to fall into Hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:158
verses.text: "For whosoever" saith Christ, "shall say to his brother, Thou fool, shall be in danger of the hell of fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:159
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:160
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:161
verses.text: ) And if a man be ever so right in all things, and yet be injurious, he shall not enter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:162
verses.text: And let no one impute cruelty to God, in that he excludes those who fail in this matter, from the kingdom of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:163
verses.text: For even with men, if any one do any thing whatsoever contrary to the law, he is banished from the king's presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:164
verses.text: And if he transgresses so much as one of the established laws, if he lays a false accusation against another, he forfeits his office.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:165
verses.text: And if he commits adultery, and is detected, he is disgraced, and even though he have done ten thousand right acts, he is undone; and if he commits murder, and is convicted, this again is enough to destroy him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:166
verses.text: Now if the laws of men are so carefully guarded, how much more should those of God be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:167
verses.text: "But He is good," a man says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:168
verses.text: How long are we to be uttering this foolish talk? foolish, I say, not because He is not good, but in that we keep thinking that His goodness will be available to us for these purposes, though I have again and again used ten thousand arguments on this subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:169
verses.text: Listen to the Scripture, which saith, "Say not, His mercy is great, He will be pacified for the multitude of my sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:170
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:171
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:172
verses.text: ) He does not forbid us to say, "His mercy is great".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:173
verses.text: This is not what He enjoins; rather he would have us constantly say it, and with this object Paul raises all sorts of arguments, but his object is what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:174
verses.text: Do not, he means, admire the loving-kindness of God with this view, with a view to sinning, and saying, "His mercy will be pacified for the multitude of my sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:175
verses.text: For it is with this object that I too discourse so much concerning His goodness, not that we may presume upon it, and do any thing we choose, because in that way this goodness will be to the prejudice of our salvation; but that we may not despair in our sins, but may repent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:176
verses.text: For "the goodness of God leadeth thee to repentance," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:177
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:178
verses.text: ) not to greater wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:179
verses.text: And if thou become depraved, because of His goodness, thou art rather belying Him before men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:180
verses.text: I see many persons thus impugning the long-suffering of God; so that if thou use it not aright, thou shalt pay the penalty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:181
verses.text: Is God a God of loving-kindness? Yes, but He is also a righteous Judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:182
verses.text: Is He one who maketh allowance for sins? True, yet rendereth He to every man according to his works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:183
verses.text: Doth He pass by iniquity and blot out transgressions? True, yet maketh He inquisition also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:184
verses.text: How then is it, that these things are not contradictions? Contradictions they are not, if we distinguish them by their times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:185
verses.text: He doeth away iniquity here, both by the laver of Baptism, and by penitence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:186
verses.text: There He maketh inquisition of what we have done by fire and torment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:187
verses.text: "If then," some man may say, "I am cast out, and forfeit the kingdom, whether I have wrought ten thousand evil deeds or only one, wherefore may I not do all sorts of evil deeds?" This is the argument of an ungrateful servant; still nevertheless, we will proceed to solve even this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:188
verses.text: Never do that which is evil in order to do thyself good; for we shall, all alike fall short of the kingdom, yet in Hell we shall not all undergo the same punishment, but one a severer, another a milder one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:189
verses.text: For now, if thou and another have "despised God's goodness," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:190
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:191
verses.text: ) the one in many instances, and the other in a few, ye will alike forfeit the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:192
verses.text: But if ye have not alike despised Him, but the one in a greater, the other in a less degree, in Hell ye shall feel the difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:193
verses.text: Now then, why, it may be said, doth He threaten them who have not done works of mercy, that they shall depart into the fire, and not simply into the fire, but into that which is "prepared for the devil and his angels?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:194
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:195
verses.text: ) Why and wherefore is this? Because nothing so provokes God to wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:196
verses.text: He puts this before all terrible things; for if it is our duty to love our enemies, of what punishment shall not he be worthy, who turns away even from them that love him, and is in this respect worse than the heathen? So that in this case the greatness of the sin will make such an one go away with the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:197
verses.text: Woe to him, it is said, who doeth not alms; and if this was the case under the Old Covenant, much more is it under the New.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:198
verses.text: If, where the getting of wealth was allowed, and the enjoyment of it, and the care of it, there was such provision made for the succoring the poor, how much more in that Dispensation, where we are commanded to surrender all we have? For what did not they of old do? They gave tithes, and tithes again upon tithes for orphans, widows, and strangers; whereas some one was saying to me in astonishment at another, "Why, such an one gives tithes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:199
verses.text: What a load of disgrace does this expression imply, since what was not a matter of wonder with the Jews has come to be so in the case of the Christians? If there was danger then in omitting tithes, think how great it must be now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:200
verses.text: Again, drunkenness shall not inherit the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:201
verses.text: Yet what is the language of most people? "Well, if both I and he are in the same case, that is no little comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:202
verses.text: What then? First of all, that thou and he shall not reap the same punishment; but were it otherwise, neither is that any comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:203
verses.text: Fellowship in sufferings has comfort in it, when the miseries have any proportion in them; but when they exceed all proportion, and carry us beyond ourselves, no longer do they allow of our receiving any comfort at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:204
verses.text: For tell the man that is being tortured, and has entered into the flames, that such an one is undergoing the same, still he will not feel the comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:205
verses.text: Did not all the Israelites perish together? What manner of comfort did that afford them? Rather, did not this very thing distress them? And this was why they kept saying, We are lost, we are perished, we are wasted away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:206
verses.text: What manner of comfort then is there here? In vain do we comfort ourselves with such hopes as these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:207
verses.text: There is but one only comfort, to avoid falling into that unquenchable fire; but it is not possible for one who has fallen into it to find comfort, where there is the gnashing of teeth, where there is the weeping, where is the worm that dieth not, and the fire that is not quenched.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:208
verses.text: For shalt thou conceive any comfort at all, tell me, when thou art in so great tribulation and distress? Wilt thou then be any longer thyself? Let us not, I pray and entreat you, let us not vainly deceive ourselves and comfort ourselves with arguments like these; no, let us practise those virtues, which shall avail to save us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:209
verses.text: The object before us is to sit together with Christ, and art thou trifling about such matters as these? Why, were there no other sin at all, how great punishment ought we not to suffer for these very speeches themselves, because we are so insensate, so wretched, and so indolent, as, even with so vast a privilege before us, to talk thus? Oh! how much shalt thou have to lament, when thou shalt then consider them that have done good! When thou shalt behold slaves and base-born who have labored but a little here, there made partakers of the royal throne, will not these things be worse to thee than torment? For if even now, when thou seest any in high reputation, though thou art suffering no evil, thou regardest this as worse than any punishment, and by this alone art consumed, and bemoanest thyself, and weepest, and judgest it to be as bad as ten thousand deaths; what shalt thou suffer then? Why, even were there no hell at all, the very thought of the kingdom, were it not enough to destroy and consume thee? And that such will be the case, we have enough in our own experience of things to teach us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 5:210
verses.text: Let us not then vainly flatter our own souls with speeches like these; no, let us take heed, let us have a regard for our own salvation, let us make virtue our care, let us rouse ourselves to the practice of good works, that we may be counted worthy to attain to this exceeding glory, in Jesus Christ our Lord with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and for ages of ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:2
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:3
verses.text: Verses ,  "Wherefore remember, that aforetime ye the Gentiles in the flesh, who are called Uncircumcision by that which is called Circumcision in the flesh made by hands; that ye were at that time separate from Christ, alienated from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of the promise, having no hope, and without God in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:4
verses.text: There are many things to show the loving-kindness of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:5
verses.text: First, the fact, that by Himself He hath saved us, and by Himself through such a method as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:6
verses.text: Secondly, that He hath saved us, as being what we were.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:7
verses.text: Thirdly, that He hath exalted us to the place where we are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:8
verses.text: For all these things both contain in themselves the greatest demonstration of His loving-kindness, and they are the very subjects which Paul is now agitating in his Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:9
verses.text: He had been saying, that when we were dead through our trespasses, and children of wrath, He saved us; He is now telling us further, to whom He hath made us equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:10
verses.text: "Wherefore," saith he, "remember;" because it is usual with us, one and all, when we are raised from a state of great meanness to corresponding, or perhaps a greater, dignity, not so much as even to retain any recollection of our former condition, being nourished in this our new glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:11
verses.text: On this account it is that he says, "Wherefore remember".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:12
verses.text: —"Wherefore".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:13
verses.text: Why, "wherefore?" Because we have been created unto good works, and this were sufficient to induce us to cultivate virtue; "remember,"—for that remembrance is sufficient to make us grateful to our Benefactor,—"that ye were aforetime Gentiles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:14
verses.text: Observe how he lowers the superior advantages of the Jews and admires the disadvantages of the Gentiles; disadvantage indeed it was not, but he is arguing with each respectively from their character and manner of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:15
verses.text: "Who are called Uncircumcision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:16
verses.text: The honor then of the Jews is in names, their perogative is in the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:17
verses.text: For uncircumcision is nothing, and circumcision is nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:18
verses.text: "By that which is called," saith he, "Circumcision in the flesh made by hands, that ye were at that time separate from Christ, alienated from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of the promise, having no hope, and without God in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:19
verses.text: Ye, saith he, who were thus called by the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:20
verses.text: But why when he is about to show that the benefit bestowed upon them consisted in this, in having fellowship with Israel, does he disparage the Israelitish prerogative? He does not disparage it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:21
verses.text: In essential points he enhances it, but only in these points, in which they had no fellowship, he disparages it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:22
verses.text: For further on he says, "Ye are fellow-citizens of the saints and of the household of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:23
verses.text: Mark, how far he is from disparaging it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:24
verses.text: These points, saith he, are indifferent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:25
verses.text: Never think, saith he, that because ye happen not to be circumcised, and are now in uncircumcision, that there is any difference in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:26
verses.text: No, the real trouble was this, the being "without Christ," the being "aliens from the commonwealth of Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:27
verses.text: Whereas this circumcision is not "the commonwealth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:28
verses.text: Again, the being strangers from the covenants of promise, the having no hope to come, the being without God in this world, all these were parts of their condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:29
verses.text: He was speaking of heavenly things; he speaks also of those which are upon earth; since the Jews had a great opinion of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:30
verses.text: Thus also Christ in comforting His disciples, after saying, "Blessed are they that have been persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven," adds the lesser point of consolation, "for so," saith He, "persecuted they the prophets which were before you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:31
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:32
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:34
verses.text: ) For this, compared with the greatness of the other, is far less, yet in regard to the being nigh, and believing, it is great and sufficient, and has much force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:35
verses.text: This then was the sharing in the commonwealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:36
verses.text: His word is not, "separated," but "alienated from the commonwealth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:37
verses.text: His word is not, "ye took no interest in," but, "ye had not so much as any part in, and were strangers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:38
verses.text: The expressions are most emphatic, and indicate the separation to be very wide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:39
verses.text: Because the Israelites themselves were without this commonwealth, not however as aliens, but as indifferent to it, and they fell from the covenants, not however as strangers, but as unworthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:40
verses.text: But what were "the covenants of the promise?" "To thee and to thy seed," saith He, "will I give this land," (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:41
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:42
verses.text: ) and whatever else He promised.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:43
verses.text: "Having no hope," he adds, "and without God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:44
verses.text: Though gods indeed they worshipped, but they were no gods: "for an idol is not any thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:45
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:46
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:47
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:49
verses.text: "But now, in Christ Jesus, ye that once were far off, are made nigh in the blood of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:50
verses.text: For He is our peace, who made both one, and brake down the middle wall of partition, having abolished in His flesh the enmity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:51
verses.text: Is this then the great privilege, it may be said, that we are admitted into the commonwealth of the Jews? What art thou saying? "He hath summed up all things that are in heaven, and that are in earth," and now dost thou tell us about Israelites? Yes, he would say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:52
verses.text: Those higher privileges we must apprehend by faith; these, by the things themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:53
verses.text: "But now," saith he, "in Christ Jesus, ye that once were far off, are made nigh," in reference to the commonwealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:54
verses.text: For the "far off," and the "nigh," are matters of will and choice only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:55
verses.text: "For He is our peace, Who made both one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:56
verses.text: What is this, "both one?" He does not mean this, that He hath raised us to that high descent of theirs, but that he hath raised both us and them to a yet higher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:57
verses.text: Only that the blessing to us is greater, because to these it had been promised, and they were nearer than we; to us it had not been promised, and we were farther off than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:58
verses.text: Therefore it is that he says, "And that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:59
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:60
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:61
verses.text: ) The promise indeed He gave to the Israelites, but they were unworthy; to us He gave no promise, nay, we were even strangers, we had nothing in common with them; yet hath He made us one, not by knitting us to them, but by knitting both them and us together into one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:62
verses.text: I will give you an illustration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:63
verses.text: Let us suppose there to be two statues, the one of silver, the other of lead, and then that both shall be melted down, and that the two shall come out gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:64
verses.text: Behold, thus hath He made the two one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 6:65
verses.text: Or put the case again in another way.
