verses.text: For some know not even this; wherefore, they even say, numberless evils come to be in the world; and others know not the extent of this love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:129
verses.text: Nor, indeed, is Paul seeking to know its extent, nor with any view to measure it; for how could he? but only to understand this, that it is transcendent, and great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:130
verses.text: And this very thing, he says, he is able to show, even from the knowledge which hath been vouchsafed to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:131
verses.text: However, what is higher than the being "strengthened with might," in order to have Christ within? Vast are the things we ask, saith he, yet is He able to do above even them, so that not only doth He love us, but doth so intensely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:132
verses.text: Be it our care therefore, beloved, to understand the love of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:133
verses.text: A great thing indeed is this; nothing is so beneficial to us, nothing so deeply touches us: more availing this to convince our souls than the fear of hell itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:134
verses.text: Whence then shall we understand it? Both from the sources now mentioned, and from the things which happen every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:135
verses.text: For from what motive have these things been done for us? from what necessity on His part? None whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:136
verses.text: Over and over again he lays down love as the cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:137
verses.text: But the highest degree of love is that where men receive a benefit, without any prior service on their part to call for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:138
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:139
verses.text: And let us then be followers of Him; let us do good to our enemies, to them that hate us, let us draw near to those who turn their backs upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:140
verses.text: This renders us like unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:141
verses.text: "For if ye love them that love you," saith Christ, "what reward have ye?" "Do not even the Gentiles the same".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:142
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:143
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:144
verses.text: ) But what is a sure proof of love? To love him that hates thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:145
verses.text: I wish to give you some example, (pardon me,) and since I find it not among them that are spiritual, I shall quote an instance from them that are without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:146
verses.text: See ye not those lovers? How many insults are wreaked upon them by their mistresses, how many artifices practised, how many punishments inflicted: yet they are enchained to them, they burn for them, and love them better than their own souls, passing whole nights before their thresholds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:147
verses.text: From them let us take our example, not indeed to love such as those,—women, I mean, that are harlots; no, but thus to love our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:148
verses.text: For tell me, do not harlots treat their lovers with greater insolence than all the enemies in the world, and squander away their substance, and cast insult in their face, and impose upon them more servile tasks than upon their own menials? And yet still they desist not, though no one hath so great an enemy in any one, as the lover in his mistress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:149
verses.text: Yea, this beloved one disdains, and reviles, and oftentimes maltreats him, and the more she is loved, the more she scorns him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:150
verses.text: And what can be more brutal than a spirit like this? Yet notwithstanding he loves her still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:151
verses.text: But possibly we shall find love like this in spiritual characters also, not in those of our day, (for it has "waxed cold,") (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:152
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:153
verses.text: ) but in those great and glorious men of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:154
verses.text: Moses, the blessed Moses, surpassed even those that love with human passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:155
verses.text: How, and in what way? First, he gave up the court, and the luxury, and the retinue, and the glory attending it, and chose rather to be with the Israelites.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:156
verses.text: Yet is this not only what no one else would ever have done, but would have even been ashamed, were another to have discovered him, of being found to be a kinsman of men, who were slaves and not only slaves, but were looked upon as even execrable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:157
verses.text: Yet was he not only not ashamed of his kindred, but with all his spirit defended them, and threw himself into dangers for their sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:158
verses.text: (Acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:159
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:160
verses.text: ) How? Seeing, it is said, one doing an injury to one of them, he defended him that suffered the injury, and slew him that inflicted it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:161
verses.text: But this is not as yet for the sake of enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:162
verses.text: Great indeed is this act of itself, but not so great as what comes afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:163
verses.text: The next day, then, he saw the same thing taking place, and when he saw him whom he had defended doing his neighbor wrong, he admonished him to desist from his wrong-doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:164
verses.text: But he said, with great ingratitude, "Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?" (Acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:165
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:166
verses.text: ) Who would not have taken fire at these words? Had then the former act been that of passion and frenzy, then would he have smitten and killed this man also; for surely he on whose behalf it was done, never would have informed against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:167
verses.text: But because they were brethren, it is said, he spoke thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:168
verses.text: When he the Hebrew was being wronged, he uttered no such word "Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?" "Wherefore saidst thou not this yesterday?" Moses would say, "Thy injustice, and thy cruelty, these make me a ruler and a judge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:169
verses.text: But now, mark, how that some, in fact, say as much even to God Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:170
verses.text: Whenever they are wronged indeed, they would have Him a God of vengeance, and complain of His long suffering; but when themselves do wrong, not for a moment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:171
verses.text: However, what could be more bitter than words like these? And yet notwithstanding, after this, when he was sent to that ungrateful, to that thankless race, he went, and shrunk not back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:172
verses.text: Yea, and after those miracles, and after the wonders wrought by his hand, oftentimes they sought to stone him to death and he escaped out of their hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:173
verses.text: They kept murmuring too incessantly, and yet still, notwithstanding, so passionately did he love them, as to say unto God, when they committed that heinous sin, "Yet now if Thou wilt forgive, forgive their sin; and if not, blot even me also out of the book which Thou hast written".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:174
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:175
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:176
verses.text: ) Fain would I perish, saith he, with them, rather than without them be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:177
verses.text: Here, verily, is love even to madness, verily, unbounded love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:178
verses.text: What sayest thou, Moses? Art thou regardless of Heaven? I am, saith he, for I love those who have wronged me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:179
verses.text: Prayest thou to be blotted out? Yea, saith he, what can I do, for it is love? And what again after these things? Hear what the Scripture saith elsewhere; "And it went ill with Moses for their sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:180
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:181
verses.text: cvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:182
verses.text: ) How often did they wax wanton? How often did they reject both himself and his brother? How often did they seek to return back to Egypt? and yet after all these things did he burn, yea, was beside himself with love for them, and was ready to suffer for their sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:183
verses.text: Thus ought a man to love his enemies; by lamentation, by unwearied endurance, by doing everything, by showing all favor, to aim at their salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:184
verses.text: And what again, tell me, did Paul? did he not ask even to be accursed in their stead? (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:185
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:186
verses.text: ) But the great pattern we must of necessity derive from the Lord, for thus doth He also Himself, where he saith, "For He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and the good," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:187
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:188
verses.text: ) adducing the example from His Father; but we from Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:189
verses.text: He came unto them, in His Incarnation, I mean, He became a servant for their sakes, "He humbled Himself, He emptied Himself, He took the form of a servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:190
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:191
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:193
verses.text: ) And when He came unto them, He went not Himself aside "into any way of the Gentiles," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:194
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:195
verses.text: ) and gave the same charge to His disciples, and not only so, but "He went about healing all manner of disease, and all manner of sickness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:196
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:197
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:198
verses.text: ) And what then? All the rest indeed were astonished, and marvelled, and said, "Whence, then, hath this man all these things?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:199
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:200
verses.text: ) But these, the objects of His beneficence, these said, "He hath a devil," (John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:201
verses.text: ) and "blasphemeth," (John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:202
verses.text: ) and "is mad," and is a "deceiver," (John vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:203
verses.text: , and Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:204
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:205
verses.text: ) Did he therefore cast them away? No, in no wise, but when He heard these sayings, He even yet more signally bestowed His benefits upon them, and went straightway to them that were about to crucify Him, to the intent that He might but only save them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:206
verses.text: And after He was crucified, what were His words? "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:207
verses.text: (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:208
verses.text: ) Both cruelly treated before this, and cruelly treated after this, even to the very latest breath, for them He did every thing, in their behalf He prayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:209
verses.text: Yea, and after the Cross itself, what did He not do for their sakes? Did He not send Apostles? Did He not work miracles? Did He not shake the whole world?  Thus is it we ought to love our enemies, thus to imitate Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:210
verses.text: Thus did Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:211
verses.text: Stoned, suffering unnumbered cruelties, yet did he all things for their good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:212
verses.text: Hear his own words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:213
verses.text: "My heart's desire and my supplication to God is for them that they may be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:214
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:215
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:217
verses.text: ) And again; "For I bear them witness that they have a zeal for God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:218
verses.text: And again; "If thou, being a wild olive tree wast grafted in, how much more shall these be grafted into their own olive tree?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:219
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:220
verses.text: ) How tender, thinkest thou, must be the affection from which these expressions proceed, how vast the benevolence? it is impossible to express it, impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:221
verses.text: Thus is it we ought to love our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:222
verses.text: This is to love God, Who hath enjoined it, Who hath given it as His law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:223
verses.text: To imitate Him is to love our enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:224
verses.text: Consider it is not thine enemy thou art benefiting, but thyself; thou art not loving him, but art obeying God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 8:225
verses.text: Knowing therefore these things, let us confirm our love one to another, that we may perform this duty perfectly, and attain those good things that are promised in Christ Jesus our Lord, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, and honor, now, and for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:2
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:3
verses.text: Verses ,  "I therefore, the prisoner in the Lord, beseech you to walk worthily of the calling wherewith ye were called, with all lowliness and meekness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:4
verses.text: It is the virtue of teachers to aim not at praise, nor at esteem from those under their authority, but at their salvation, and to do every thing with this object; since the man who should make the other end his aim, would not be a teacher but a tyrant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:5
verses.text: Surely it is not for this that God set thee over them, that thou shouldest enjoy greater court and service, but that thine own interests should be disregarded, and every one of theirs built up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:6
verses.text: This is a teacher's duty: such an one was the blessed Paul, a man who was free from all manner of vanity, and was contented to be one of the many, nay more, to be the very least even of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:7
verses.text: Hence he even calls himself their servant, and so generally speaks in a tone of supplication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:8
verses.text: Observe him then even now writing nothing dictatorial, nothing imperious, but all chastened and subdued.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:9
verses.text: "I therefore," saith he, "the prisoner in the Lord, beseech you to walk worthily of the calling wherewith ye were called".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:10
verses.text: What is it, tell me, thou art beseeching? Is it that thou mayest gain any end for thyself? No, saith he, in no wise; it is that I may save others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:11
verses.text: And yet surely they who beseech, do so for things which are of importance to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:12
verses.text: True; and this, saith he, is of importance to myself, according to what he says also elsewhere in his writings, "Now we live, if ye stand fast in the Lord;" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:13
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:14
verses.text: ) for he ever earnestly desired the salvation of those whom he was instructing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:15
verses.text: "I, the prisoner in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:16
verses.text: Great and mighty dignity! Greater than that of king or of consul, or of any other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:17
verses.text: Hence it is the very title he uses in writing to Philemon, "As Paul the aged, and now a prisoner also of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:18
verses.text: (Philemon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:19
verses.text: ) For nothing is so glorious as a bond for Christ's sake, as the chains that were bound around those holy hands; more glorious is it to be a prisoner for Christ's sake than to be an Apostle, than to be a Teacher, than to be an Evangelist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:20
verses.text: Is there any that loveth Christ, he will understand what I am saying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:21
verses.text: Is any transported and fired with devotion for the Lord, he knows the power of these bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:22
verses.text: Such an one would rather choose to be a prisoner for Christ's sake, than to have the Heavens for his dwelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:23
verses.text: More glorious than any gold were the hands he was showing to them, yea, than any royal diadem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:24
verses.text: Yes, no jewelled tiara bound around the head invests it with such glory, as an iron chain for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:25
verses.text: Then was the prison more glorious than palaces, yea, than heaven itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:26
verses.text: Why say I than palaces? Because it contained a prisoner of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:27
verses.text: Is there any that loveth Christ, he knows the dignity of this title, he knows what a virtue is this, he knows how great a boon he bestowed upon mankind, even this, to be bound for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:28
verses.text: More glorious this, perhaps to be bound for His sake, than "to sit at His right hand," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:29
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:30
verses.text: ) more august this, than to "sit upon the twelve thrones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:31
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:32
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:33
verses.text: )  And why speak I of human glories? I am ashamed to compare earthly riches and golden attire to these bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:34
verses.text: But forbearing to speak of those great and heavenly glories, even were the thing attended with no reward at all, this alone were a great reward, this an ample recompense, to suffer these hardships for the sake of the Beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:35
verses.text: They that love, even though it be not God, but man, they know what I am saying, since they are more delighted to suffer for, than to be honored by those they love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:36
verses.text: But to fully understand these things belongs to the holy company, the Apostles, I mean, and them alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:37
verses.text: For hearken to what the blessed Luke saith, (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:38
verses.text: ) "that they departed from the presence of the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:39
verses.text: To all others indeed it seems to be foolishness, that to suffer dishonor is to be counted worthy, that to suffer dishonor is to rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:40
verses.text: But to them that understand the love of Christ, this is esteemed of all things the most blessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:41
verses.text: Were any to offer me my choice, the whole Heaven or that chain, that chain I would prefer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:42
verses.text: Were any to ask whether he should place me on high with the Angels, or with Paul in his bonds, the prison I would choose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:43
verses.text: Were any about to change me into one of those powers, that are in Heaven, that are round about the throne, or into such a prisoner as this, such a prisoner I would choose to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:44
verses.text: Nothing is more blessed than that chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:45
verses.text: Would that I could be at this moment in that very spot, (for the bonds are said to be still in existence,) to behold and admire those men, for their love of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:46
verses.text: Would that I could behold the chains, at which the devils fear and tremble, but which Angels reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:47
verses.text: Nothing is more noble than to suffer any evil for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:48
verses.text: I count not Paul so happy, because he was "caught up into Paradise," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:49
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:50
verses.text: ) as because he was cast into the dungeon; I count him not so happy, because he heard "unspeakable words," as because he endured those bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:51
verses.text: I count him not so happy, because he was "caught up into the third Heaven," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:52
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:53
verses.text: ) as I count him happy for those bonds' sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:54
verses.text: For that these are greater than those, hear how even he himself knew this; for he saith not, I who "heard unspeakable words," beseech you: but what? "I, the prisoner in the Lord, beseech you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:55
verses.text: Nor yet are we to wonder, though he inscribes not this in all his Epistles, for he was not always in prison, but only at certain times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:56
verses.text: I deem it more desirable to suffer evil for Christ's sake, than to receive honor at Christ's hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:57
verses.text: This is transcendent honor, this is glory that surpasseth all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:58
verses.text: If He Himself who became a servant for my sake, and "emptied" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:59
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:60
verses.text: ) His glory, yet thought not Himself so truly in glory, as when He was crucified for my sake, what ought not I to endure? For hear His own words: "Father, glorify Thou Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:61
verses.text: (John xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:62
verses.text: ) What is this thou art saying? Thou art being led to the cross with thieves and plunderers of graves, thou endurest the death of the accursed; Thou art about to be spit upon and buffeted; and callest Thou this glory? Yes, He saith, for I suffer these things for My beloved ones, and I count them altogether glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:63
verses.text: If He who loved the miserable and wretched calleth this glory, not to be on His Father's throne, nor in His Father's glory, but in dishonor,—if this was His glory, and if this He set before the other: much more ought I to regard these things as glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:64
verses.text: Oh! those blessed bonds! Oh! those blessed hands which that chain adorned! Not so worthy were Paul's hands when they lifted up and raised the lame man at Lystra, as when they were bound around with those chains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:65
verses.text: Had I been living in those times, how eagerly would I have embraced them, and put them to the very apple of mine eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:66
verses.text: Never would I have ceased kissing those hands which were counted worthy to be bound for my Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:67
verses.text: Marvellest thou at Paul, when the viper fastened on his hand, and did him no hurt? Marvel not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:68
verses.text: It reverenced his chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:69
verses.text: Yea, and the whole sea reverenced it; for then too was he bound, when he was saved from shipwreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:70
verses.text: Were any one to grant me power to raise the dead at this moment, I would not choose that power, but this chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:71
verses.text: Were I free from the cares of the Church, had I my body strong and vigorous, I would not shrink from undertaking so long a journey, only for the sake of beholding those chains, for the sake of seeing the prison where he was bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:72
verses.text: The traces indeed of his miracles are numerous in all parts of the world, yet are they not so dear as those of his scars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:73
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:74
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:75
verses.text: ) Nor in the Scriptures does he so delight me when he is working miracles, as when he is suffering evil, being scourged, and dragged about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:76
verses.text: Insomuch that from his body were carried away handkerchiefs or aprons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:77
verses.text: Marvellous, truly marvellous, are these things, and yet not so marvellous as those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:78
verses.text: "When they had laid many stripes upon him, they cast him into prison".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:79
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:80
verses.text: ) And again; being in bonds, "they were singing hymns unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:81
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:82
verses.text: ) And again; "They stoned him, and dragged him out of the city, supposing that he was dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:83
verses.text: (Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:84
verses.text: ) Would ye know how mighty a thing is an iron chain for Christ's sake, bound about His servant's body? Hearken to what Christ Himself saith, "Blessed are ye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:85
verses.text: (Mat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:86
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:87
verses.text: ) Why? When ye shall raise the dead? No.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:88
verses.text: But why? When ye shall heal the blind? Not at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:89
verses.text: But why then? "When men shall reproach you, and persecute you, and say all manner of evil against you falsely for My sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:90
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:91
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:92
verses.text: ) Now, if to be evil spoken of renders men thus blessed, to be evil entreated, what may not that achieve? Hearken to what this blessed one himself saith elsewhere; "Henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness:" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:93
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:94
verses.text: ) and yet, more glorious than this crown is the chain: of this, saith he, the Lord will count me worthy, and I am in no wise inquisitive about those things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:95
verses.text: Enough it is for me for every recompense, to suffer evil for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:96
verses.text: Let Him but grant me to say, that "I fill up that which is lacking of the afflictions of Christ:" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:97
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:98
verses.text: ) and I ask nothing further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:99
verses.text: Peter also was counted worthy of this chain; for he, we read, was bound, and delivered to soldiers, and was sleeping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:100
verses.text: (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:101
verses.text: ) Yet he rejoiced and was not diverted from his right mind and he fell into deep sleep which could not have been, had he been in any great anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:102
verses.text: However, he was sleeping, being between two soldiers: and an Angel came unto him, and smote him on the side, and raised him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:103
verses.text: Now then, were any one to say to me, Which wouldest thou? Wouldest thou be the Angel that struck Peter, or Peter that was delivered? I would rather choose to be Peter, for whose sake even the Angel came, yea, I would that I might enjoy those chains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:104
verses.text: And how is it, say ye, that, as being released from great evils, he prays? Marvel not: he prays, because he is afraid lest he should die; and of dying he is afraid, because he would fain have his life to be still a subject for further sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:105
verses.text: For hearken to what the blessed Paul himself also saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:106
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:107
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:109
verses.text: ) "To depart, and to be with Christ, is very far better;" "Yet to abide in the flesh is more needful for your sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:110
verses.text: This he calls even a favor where he writes, and says, "To you it hath been granted, (as a favor ἕχαρίσθη) in the behalf of Christ, not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer in His behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:111
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:112
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:113
verses.text: ) So that this latter is greater than the other: for He gave it of His free grace; verily, a favor it is, exceeding great, yea greater than any one of those, greater than to make the sun and the moon stand still, than to move the world! greater this than to have power over devils, or to cast out devils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:114
verses.text: The devils grieve not so much at being cast out by the faith which we exert, as when they behold us suffering any evil, and imprisoned for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:115
verses.text: For this increases our boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:116
verses.text: Not for this is it a noble thing to be in bonds for Christ's sake that it procures for us a kingdom; it is that it is done for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:117
verses.text: Not for this do I bless those bonds, for that they conduct on to Heaven; it is because they are worn for the sake of the Lord of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:118
verses.text: How great a boast to know that he was bound for Christ's sake! How great a happiness, how high an honor, how illustrious a distinction! Fain would I ever be dwelling on these subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:119
verses.text: Fain would I cling to this chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:120
verses.text: Fain would I, though in reality I have not the power, yet still in idea, bind this chain round my soul by a temper like his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:121
verses.text: "The foundations of the prison-house," we read, "were shaken" where Paul was bound, "and every one's bands were loosed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:122
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:123
verses.text: ) Beholdest thou then in bonds a nature that can dissolve bonds themselves? for as the Lord's death put death itself to death, so also did Paul's bonds loose the men in bonds, shake the house of bondage, open the doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:124
verses.text: Yet is not this the natural effect of bonds, but the very reverse; it is to keep him that is bound in safety, not to open for him the prison walls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:125
verses.text: No, of bonds then in general this is not the nature, but of those bonds which are for Christ's sake, it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:126
verses.text: "The jailor fell down before Paul and Silas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:127
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:128
verses.text: ) And yet neither is this again the effect of chains in general, to lay the binders at the feet of the bound: no, but, on the contrary, to put these last under the hands of the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:129
verses.text: Whereas here, the man who was free was under the feet of the man who had been bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:130
verses.text: The binder was beseeching him whom he had bound to release him from his fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:131
verses.text: Tell me, was it not thou that didst bind him? Didst thou not cast him into the inner prison? Didst thou not make his feet fast in the stocks? Why tremblest thou? Why art thou troubled? Why weepest thou? Why hast thou drawn thy sword? Never bound I, saith he, aught like this! I knew not that the prisoners of Christ had power so mighty as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:132
verses.text: What sayest thou? They received power to open Heaven, and should they not be able to open a prison? They loosed them that were bound by evil spirits, and was a piece of iron likely to conquer them? Thou knowest not the men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:133
verses.text: And therefore also wert thou pardoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:134
verses.text: That prisoner is Paul, whom all the Angels reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:135
verses.text: He is Paul, whose very handkerchiefs and napkins cast out devils, and chase diseases to flight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:136
verses.text: And sure the bond which is of the devil is adamantine, and far more indissoluble than iron; for this indeed binds the soul, the other only the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:137
verses.text: He therefore that released souls that were bound, shall not he have power to release his own body? He that could burst asunder the bonds of evil spirits, shall he not unloose a rivet of iron? He that by his very garments unloosed those prisoners, and released them from the spell of devils, shall not he of himself set himself at liberty? For this was he first bound himself, and then loosed the prisoners, that thou mightest understand that Christ's servants in bonds possess a power far greater than they that are at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:138
verses.text: Had one who was at liberty wrought this, then had it not been so marvellous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:139
verses.text: So then the chain was not a token of weakness, but rather of a greater power, and thus is the saint's might more illustriously displayed, when, even though in bonds, he overpowers them that are at liberty, when he that is in bonds sets not only himself at liberty, but them that are in bonds also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:140
verses.text: Where is the use of walls? What the advantage of thrusting him into the inner prison, whereas he opened the outer also? and why too was it done in the night? and why with an earthquake?  Oh, bear with me a little, and give me leave while I refrain from the Apostle's words, and revel in the Apostle's deeds, and banquet on Paul's chain; grant me still longer to dwell upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:141
verses.text: I have laid hold on that chain, and no one shall part me from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:142
verses.text: More securely at this moment am I bound by affection, than was he then in the stocks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:143
verses.text: This is a bond which no one can loose, for it is formed of the love of Christ; this neither the Angels, no, nor the kingdom of Heaven, has power to unloose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:144
verses.text: We may hear Paul's own words; (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:145
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:147
verses.text: ) "Neither angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers, nor height, nor depth, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:148
verses.text: Now then, why did the event take place at midnight? And wherefore too with an earthquake? Hearken, and marvel at the providential orderings of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:149
verses.text: Every one's bands were loosed, and the doors were opened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:150
verses.text: And yet was this done only for the jailor's sake, not with a view to display, but with a view to his salvation: for that the prisoners knew not that they were loosed, is evident from Paul's exclamation; for what said he? "He cried with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm, for we are all here".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:151
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:152
verses.text: ) But never would they all have been within, had they seen the doors opened, and themselves set at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:153
verses.text: They who were used to cut through walls, and to scale roofs and parapets, and to venture on all sorts of attempts in chains, never would have endured to remain within, with their bands loosed, and the doors opened, with the jailer himself asleep; no, but the bond of sleep was to them instead of the bonds of iron.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:154
verses.text: So that the thing took place and yet no damage ensued from the miracle to the jailer who was to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:155
verses.text: And besides this too, they that are bound are bound most securely in the night, not in the day; and so accordingly might we behold them bound again with all care and sleeping: but had these things been done in the day time, there would have been great stir and tumult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:156
verses.text: Then again, wherefore was the building shaken? It was to arouse the jailer, to behold what was done, for he alone was worthy of being saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:157
verses.text: And do thou too, behold, I pray, the exceeding greatness of the grace of Christ, for well were it in the midst of Paul's bonds to make mention also of the grace of God, nay indeed the very bonds themselves are of the gift and grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:158
verses.text: Some indeed there are who complain "Why was the jailer saved?" and from those very circumstances, for which they ought to admire the loving-kindness of God they find fault with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:159
verses.text: Nor is it anything to be wondered at.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:160
verses.text: Such are those sickly persons, that find fault even with the food that nourishes them, which they ought to prize, and who affirm that honey is bitter: and those dimsighted persons who are darkened by the very thing which ought to enlighten them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:161
verses.text: Not that these effects arise from the nature of the objects themselves, but from the weakness of the persons who are unable to use them properly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:162
verses.text: What, however, was I saying? When they ought to be admiring God's loving-kindness, in that He took a man who had fallen into the most desperate wickedness, and was making him better, they find fault: "Why, how was it that he did not take the thing to be the work of witchcraft and of sorcery, and confine them the more closely, and cry out?" Many things conspired to prevent this; first, that he heard them singing praises to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:163
verses.text: And sorcerers never would have been singing such hymns as those, for he heard them, it is said, singing praises unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:164
verses.text: Secondly, the fact, that they themselves did not take flight, but even withheld him from killing himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:165
verses.text: Now had they done it for their own sake, they never would have remained still within; they would themselves have escaped first of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:166
verses.text: Great again was their kindness also; they withheld the man from killing himself, even him who had bound them, thus all but saying unto him, "Truly, thou didst bind us with all safety, and most cruelly, that thou thyself mightest be loosed from the most cruel of all bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:167
verses.text: For every one is shackled with the chains of his own sins; and those bonds are accursed, whereas these for Christ's sake are blessed, and worth many an earnest prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:168
verses.text: For that these bonds can loose those other bonds of sin, he showed to us by things which are matters of sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:169
verses.text: Didst thou behold them released, who had been bound with iron? Thou shalt see thyself also delivered from other galling bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:170
verses.text: These bonds, the prisoners' bonds, not those of Paul, I mean, are the effect of those other bonds, the bonds of sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:171
verses.text: They who were confined within, were doubly prisoners, and the jailer himself was a prisoner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:172
verses.text: They indeed were bound both with iron and with sins, he with sins only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:173
verses.text: Them did Paul loose to assure the faith of him, for the chains which he loosed were visible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:174
verses.text: And thus too did Christ Himself; but rather in the inverse order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:175
verses.text: In that instance, there was a double palsy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:176
verses.text: What was it? There was that of the soul by sins, and also that of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:177
verses.text: What then did the Lord do? "Son," saith He, "be of good cheer, thy sins are forgiven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:178
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:179
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:181
verses.text: ) He first loosed the bonds of the real and true palsy, and then proceeds to the other: for when "certain of the Scribes said within themselves, This man blasphemeth; Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, Wherefore think ye evil in your hearts? For whether is easier, to say, Thy sins are forgiven, or to say, Arise, and walk? But, that ye may know that the Son of Man hath power on earth to forgive sins, (then saith he to the sick of the palsy,) Arise, and take up thy bed, and go unto thy house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:182
verses.text: Having wrought the invisible miracle, He confirmed it by the visible, the spiritual by the bodily cure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:183
verses.text: And why did He do thus? That it might be fulfilled, which is spoken, (Luke xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:184
verses.text: ) "Out of thine own mouth will I judge thee, thou wicked servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:185
verses.text: For what said they? "None can forgive sins, but God alone".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:186
verses.text: Of course, therefore, no Angel, nor Archangel, nor any other created power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:187
verses.text: This ye have yourselves confessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:188
verses.text: And what then ought to be said? If I shall be shown to have forgiven sins, it is fully evident that I am God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:189
verses.text: However, He said it not thus, but what said He? "But that ye may know that the Son of Man hath power on earth to forgive sins; then saith He to the sick of the palsy, Arise, and take up thy bed, and go unto thy house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:190
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:191
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:192
verses.text: ) When therefore, He would say, I work the more difficult miracle, it is plain that there is no pretext left you, no room for gainsaying about the easier one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:193
verses.text: Hence it was that He wrought the invisible miracle first, because there were many gainsayers; and then He led them from the invisible to the visible itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:194
verses.text: Surely then the faith of the jailer was no light or hasty faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:195
verses.text: He saw the prisoners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:196
verses.text: And he saw nothing, he heard nothing wrong; he saw that nothing was done by sorcery, for they were singing hymns unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:197
verses.text: He saw that every thing done proceeded from overflowing kindness, for they did not avenge themselves against him, although they had it in their power; for it was in their power to rescue both themselves and the prisoners, and escape; and if not the prisoners, at all events themselves; but they did not do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:198
verses.text: Thus did they challenge his reverence, not only by the miracle, but also by their behavior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:199
verses.text: For how did Paul cry out? "He cried with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm, for we are all here".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:200
verses.text: Thou seest at once his freedom from vain-glory and arrogance, and his fellow-feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:201
verses.text: He said not, "It is for us these wonders have been wrought," but as though he were merely one of the prisoners, he said, "For we are all here".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:202
verses.text: And yet, even though they had not before this loosed themselves, nor had done so by means of the miracle, still they might have been silent, and have set all that were bound at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:203
verses.text: For had they held their peace, and had they not with their loud crying stayed his hand, he would have thrust the sword through his throat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:204
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul cried out, because he had been cast into the inner ward: as though he had said, "To thine own injury hast thou done this, that thou hast thrust in so far those that could deliver thee from the danger".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:205
verses.text: However they imitated not the treatment they had received at his hands; though, had he died, all would have escaped.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:206
verses.text: Thou seest that they chose rather to remain in bonds, than to suffer him to perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:207
verses.text: Hence too might he reason within himself, "Had they been sorcerers, doubtless they would have set the others at liberty, and have released themselves from their bonds:" (for it is likely that many such had also been imprisoned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:208
verses.text: ) He was the more amazed, in that having often received sorcerers in charge, he had yet witnessed nothing done like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:209
verses.text: A sorcerer never would have shaken the foundations, so as to startle the jailer from sleep, and thus render his own escape more difficult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:210
verses.text: Now, however, let us proceed to look at the jailor's faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:211
verses.text: "And," saith the Scripture, "he called for lights and sprang in, and trembling for fear fell down before Paul and Silas, and brought them out, and said, Sirs, what must I do to be saved?" He grasped fire and sword, and cried, "Sirs, what must I do to be saved?" "And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, thou and thy house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:212
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:214
verses.text: ) "This is not the act of sorcerers," he would say, "to deliver a doctrine like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:215
verses.text: No mention any where here of an evil spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:216
verses.text: Thou seest how worthy he was to be saved: for when he beheld the miracle, and was relieved from his terror, he did not forget what most concerned him, but even in the midst of so great peril, he was solicitous about that salvation which concerned his soul: and came before them in such a manner as it was meet to come before teachers: he fell down at their feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:217
verses.text: "And they spake," it continues, "the word of the Lord, unto him with all that were in his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:218
verses.text: And he took them the same hour of the night, and washed their stripes; and was baptized, he and all his, immediately".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:219
verses.text: (Acts xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:221
verses.text: ) Observe the fervency of the man! He did not delay; he did not say, "Let day come, let us see, let us look about us;" but with great fervency, he was both himself baptized, and all his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:222
verses.text: Yes, not like most men now-a-days, who suffer both servants and wives and children to go unbaptized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:223
verses.text: Be ye, I beseech you, like the jailor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:224
verses.text: I say not, in authority, but in purpose; for what is the benefit of authority, where purpose is weak? The savage one, the inhuman one, who lived in the practice of unnumbered wrongs and made this his constant study, has become all at once so humane, so tenderly attentive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:225
verses.text: "He washed," it is said, "their stripes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:226
verses.text: And mark, on the other hand, the fervency of Paul also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:227
verses.text: Bound, scourged, thus he preached the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:228
verses.text: Oh, that blessed chain, with how great travail did it travail that night, what children did it bring forth! Yea of them too may he say, "Whom I have begotten in my bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:229
verses.text: (Philem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:230
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:231
verses.text: ) Mark thou, how he glories, and will have the children thus begotten, to be on that account the more illustrious! Mark thou, how transcendant is the glory of those bonds, in that they give lustre not only to him that wore them, but also to them who were on that occasion begotten by him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:232
verses.text: They have some advantage, who were begotten in Paul's bonds, I say not in respect of grace, (for grace is one and the same,) nor in respect of remission, (for remission is one and the same to all,) but in that they are thus from the very outset taught to rejoice and to glory in such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:233
verses.text: "The same hour of the night," it is said, "he took them, and washed their stripes, and was baptized".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:234
verses.text: And now then behold the fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:235
verses.text: He straightway recompensed them with his carnal things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:236
verses.text: "He brought them up into his house, and set meat before them, and rejoiced greatly with all his house, having believed in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:237
verses.text: For what was he not ready to do, now that by the opening of the prison doors, heaven itself was opened to him? He washed his teacher, he set food before him, and rejoiced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:238
verses.text: Paul's chain entered into the prison, and transformed all things there into a Church; it drew in its train the body of Christ, it prepared the spiritual feast, and travailed with that birth, at which Angels rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:239
verses.text: And was it without reason then that I said that the prison was more glorious than Heaven? For it became a source of joy there; yes, if "there is joy in Heaven over one sinner that repenteth," (Luke xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:240
verses.text: ) if, "where two or three are gathered together in His Name, there is Christ in the midst of them;" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:241
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:242
verses.text: ) how much more, where Paul and Silas, and the jailor and all his house were, and faith so earnest as theirs! Observe the intense earnestness of their faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:243
verses.text: But this prison has reminded me of another prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:244
verses.text: And what then is that? It is that where Peter was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:245
verses.text: Not, however, that any thing like this took place there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:246
verses.text: No.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:247
verses.text: He was delivered to four quaternions of soldiers to keep him and he sang not, he watched not, but he slept; neither, again, had he been scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:248
verses.text: And yet was the peril greater, for in the case before us indeed the end was accomplished, and the prisoners Paul and Silas, had undergone their punishment; but in his case it was yet to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:249
verses.text: So that though there were no stripes to torture him, yet was there the anticipation of the future to distress him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:250
verses.text: And mark too the miracle there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:251
verses.text: "Behold, an angel of the Lord," it is related, "stood by him, and a light shined in the cell; and he smote Peter on the side, and awoke him, saying, Rise up quickly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:252
verses.text: And his chains fell off from his hands".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:253
verses.text: (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:254
verses.text: ) In order that he might not imagine the transaction to be the work of the light alone, he also struck Peter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:255
verses.text: Now no one saw the light, save himself only, and he thought it was a vision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:256
verses.text: So insensible are they that are asleep to the mercies of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:257
verses.text: "And the angel," it proceeds, "said unto him, Gird thyself and bind on thy sandals; and he did so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:258
verses.text: And he saith unto him, Cast thy garment about thee, and follow me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:259
verses.text: And he went out and followed, and he wist not that it was true which was done by the angel; but thought he saw a vision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:260
verses.text: And when they were past the first and the second ward, they came unto the iron gate, that leadeth unto the city, which opened to them of his own accord; and they went out, and passed on through one street; and straightway the angel departed from him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:261
verses.text: (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:263
verses.text: ) Why was not the same thing done here as was done in the case of Paul and Silas? Because in that case they were intending to release them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:264
verses.text: On that account God willed not that they should be released in this manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:265
verses.text: Whereas in blessed Peter's case, they were intending to lead him forth to execution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:266
verses.text: But what then? Would it not have been far more marvellous, some one may say, had he been led forth, and delivered over into the king's hands, and then had been snatched away from the very midst of his imminent peril, and sustained no harm? For thus moreover, neither had the soldiers perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:267
verses.text: Great is the question which has been raised upon this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:268
verses.text: What! did God, it is said, save His own servant with the punishment of others, with the destruction of others? Now in the first place, it was not with the destruction of others; for this did not arise from the ordering of providence, but arose from the cruelty of the judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:269
verses.text: How so? God had so providentially ordered it, as that not only these men need not perish, but moreover that even he, the judge, should have been saved, just as in this case of the jailor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:270
verses.text: But he did not use the boon aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:271
verses.text: "Now as soon as it was day," it continues, "there was no small stir among the soldiers, what was become of Peter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:272
verses.text: And what then? Herod makes strict inquiry into the matter, "and he examined the guards," it is related, "and commanded that they should be put to death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:273
verses.text: (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:275
verses.text: ) Now, indeed, had he not examined them, there might have been some excuse for executing them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:276
verses.text: Whereas, as it is, he had them brought before him, he examined them, he found that Peter had been bound, that the prison had been well secured, that the keepers were before the doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:277
verses.text: No wall had been broken through, no door had been opened, nor was there any other evidence whatever of false dealing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:278
verses.text: He ought upon this to have been awed by the power of God, which had snatched Peter from the very midst of perils, and to have adored Him who was able to do such mighty works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:279
verses.text: But, on the contrary, he ordered those men off to execution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:280
verses.text: How then in this case is God the cause? Had He indeed caused the wall to be broken through, and thus had extricated Peter, possibly the deed might have been put to the account of their negligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:281
verses.text: But if He so providentially ordered it, as that the matter should be shown to be the work not of the evil agency of man, but of the miraculous agency of God, why did Herod act thus? For had Peter intended to flee, he would have fled as he was, with his chains on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:282
verses.text: Had he intended to fly, in his confusion he never would have had so great forethought as to take even his sandals, but he would have left them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:283
verses.text: Whereas, as it is, the object of the Angel's saying unto him, "Bind on thy sandals," was that they might know that he had done the thing not in the act of flight, but with full leisure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:284
verses.text: For, bound as he was, and fixed between the two soldiers, he never would have found sufficient time to unbind the chains also, and especially as he too, like Paul, was in the inner ward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:285
verses.text: Thus then was the punishment of the keepers owing to the unrighteousness of the judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:286
verses.text: For why did not the Jews act in the same way? For now again I am reminded of yet another prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:287
verses.text: The first was that at Rome, next, was this at Caesarea, now we come to that at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:288
verses.text: When then the chief Priests and the Pharisees heard from those whom they had sent to the prison to bring Peter out, that "they found no man within," but both doors "closed," and "the keepers standing at the doors," why was it that they not only did not put the keepers to death, but, so far from it, "they were much perplexed concerning them whereunto this would grow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:289
verses.text: Now if the Jews, murderous as they were in their designs against them, yet entertained not a thought of the kind, much more shouldest not thou, who didst every thing to please those Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:290
verses.text: For this unrighteous sentence vengeance quickly overtook Herod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:291
verses.text: But now if any complain of this, then complain too about those who are killed on the highway, and about the ten thousand others who are unjustly put to death, and further, of the infants also that were slaughtered at the time of Christ's birth; for Christ also, according to what thou allegest, was the cause of their deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:292
verses.text: But it was not Christ, but rather the madness and tyranny of Herod's father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:293
verses.text: Dost thou ask, Why then did He not snatch Him out of Herod's hands? True, He might have done so, but there would have been nothing gained by so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:294
verses.text: How many times, at least, did Christ escape even from the grasp of their hands? And yet what good did this do to that unfeeling people? Whereas here there is even much profit arising to the faithful from what was done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:295
verses.text: For as there were records made, and the enemies themselves bore testimony to the facts, the testimony was above suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:296
verses.text: As therefore in that instance the mouths of the enemies were stopped in no other way whatever, but only by the persons who came acknowledging the facts, so was it also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:297
verses.text: For why did the jailor here do nothing like what Herod did? Nay, and the things which Herod witnessed were not at all less wonderful than those which this man witnessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:298
verses.text: So far as wonder goes, it is no less wonderful to be assured that a prisoner came out when the doors were closed, than it is to behold them set open.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:299
verses.text: Indeed this last might rather have seemed to be perhaps a vision of the imagination, the other never could, when exactly and circumstantially reported.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:300
verses.text: So that, had this man been as wicked as Herod, he would have slain Paul, as Herod did the soldiers; but such he was not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:301
verses.text: If any one should ask, 'Why was it that God permitted the children also to be murdered?' I should fall, probably, into a longer discourse, than was originally intended to be addressed to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:302
verses.text: At this point, however, let us terminate our discourse, with many thanks to Paul's chain, for that it has been made to us the source of so many blessings, and exhorting you, should ye have to suffer any thing for Christ's sake, not only not to repine, but to rejoice, as the Apostles did, yea, and to glory; as Paul said, "Most gladly, therefore will I rather glory in my infirmities," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:303
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:304
verses.text: ) for because of this it was that he heard also those words, "My grace is sufficient for thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:305
verses.text: Paul glories in bonds; and dost thou pride thyself in riches? The Apostles rejoiced that they were counted worthy to be scourged, and dost thou seek for ease and self-indulgence? On what ground then, dost thou wish to attain the same end as they, if here on earth thou art traveling the contrary road from them? "And now," saith Paul, "I go bound in the spirit unto Jerusalem, not knowing the things that shall befall me there; save that the Holy Ghost testifieth unto me in every city, saying, that bonds and afflictions abide me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:306
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:307
verses.text: ) And why then dost thou set out, if bonds and afflictions abide thee? For this very reason, saith he, that I may be bound for Christ's sake, that I may die for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:308
verses.text: "For I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die for the name of the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:309
verses.text: (Acts xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:310
verses.text: )  Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:311
verses.text: Nothing can be more blessed than that soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:312
verses.text: In what does he glory? In bonds, in afflictions, in chains, in scars; "I bear branded on my body," saith he, "the marks of Jesus," (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:313
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:314
verses.text: ) as though they were some great trophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:315
verses.text: And again, "For because of the hope of Israel," saith he, "I am bound with this chain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:316
verses.text: (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:317
verses.text: ) And again, "For which I am an ambassador in chains".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:318
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:319
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:320
verses.text: ) What is this? Art thou not ashamed, art thou not afraid going about the world as a prisoner? Dost thou not fear lest any one should charge thy God with weakness? lest any one should on this account refuse to come near thee and to join the fold? No, saith he, not such are my bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:321
verses.text: They can shine brightly even in kings' palaces.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:322
verses.text: "So that my bonds," saith he, "became manifest in Christ, throughout the whole praetorian guard: and most of the brethren in the Lord, being confident through my bonds, are more abundantly bold to speak the word of God without fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:323
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:324
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:326
verses.text: ) Behold ye a force in bonds stronger than the raising of the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:327
verses.text: They beheld me bound, and they are the more courageous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:328
verses.text: For where bonds are, there of necessity is something great also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:329
verses.text: Where affliction is, there verily is salvation also, there verily is solace, there verily are great achievements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:330
verses.text: For when the devil kicks, then is he, doubtless, hit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:331
verses.text: When he binds God's servants, then most of all does the word gain ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:332
verses.text: And mark how this is every where the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:333
verses.text: Paul was imprisoned; and in the prison he did these things, yea, saith he, by my very bonds themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:334
verses.text: He was imprisoned at Rome, and brought the more converts to the faith; for not only was he himself emboldened, but many others also because of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:335
verses.text: He was imprisoned at Jerusalem, and preaching in his bonds he struck the king with amazement, (Acts xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:336
verses.text: ) and made the governor tremble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:337
verses.text: (Acts xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:338
verses.text: ) For being afraid, it is related, he let him go, and he that had bound him was not ashamed to receive instruction concerning the things to come at the hands of him whom he had bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:339
verses.text: In bonds he sailed, and retrieved the wreck, and bound fast the tempest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:340
verses.text: It was when he was in bonds that the monster fastened on him, and fell off from his hand, having done him no hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:341
verses.text: He was bound at Rome, and preaching in bonds drew thousands to his cause, holding forward, in the place of every other, this very argument, I mean his chain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:342
verses.text: It is not however our lot to be bound now-a-days.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:343
verses.text: And yet there is another chain if we have a mind to wear it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:344
verses.text: And what is it? It is to restrain our hand, to be not so forward to covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:345
verses.text: With this chain let us bind ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:346
verses.text: Let the fear of God be unto us instead of a bond of iron.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:347
verses.text: Let us loose them that are bound by poverty, by affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:348
verses.text: There is no comparison between opening the doors of a prison, and releasing an enthralled soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:349
verses.text: There is no comparison between loosing the bonds of prisoners and "setting at liberty them that are bruised;" (Luke iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:350
verses.text: ) this last is far greater than the other; for the other there is no reward in store, for this last there are ten thousand rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:351
verses.text: Paul's chain has proved a long one, and has detained us a length of time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:352
verses.text: Yea, long indeed it is, and more beautiful than any cord of gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:353
verses.text: A chain this, which draws them that are bound by it, as it were by a kind of invisible machinery, to Heaven, and, like a golden cord let down, draws them up to the Heaven of heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:354
verses.text: And the wonderful thing is this, that, bound, as it is, below, it draws its captives upwards: and indeed this is not the nature of the things themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:355
verses.text: But where God orders and disposes, look not for the nature of things, nor for natural sentence, but for things above nature and natural sequence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:356
verses.text: Let us learn not to sink under affliction, nor to repine; for look at this blessed saint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:357
verses.text: He had been scourged, and sorely scourged, for it is said, "When they had laid many stripes upon them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:358
verses.text: He had been bound too, and that again sorely, for the jailor cast him into the inner ward, and with extraordinary security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:359
verses.text: And though he was in so many perils, at midnight, when even the most wakeful are asleep with sleep, another and a stronger bond upon them, they chanted and sang praise unto the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:360
verses.text: What can be more adamantine than these souls? They bethought them how that the holy Children sang even in fire and furnace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:361
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:362
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:364
verses.text: ) Perhaps they thus reasoned with themselves, "we have as yet suffered nothing like that".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:365
verses.text: But our discourse has done well, in that it has thus brought us out again to other bonds, and into another prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:366
verses.text: What am I to do? I would fain be silent, but am not able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:367
verses.text: I have discovered another prison, far more wonderful and more astonishing than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:368
verses.text: But, come now, rouse yourselves, as though I were just commencing my discourse, and attend to me with your minds fresh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:369
verses.text: I would fain break off the discourse, but it will not suffer me; for just as a man in the midst of drinking cannot bear to break off his draught, whatever any one may promise him; so I too, now I have laid hold of this glorious cup of the prison of them that were bound for Christ's sake, I cannot leave off, I cannot hold my peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:370
verses.text: For if Paul in the prison, and in the night, kept not silence, no, nor under the scourge; shall I, who am sitting here by daylight, and speaking so much at my ease, shall I hold my peace, when men in bonds, and under the scourge, and at midnight could not endure to do so? The holy Children were not silent, no, not in the furnace and in the fire, and are not we ashamed to hold our peace? Let us look then at this prison also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:371
verses.text: Here too, they were bound, but at once and from the very outset it was evident that they were not about to be burned, but only to enter as into a prison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:372
verses.text: For why do ye bind men who are about to be committed to the flames? They were bound, as Paul was, hand and foot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:373
verses.text: They were bound with as great violence as he was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:374
verses.text: For the jailor thrust him into the inner prison; and the king commanded the furnace to be intensely heated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:375
verses.text: And now let us see the issue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:376
verses.text: When Paul and Silas sang, the prison was shaken, and the doors were opened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:377
verses.text: When the three Children sang, the bonds both of their feet and hands were loosed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:378
verses.text: The prison was opened, and the doors of the furnace were opened: for a dewy breeze whistled through it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:379
verses.text: But many thoughts crowd around me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:380
verses.text: I know not which to utter first, and which second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:381
verses.text: Wherefore, let no one, I entreat, require order of me, for the subjects are closely allied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:382
verses.text: They who were bound together with Paul and Silas were loosed, and yet nevertheless they slept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:383
verses.text: In the case of the three Children, instead of that, something else took place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:384
verses.text: The men who had cast them in, were themselves burned to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 9:385
