verses.text: When thou hearest these words, think not of a mere removal from one place to another; for what Paul establishes in the Epistle to the Philippians (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:56
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:58
verses.text: ), that very argument is he also insisting upon here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:59
verses.text: In the same way as there, when exhorting them concerning lowliness, he brings forward Christ as an example, so does he here also, saying, "He descended into the lower parts of the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:60
verses.text: For were not this so, this expression which he uses, "He became obedient even unto death" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:61
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:63
verses.text: ), were superfluous; whereas from His ascending, he implies His descent, and by "the lower parts of the earth," he means "death," according to the notions of men; as Jacob also said, "Then shall ye bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:64
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:65
verses.text: xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:66
verses.text: ) And again as it is in the Psalm, "Lest I become like them that go down into the pit" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:67
verses.text: cxliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:68
verses.text: ), that is like the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:69
verses.text: Why does he descant upon this region here? And of what captivity does he speak? Of that of the devil; for He took the tyrant captive, the devil, I mean, and death, and the curse, and sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:70
verses.text: Behold His spoils and His trophies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:71
verses.text: "Now this, He ascended, what is it but that He also descended?"  This strikes at Paul of Samosata and his school.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:72
verses.text: "He that descended, is the same also that ascended far above all the Heavens, that He might fill all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:73
verses.text: He descended, saith he, into the lower parts of the earth, beyond which there are none other: and He ascended up far above all things, to that place, beyond which there is none other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:74
verses.text: This is to show His divine energy, and supreme dominion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:75
verses.text: For indeed even of old had all things been filled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:78
verses.text: "And He gave some to be apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers; for the perfecting of the saints, unto the work of ministering, unto the building up of the body of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:79
verses.text: What he said elsewhere, "Wherefore also God hath highly exalted Him" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:80
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:81
verses.text: ), that saith he also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:82
verses.text: "He that descended, is the same also that ascended".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:83
verses.text: It did Him no injury that He came down into the lower parts of the earth, nor was it any hindrance to His becoming far higher than the Heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:84
verses.text: So that the more a man is humbled, so much the more is he exalted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:85
verses.text: For as in the case of water, the more a man presses it downwards, the more he forces it up; and the further a man retires to hurl a javelin, the surer his aim; so is it also with humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:86
verses.text: However, when we speak of ascents with reference to God, we must needs conceive a descent first; but when with reference to man, not at all so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:87
verses.text: Then he goes on to show further His providential care, and His wisdom, for He who hath wrought such things as these, who had such might, and who refused not to go down even to those lower parts for our sakes, never would He have made these distributions of spiritual gifts without a purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:88
verses.text: Now elsewhere he tells us that this was the work of the Spirit, in the words, "In the which the Holy Ghost hath made you bishops to feed the Church of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:89
verses.text: And here he saith that it is the Son; and elsewhere that it is God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:90
verses.text: "And He gave to the Church some apostles, and some prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:91
verses.text: But in the Epistle to the Corinthians, he saith, "I planted, Apollos watered; but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:92
verses.text: And again, "Now he that planteth and he that watereth are one: but each shall receive his own reward according to his own labor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:93
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:94
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:96
verses.text: ) So is it also here; for what if thou bring in but little? Thou hast received so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:97
verses.text: First, he says, "apostles"; for these had all gifts; secondarily, "prophets," for there were some who were not indeed apostles, but prophets, as Agabus; thirdly, "evangelists," who did not go about everywhere, but only preached the Gospel, as Priscilla and Aquila; "pastors and teachers," those who were entrusted with the charge of a whole nation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:98
verses.text: What then? are the pastors and the teachers inferior? Yes, surely; those who were settled and employed about one spot, as Timothy and Titus, were inferior to those who went about the world and preached the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:99
verses.text: However, it is not possible from this passage to frame the subordination and precedence, but from another Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:100
verses.text: "He gave," saith he; thou must not say a word to gainsay it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:101
verses.text: Or perhaps by "evangelists" he means those who wrote the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:102
verses.text: "For the perfecting of the saints unto the work of ministering, unto the building up of the body of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:103
verses.text: Perceive ye the dignity of the office? Each one edifies, each one perfects, each one ministers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:104
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:105
verses.text: "Till we all attain," he proceeds, "unto the unity of the faith and of the knowledge of the Son of God, unto a full-grown man, unto the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:106
verses.text: By "stature" here he means perfect "knowledge"; for as a man will stand firmly, whereas children are carried about and waver in mind, so is it also with believers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:107
verses.text: "To the unity," saith he, "of the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:108
verses.text: That is, until we shall be shown to have all one faith: for this is unity of faith, when we all are one, when we shall all alike acknowledge the common bond.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:109
verses.text: Till then thou must labor to this end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:110
verses.text: If for this thou hast received a gift, that thou mightest edify others, look well that thou overturn not thyself, by envying another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:111
verses.text: God hath honored thee, and ordained thee, that thou shouldest build up another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:112
verses.text: Yea, for about this was the Apostle also engaged; and for this was the prophet prophesying and persuading, and the Evangelist preaching the Gospel, and for this was the pastor and teacher; all had undertaken one common work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:113
verses.text: For tell me not of the difference of the spiritual gifts; but that all had one work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:114
verses.text: Now when we shall all believe alike then shall there be unity; for that this is what he calls "a perfect man," is plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:115
verses.text: And yet he elsewhere calls us "babes" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:116
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:117
verses.text: ), even when we are of mature age; but he is there looking to another comparison, for there it is in comparison with our future knowledge that he there calls us babes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:118
verses.text: For having said, "We know in part" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:119
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:121
verses.text: ), he adds also the word "darkly," and the like: whereas here he speaks with reference to another thing, with reference to changeableness, as he saith also elsewhere, "But solid food is for full-grown men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:122
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:123
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:124
verses.text: ) Do you see then also in what sense he there calls them full-grown? Observe also in what sense he calls men "perfect" here, by the words next added, where he says, "that we may be no longer children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:125
verses.text: That we keep, he means to say, that little measure, which we may have received, with all diligence, with firmness and steadfastness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:126
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:127
verses.text: "That we may be no longer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:128
verses.text: —The word, "no longer," shows that they had of old been in this case, and he reckons himself moreover as a subject for correction, and corrects himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:129
verses.text: For this cause, he would say, are there so many workmen, that the building may not be shaken, may not be "carried about," that the stones may be firmly fixed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:130
verses.text: For this is the character of children, to be tossed to and fro, to be carried about and shaken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:131
verses.text: "That we may be no longer," saith he, "children, tossed to and fro, and carried about with every wind of doctrine, by the sleight of men, in craftiness, after the wiles of error".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:132
verses.text: "And carried about," saith he, "with every wind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:133
verses.text: He comes to this figure of speech, to point out in how great peril doubting souls are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:134
verses.text: "With every wind," saith he, "by the sleight of men, in craftiness, after the wiles of error".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:135
verses.text: The word "sleight" means the art of gamesters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:136
verses.text: Such are the "crafty," whenever they lay hold on the simpler sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:137
verses.text: For they also change and shift about everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:138
verses.text: He here glances also at human life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:139
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:141
verses.text: "But speaking truth," saith he, "in love, may grow up in all things into Him, which is the Head, even Christ, from whom," (that is, from Christ,) "all the body fitly framed and knit together, through that which every joint supplieth, according to the working in due measure of each several part, maketh increase of the body unto the building up of itself in love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:142
verses.text: He expresses himself with great obscurity, from his desire to utter everything at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:143
verses.text: What he means, however, is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:144
verses.text: In the same way as the spirit, or vital principle, which descends from the brain, communicates the sensitive faculty which is conveyed through the nerves, not simply to all the members, but according to the proportion of each member, to that which is capable of receiving more, more, to that which is capable of less, less, (for the spirit is the root or source;) so also is Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:145
verses.text: For the souls of men being dependent upon Him as members, His provident care, and supply of the spiritual gifts according to a due proportion in the measure of every single member, effects their increase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:146
verses.text: But what is the meaning of this, "by the touch of the supply"? that is to say, by the sensitive faculty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:147
verses.text: For that spirit which is supplied to the members from the head, "touches," each single member, and thus actuates it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:148
verses.text: As though one should say, "the body receiving the supply according to the proportion of its several members, thus maketh the increase"; or, in other words, "the members receiving the supply according to the proportion of their proper measure, thus make increase"; or otherwise again thus, "the spirit flowing plenteously from above, and touching all the members, and supplying them as each is capable of "receiving it, thus maketh increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:149
verses.text: But wherefore doth he add, "in love"? Because in no other way is it possible for that Spirit to descend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:150
verses.text: For as, in case a hand should happen to be torn from the body, the spirit which proceeds from the brain seeks the limb, and if it finds it not, does not leap forth from the body, and fly about and go to the hand, but if it finds it not in its place, does not touch it; so also will it be here, if we be not bound together in love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:151
verses.text: All these expressions he uses as tending to humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:152
verses.text: For what, he seems to say, if this or that man receives more than another? He has received the same Spirit, sent forth from the same Head, effectually working in all alike, communicating itself to all alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:153
verses.text: "Fitly framed and knit together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:154
verses.text: That is, having great care bestowed upon it; for the body must not be put together anyhow, but with exceeding art and nicety, since if it gets out of place, it is no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:155
verses.text: So that each must not only be united to the body, but also occupy his proper place, since if thou shalt go beyond this, thou art not united to it, neither dost thou receive the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:156
verses.text: Dost thou not see, that in those dislocations of the bones which take place in any accident, when a bone gets out of its proper place and occupies that of another, how it injures the whole body, and oftentimes will produce death? So that sometimes it will be found to be no longer worth preserving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:157
verses.text: For many in many cases will cut it off, and leave a void in its place; because everywhere what is in excess is an evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:158
verses.text: And so again with the elements, if they lose their proper proportion and be in excess, they impair the whole system.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:159
verses.text: This is the meaning of the being "fitly framed and knit together".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:160
verses.text: Consider then of how vast importance it is, that each should remain in his own proper place, and not encroach on another which in nowise appertains to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:161
verses.text: Thou puttest the members together, He supplieth them from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:162
verses.text: For as there are in the body such recipient organs, as we have seen, so is it also with the Spirit, the whole root or source being from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:163
verses.text: For example, the heart is the recipient of the breath, the liver of the blood, the spleen of the bile, and the other organs, some of one thing, others of another, but all these have their source from the brain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:164
verses.text: So also hath God done, highly honoring man, and being unwilling to be far from him, He hath made Himself indeed the source of his dependence, and hath constituted them fellow-workers with Himself; and some He hath appointed to one office, and others to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:165
verses.text: For example, the Apostle is the most vital vessel of the whole body, receiving everything from Him; so that He maketh eternal life to run through them to all, as through veins and arteries, I mean through their discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:166
verses.text: The Prophet foretells things to come, whilst He alone ordereth the same; Thou puttest the members together, but He supplies them with life, "For the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:167
verses.text: Love builds up, and makes men cleave one to another, and be fastened and fitted together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:168
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:169
verses.text: If therefore we desire to have the benefit of that Spirit which is from the Head, let us cleave one to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:170
verses.text: For there are two kinds of separation from the body of the Church; the one, when we wax cold in love, the other, when we dare commit things unworthy of our belonging to that body; for in either way we cut ourselves off from the "fullness of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:171
verses.text: But if we are appointed to build up others also, what shall not be done to them who are first to make division? Nothing will so avail to divide the Church as love of power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:172
verses.text: Nothing so provokes God's anger as the division of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:173
verses.text: Yea, though we have achieved ten thousand glorious acts, yet shall we, if we cut to pieces the fullness of the Church, suffer punishment no less sore than they who mangled His body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:174
verses.text: For that indeed was brought to pass for the benefit of the world, even though it was done with no such intention; whereas this produces no advantage in any case, but the injury is excessive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:175
verses.text: These remarks I am addressing not to the governors only, but also to the governed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:176
verses.text: Now a certain holy man said what might seem to be a bold thing; yet, nevertheless, he spoke it out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:177
verses.text: What then is this? He said, that not even the blood of martyrdom can wash out this sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:178
verses.text: For tell me for what dost thou suffer as a martyr? Is it not for the glory of Christ? Thou then that yieldest up thy life for Christ's sake, how dost thou lay waste the Church, for whose sake Christ yielded up His life? Hear what Paul saith, "I am not meet to be called an Apostle ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:179
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:180
verses.text: ), because I persecuted the Church of God and made havoc of it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:181
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:182
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:183
verses.text: ) This injury is not less than that received at the hands of enemies, nay, it is far greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:184
verses.text: For that indeed renders her even more glorious, whereas this, when she is warred upon by her own children, disgraces her even before her enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:185
verses.text: Because it seems to them a great mark of hypocrisy, that those who have been born in her, and nurtured in her bosom, and have learned perfectly her secrets, that these should of a sudden change, and do her enemies' work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:186
verses.text: I mean these remarks for those who give themselves up indiscriminately to the men who are dividing the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:187
verses.text: For if on the one hand those men have doctrines also contrary to ours, then on that account further it is not right to mix with them: if, on the other hand, they hold the same opinions, the reason for not mixing with them is greater still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:188
verses.text: And why so? Because then the disease is from lust of authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:189
verses.text: Know ye not what was the fate of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram? (Num.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:190
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:192
verses.text: ) Of them only did I say? Was it not also of them that were with them? What wilt thou say? Shall it be said, "Their faith is the same, they are orthodox as well as we"? If so, why then are they not with us? There is "one Lord, one faith, one baptism".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:193
verses.text: If their cause is right, then is ours wrong; if ours is right, then is theirs wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:194
verses.text: "Children," saith he, "tossed to and fro, and carried about with every wind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:195
verses.text: Tell me, dost thou think this is enough, to say that they are orthodox? Is then the ordination of clergy past and done away? And what is the advantage of other things, if this be not strictly observed? For as we must needs contend for the faith; so must we for this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:196
verses.text: For if it is lawful for any one, according to the phrase of them of old, "to fill his hands," and to become a priest, let all approach to minister.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:197
verses.text: In vain has this altar been raised, in vain the fullness of the Church, in vain the number of the priests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:198
verses.text: Let us take them away and destroy them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:199
verses.text: "God forbid!" ye will say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:200
verses.text: You are doing these things, and do ye say, "God forbid"? How say ye, "God forbid," when the very things are taking place? I speak and testify, not looking to my own interest, but to your salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:201
verses.text: But if any one be indifferent, he must see to it himself: if these things are a care to no one else, yet are they a care to me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:202
verses.text: "I planted," saith he, "Apollos watered, but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:203
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:204
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:205
verses.text: ) How shall we bear the ridicule of the Greeks? For if they reproach us on account of our heresies, what will they not say of these things? "If they have the same doctrines, if the same mysteries, wherefore does a ruler in one Church invade another? See ye," say they, "how all things amongst the Christians are full of vainglory? And there is an ambition among them, and hypocrisy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:206
verses.text: Strip them," say they, "of their numbers, and they are nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:207
verses.text: Cut out the disease, the corrupt multitude".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:208
verses.text: Would ye have me tell what they say of our city, how they accuse us on the score of our easy compliances? Any one, say they, that chooses may find followers, and would never be at a loss for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:209
verses.text: Oh, what a sneer is that, what a disgrace are these things! And yet the sneer is one thing, the disgrace is another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:210
verses.text: If any amongst us are convicted of deeds the most disgraceful, and are about to meet with some penalty, great is the alarm, great is the fear on all sides, lest he should start away, people say, and join the other side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:211
verses.text: Yea, let such an one start away ten thousand times, and let him join them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:212
verses.text: And I speak not only of those who have sinned, but if there be any one free from offense, and he has a mind to depart, let him depart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:213
verses.text: I am grieved indeed at it, and bewail and lament it, and am cut to the very heart, as though I were being deprived of one of my own limbs; and yet I am not so grieved, as to be compelled to do anything wrong through such fear as this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:214
verses.text: We have "not lordship over your faith" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:215
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:216
verses.text: ), beloved, nor command we these things as your lords and masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:217
verses.text: We are appointed for the teaching of the word, not for power, nor for absolute authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:218
verses.text: We hold the place of counselors to advise you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:219
verses.text: The counselor speaks his own sentiments, not forcing the hearer, but leaving him full master of his choice upon what is said; in this case alone is he blameable, if he fail to utter the things which present themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:220
verses.text: For this cause do we also say these things, these things do we assert, that it may not be in your power in that day to say, "No one told us, no one gave us commandment, we were ignorant, we thought it was no sin at all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:221
verses.text: Therefore I assert and protest, that to make a schism in the Church is no less an evil than to fall into heresy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:222
verses.text: Tell me, suppose a subject of some king, though he did not join himself to another king, nor give himself to any other, yet should take and keep hold of his king's royal purple, and should tear it all from its clasp, and rend it into many shreds; would he suffer less punishment than those who join themselves to the service of another? And what, if withal he were to seize the king himself by the throat and slay him, and tear his body limb from limb, what punishment could he undergo, that should be equal to his deserts? Now if in doing this toward a king, his fellow-servant, he would be committing an act too great for any punishment to reach; of what hell shall not he be worthy who slays Christ, and plucks Him limb from limb? of that one which is threatened? No, I think not, but of another far more dreadful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:223
verses.text: Speak, ye women, that are present,—for this generally is a failing of women,—relate to them that are absent this similitude which I have made; startle them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:224
verses.text: If any think to grieve me and thus to have their revenge, let them be well aware that they do these things in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:225
verses.text: For if thou wishest to revenge thyself on me, I will give thee a method by which thou mayest take vengeance without injury to thyself; or rather without injury it is not possible to revenge thyself, but at all events with less injury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:226
verses.text: Buffet me, woman, spit upon me, when thou meetest me in the public way, and aim blows at me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:227
verses.text: Dost thou shudder at hearing this? When I bid thee buffet me, dost thou shudder, and dost thou tear thy Lord and Master and not shudder? Dost thou pluck asunder the limbs of thy Lord and Master, and not tremble? The Church is our Father's house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:228
verses.text: "There is one body, and one Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:229
verses.text: But dost thou wish to revenge thyself on me? Yet stop at me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:230
verses.text: Why dost thou revenge thyself on Christ in my stead? nay, rather, why kick against the nails? In no case indeed is revenge good and right, but to assault one when another has done the wrong is far worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:231
verses.text: Is it I that wronged you? Why then inflict pain on Him who hath not wronged you? This is the very extreme of madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:232
verses.text: I speak not in irony what I am about to say, nor without purpose, but as I really think and as I feel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:233
verses.text: I would that every one of those who with you are exasperated against me, and who by this exasperation are injuring themselves, and departing elsewhere, would direct his blows at me in my very face, would strip me and scourge me, be his charge against me just or unjust, and let loose his wrath upon me, rather than that they should dare to commit what they now dare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:234
verses.text: If this were done, it were nothing; nothing, that a man who is a mere nothing and of no account whatever, should be so treated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:235
verses.text: And besides, I, the wronged and injured person, might call upon God, and He might forgive you your sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:236
verses.text: Not because I have so great confidence; but because when he who has been wronged, entreats for him who has done the wrong, he gains great confidence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:237
verses.text: "If one man sin against another," it is said, "then shall they pray for him" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:238
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:239
verses.text: ); and if I were unable, I might seek for other holy men, and entreat them, and they might do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:240
verses.text: But now whom shall we even entreat, when God is outraged by us?  Mark the consistency; for of those who belong to this Church, some never approach to communicate at all, or but once in the year, and then without purpose, and just as it may happen; others more regularly indeed, yet they too carelessly and without purpose, and while engaged in conversation, and trifling about nothing: whilst those who, forsooth, seem to be in earnest, these are the very persons who work this mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:241
verses.text: Yet surely, if it is for these things ye are in earnest, it were better that ye also were in the ranks of the indifferent; or rather it were better still, that neither they should be indifferent, nor you such as ye are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:242
verses.text: I speak not of you that are present, but of those who are deserting from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:243
verses.text: The act is adultery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:244
verses.text: And if ye bear not to hear these things of them, neither should ye of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:245
verses.text: There must be breach of the law either on the one side or the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:246
verses.text: If then thou hast these suspicions concerning me, I am ready to retire from my office, and resign it to whomsoever ye may choose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:247
verses.text: Only let the Church be one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:248
verses.text: But if I have been lawfully made and consecrated, entreat those who have contrary to the law mounted the episcopal throne to resign it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:249
verses.text: These things I have said, not as dictating to you, but only to secure and protect you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:250
verses.text: Since every one of you is come to age, and will have to give account of the things which he has done, I entreat you not to cast the whole matter on us, and consider yourselves to be irresponsible, that ye may not go on fruitlessly deceiving yourselves, and at last bewail it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:251
verses.text: An account indeed we shall have to give of your souls; but it will be when we have been wanting on our part, when we fail to exhort, when we fail to admonish, when we fail to protest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:252
verses.text: But after these words, allow even me to say that "I am pure from the blood of all men" (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:253
verses.text: ); and that "God will deliver my soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:254
verses.text: (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:255
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:257
verses.text: ) Say what ye will, give a just cause why ye depart, and I will answer you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:258
verses.text: But no, ye will not state it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 12:259
verses.text: Wherefore I entreat you, endeavor henceforward both to resist nobly and to bring back those who have seceded, that we may with one accord lift up thanksgiving to God; for to Him belongs the glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:3
verses.text: "This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye no longer walk as the Gentiles also walk, in the vanity of their mind, being darkened in their understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:4
verses.text: It is the duty of the teacher to build up and restore the souls of his disciples, not only by counseling and instructing them, but also by alarming them, and delivering them up to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:5
verses.text: For when the words spoken by men as coming from fellow-servants are not sufficient to kindle the soul, it then becomes necessary to make over the case to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:6
verses.text: This accordingly Paul does also; for having discoursed concerning lowliness, and concerning unity, and concerning our duty not to rise up one against another, hear what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:7
verses.text: "This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye no longer walk as the Gentiles also walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:8
verses.text: He does not say, "That ye henceforth walk not as ye are now walking," for that expression would have struck too hard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:9
verses.text: But he plainly indicates the same thing, only he brings his example from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:10
verses.text: And so in writing to the Thessalonians, he does this very same thing, where he says, "Not in the passion of lust, even as the Gentiles which know not God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:11
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:12
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:13
verses.text: ) Ye differ from them, he means to say, in doctrine, but that is wholly God's work: what I require on your path is the life and the course of behavior that is after God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:14
verses.text: This is your own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:15
verses.text: And I call the Lord to witness what I have said, that I have not shrunk, but have told you how ye ought to walk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:16
verses.text: "In the vanity," saith he, "of their mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:17
verses.text: What is vanity of mind? It is the being busied about vain things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:18
verses.text: And what are those vain things, but all things in the present life? Of which the Preacher saith, "Vanity of vanities, all is vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:19
verses.text: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:20
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:21
verses.text: ) But a man will say, If they be vain and vanity, wherefore were they made? If they are God's works, how are they vain? And great is the dispute concerning these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:22
verses.text: But hearken, beloved: it is not the works of God which he calls vain; God forbid! The Heaven is not vain, the earth is not vain,—God forbid!—nor the sun, nor the moon and stars, nor our own body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:23
verses.text: No, all these are "very good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:24
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:25
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:26
verses.text: ) But what is vain? Let us hear the Preacher himself, what he saith; "I planted me vineyards, I gat me men singers and women singers, I made me pools of water, I had great possession of herds and flocks, I gathered me also silver and gold, and I saw that these are vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:27
verses.text: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:28
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:30
verses.text: ) And again, "Vanity of vanities, all things are vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:31
verses.text: (Eccles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:32
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:33
verses.text: ) Hear also what the Prophet saith, "He heapeth up riches, and knoweth not who shall gather them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:34
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:35
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:36
verses.text: ) Such is "vanity of vanities," your splendid buildings, your vast and overflowing riches, the herds of slaves that bustle along the public square, your pomp and vainglory, your high thoughts, and your ostentation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:37
verses.text: For all these are vain; they came not from the hand of God, but are of our own creating.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:38
verses.text: But why then are they vain? Because they have no useful end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:39
verses.text: Riches are vain when they are spent upon luxury; but they cease to be vain when they are "dispersed and given to the needy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:40
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:41
verses.text: cxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:42
verses.text: ) But when thou hast spent them upon luxury, let us look at the end of them, what it is;—grossness of body, flatulence, pantings, fullness of belly, heaviness of head, softness of flesh, feverishness, enervation; for as a man who shall draw into a leaking vessel labors in vain, so also does the one who lives in luxury and self-indulgence draw into a leaking vessel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:43
verses.text: But again, that is called "vain," which is expected indeed to contain something, but contains it not;—that which men call empty, as when they speak of "empty hopes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:44
verses.text: And generally that is called "vain," which is bare and purposeless, which is of no use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:45
verses.text: Let us see then whether all human things are not of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:46
verses.text: "Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:47
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:48
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:49
verses.text: ) What then, tell me, is the end? Corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:50
verses.text: Let us put on clothing and raiment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:51
verses.text: And what is the result? Nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:52
verses.text: Such are the lives of the Greeks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:53
verses.text: They philosophized, but in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:54
verses.text: They made a show of a life of hardship, but of mere hardship, not looking to any beneficial end, but to vainglory, and to honor from the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:55
verses.text: But what is the honor of the many? It is nothing, for if they themselves which render the honor perish, much more does the honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:56
verses.text: He that renders honor to another, ought first to render it to himself; for if he gain not honor for himself, how can he ever render it to another? Whereas now we seek even honors from vile and despicable characters, themselves dishonorable, and objects of reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:57
verses.text: What kind of honor then is this? Perceive ye, how that all things are "vanity of vanities"? Therefore, saith he, "in the vanity of their mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:58
verses.text: But further, is not their religion of this sort, wood and stone? He hath made the sun to shine for a lamp to light us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:59
verses.text: Who will worship his own lamp? The sun supplies us with light, but where he cannot, a lamp can do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:60
verses.text: Then why not worship thy lamp? "Nay," one will say, "I worship the fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:61
verses.text: Oh, how ridiculous! So great is the absurdity, and yet look again at another absurdity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:62
verses.text: Why extinguish the object of thy worship? Why destroy, why annihilate thy god? Wherefore dost thou not suffer thy house to be filled with him? For if the fire be god, let him feed upon thy body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:63
verses.text: Put not thy god under the bottom of thy kettle, or thy cauldron.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:64
verses.text: Bring him into thy inner chambers, bring him within thy silken draperies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:65
verses.text: Whereas not only dost thou not bring him in, but if by any accident he has found entrance, thou drivest him out from every place, thou callest everybody together, and, as though some wild beast had entered, thou weepest and wailest, and callest the presence of thy god an overwhelming calamity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:66
verses.text: I have a God, and I do all I can to enshrine Him in my bosom, and I deem it my true bliss, not when He visits my dwelling, but when I can draw Him even to my heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:67
verses.text: Do thou too draw the fire to thine heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:68
verses.text: This is folly and vanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:69
verses.text: Fire is good for use, not for adoration; good for ministration and for service, to be my slave, not to be my master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:70
verses.text: It was made for me, not I for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:71
verses.text: If thou art a worshiper of fire, why recline upon thy couch thyself, and order thy cook to stand before thy god? Take up the art of cookery thyself, become a baker if thou wilt, or a coppersmith, for nothing can be more honorable than these arts, since these are they that thy god visits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:72
verses.text: Why deem that art a disgrace, where thy god is all in all? Why commit it to thy slaves, and not be ambitious of it thyself? Fire is good, inasmuch as it is the work of a good Creator, but it is not God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:73
verses.text: It is the work of God, it was not called God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:74
verses.text: Seest thou not how ungovernable is its nature;—how when it lays hold on a building it stops nowhere? But if it seizes anything continuous, it destroys all; and, except the hands of workmen or others quench its fury, it knows not friends nor foes, but deals with all alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:75
verses.text: Is this then your god, and are ye not ashamed? Well indeed does he say, "in the vanity of their mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:76
verses.text: But the sun, they say, is God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:77
verses.text: Tell me, how and wherefore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:78
verses.text: Is it that he sheds abundance of light? Yet dost thou not see him overcome by clouds, and in bondage to the necessity of nature, and eclipsed, and hidden by the moon? And yet the cloud is weaker than the sun; but still it often gains the mastery of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:79
verses.text: And this indeed is the work of God's wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:80
verses.text: God must needs be all sufficient: but the sun needs many things; and this is not like a god.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:81
verses.text: For he requires air to shine in, and that, too, thin air; since the air, when it is greatly condensed, suffers not the rays to pass through it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:82
verses.text: He requires also water, and other restraining power, to prevent him from consuming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:83
verses.text: For were it not that fountains, and lakes, and rivers, and seas, formed some moisture by the emission of their vapors, there would be nothing to prevent an universal conflagration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:84
verses.text: Dost thou see then, say ye, that he is a god? What folly, what madness! A god, say ye, because he has power to do harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:85
verses.text: Nay, rather, for this very reason is he no god, because where he does harm he needs nothing; whereas, where he does good, he requires many things besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:86
verses.text: Now to do harm, is foreign to God's nature; to do good, is His property.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:87
verses.text: Where then the reverse is the case, how can he be God? Seest thou not that poisonous drugs injure, and need nothing; but when they are to do good, need many things? For thy sake then is he such as he is, both good, and powerless; good, that thou mayest acknowledge his Lord; and powerless, that thou mayest not say that he is lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:88
verses.text: "But," say they, "he nourishes the plants and the seeds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:89
verses.text: What then, at that rate is not the very dung a god? for even that also nourishes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:90
verses.text: And why not at that rate the scythe as well, and the hands of the husbandman? Prove to me that the sun alone does the work of nourishing without needing the help of either earth, or water, or tillage; but let the seeds be sown, and let him shed forth his rays, and produce the ears of corn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:91
verses.text: But now if this work be not his alone, but that of the rains also, wherefore is not the water a god also? But of this I speak not yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:92
verses.text: Why is not the earth too a god, and why not the dung, and the hoe? Shall we then, tell me, worship all? Alas, what trifling! And indeed rather might the ear of corn be produced without sun, than without earth and water; and so with plants and all other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:93
verses.text: Were there no earth, none of these things could ever appear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:94
verses.text: And if any one, as children and women do, were to put some earth into a pot, and to fill up the pot with a quantity of dung, and to place it under the roof, plants, though they may be weak ones, will be produced from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:95
verses.text: So that the contribution of the earth and of the dung is greater, and these therefore we ought to worship rather than the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:96
verses.text: He requires the sky, he requires the air, he requires these waters, to prevent his doing harm, to be as bridles to curb the fierceness of his power, and to restrain him from letting loose his rays over the world, like some furious horse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:97
verses.text: And now tell me, where is he at night? Whither has your god taken his departure? For this is not like a god, to be circumscribed and limited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:98
verses.text: This is in fact the property of bodies only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:99
verses.text: But, say they, there is some sort of power residing in him, and he has motion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:100
verses.text: Is this power then, I pray you, itself God? Why then is it insufficient in itself, and why does it not restrain the fire? For again, I come to the same argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:101
verses.text: But what is that power? Is it productive of light, or does it by the sun give light, though of itself possessing none of these qualities? If so, then is the sun superior to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:102
verses.text: How far shall we unwind this maze?  Again, what is water? is not that too, they say, a god? This again is a matter of truly absurd disputation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:103
verses.text: Is that not a god, they say, which we make use of for so many purposes? And so again, in like manner, of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:104
verses.text: Truly "they walk in the vanity of their mind, being darkened in their understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:105
verses.text: But these words he is now using concerning life and conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:106
verses.text: The Greeks are fornicators and adulterers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:107
verses.text: Of course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:108
verses.text: They who paint to themselves such gods as these, will naturally do all these things; and if they can but escape the eyes of men, there is no one to restrain them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:109
verses.text: For what will avail the argument of a resurrection, if it appear to them a mere fable? Yea, and what that of the torments of hell?—they too are but a fable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:110
verses.text: And mark the Satanic notion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:111
verses.text: When they are told of gods who are fornicators, they deny that these are fables, but believe them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:112
verses.text: Yet whenever any shall discourse to them of punishment, "these," they say, "are poets, men who turn everything into fable, that man's happy condition may be on all sides overturned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:113
verses.text: But the philosophers, it is said, discovered something truly grand, and far better than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:114
verses.text: How? They who introduced fate, and who tell us that nothing is providential, and that there is no one to care for anything, but that all things consist of atoms? Or, others again who say that God is a body? Or who, tell me, are they? Are they those who would turn the souls of men into the souls of dogs, and would pervade mankind that one was once a dog, and a lion, and a fish? How long will ye go on and never cease trifling, "being darkened in the understanding"? for they say and do all things as though they were indeed in the dark, both in those things which concern doctrine, and those which concern life and conduct; for the man who is in darkness sees none of the things which lie before him, but oftentimes when he sees a rope, he will take it for a live serpent; or again, if he is caught by a hedge, he will think that a man or an evil spirit has hold of him, and great is the alarm, and great the perturbation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:115
verses.text: Such as these are the things they fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:116
verses.text: "There were they in great fear," it saith, "where no fear was" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:117
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:118
verses.text: ); but the things which they ought to fear, these they fear not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:119
verses.text: But just as children in their nurses' arms thrust their hands incautiously into the fire, and boldly into the candle also, and yet are scared at a man clothed in sackcloth; just so these Greeks, as if they were really always children, (as some one also amongst themselves has said, the Greeks are always children,) fear those things that are no sins, such as filthiness of the body, the pollution of a funeral, a bed, or the keeping of days, and the like: whereas those which are really sins, unnatural lust, adultery, fornication, of these they make no account at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:120
verses.text: No, you may see a man washing himself from the pollution of a dead body, but from dead works, never; and, again, spending much zeal in the pursuit of riches, and yet supposing the whole is undone by the crowing of a single cock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:121
verses.text: "So darkened are they in their understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:122
verses.text: Their soul is filled with all sorts of terrors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:123
verses.text: For instance: "Such a person," one will say, "was the first who met me, as I was going out of the house"; of course ten thousand evils must certainly ensue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:124
verses.text: At another time, "the wretch of a servant in giving me my shoes, held out the left shoe first,"—terrible mishaps and mischiefs! "I myself in coming out set forth with the left foot foremost"; and this too is a token of misfortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:125
verses.text: And these are the evils that occur about the house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:126
verses.text: Then, as I go out, my right eye shoots up from beneath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:127
verses.text: This is a sure sign of tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:128
verses.text: Again the women, when the reeds strike against the standards, and ring, or when they themselves are scratched by the shuttle, turn this also into a sign.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:129
verses.text: And again, when they strike the web with the shuttle, and do it with some vehemence, and then the reeds on the top from the intensity of the blow strike against the standards and ring, this again they make a sign, and ten thousand things besides, deserving of ridicule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:130
verses.text: And so if an ass should bray, or a cock should crow, or a man should sneeze, or whatever else may happen, like men bound with ten thousand chains, or, as I was saying, like men confined in the dark, they suspect everything, and are more slavish than all the slaves in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:131
verses.text: But let it not be so with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:132
verses.text: But scorning all these things, as men living in the light, and having our citizenship in Heaven, and having nothing in common with earth, let us regard but one thing as terrible, that is, sin, and offending against God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:133
verses.text: And if there be not this, let us scorn all the rest, and him that brought them in, the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:134
verses.text: For these things let us give thanks to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:135
verses.text: Let us be diligent, not only that we ourselves be never caught by this slavery, but if any of those who are dear to us have been caught, let us break his bonds asunder, let us release him from this most bitter and contemptible captivity, let us make him free and unshackled for his course toward Heaven, let us raise up his flagging wings, and teach him to be wise for life and doctrine's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:136
verses.text: Let us give thanks to God for all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:137
verses.text: Let us beseech Him that He will not declare us unworthy of the gifts offered to us, and let us ourselves withal endeavor to contribute our own part, that we may teach not only by speaking, but by acting also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 13:138
verses.text: For thus shall we be able to attain His unnumbered blessings, of which God grant we may all be counted worthy, in Christ Jesus our Lord with whom, to the Father and the Holy Ghost together, be glory, might, and honor, now, henceforth, and for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:3
verses.text: –  "This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye no longer walk as the Gentiles also walk, in the vanity of their mind, being darkened in their understanding, alienated from the life of God, because of the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardening of their heart: who being past feeling, gave themselves up to lasciviousness, to work all uncleanness with greediness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:4
verses.text: These words are not addressed to the Ephesians only, but are now addressed also to you; and that, not from me, but from Paul; or rather, neither from me nor from Paul, but from the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:5
verses.text: And we then ought so to feel, as though that grace itself were uttering them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:6
verses.text: And now hear what it saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:7
verses.text: "This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye no longer walk as the Gentiles also walk, in the vanity of their mind, being darkened in their understanding, alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardening of their heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:8
verses.text: If then it is ignorance, if it is hardening, why blame it? if a man is ignorant, it were just, not that he should be ill-treated for it, nor be blamed, but that he should be informed of those things of which he is ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:9
verses.text: But mark how at once he cuts them off from all excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:10
verses.text: "Who being past feeling," saith he, "gave themselves up to lasciviousness, to work all uncleanness with greediness; but ye did not so learn Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:11
verses.text: Here he shows us, that the cause of their hardening was their way of life, and that their life was the consequence of their own indolence and want of feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:12
verses.text: "Who being past feeling," saith he, "gave themselves up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:13
verses.text: Whenever then ye hear, that "God gave them up unto a reprobate mind" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:14
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:15
verses.text: ), remember this expression, that "they gave themselves up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:16
verses.text: If then they gave themselves over, how did God give them over? and if again God gave them over, how did they give themselves over? Thou seest the seeming contradiction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:17
verses.text: The word, "gave them over," then, means this, He permitted them to be given over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:18
verses.text: Seest thou, that the impure life is the ground for like doctrines also? "Every one," saith the Lord, "that doeth ill hateth the light, and cometh not to the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:19
verses.text: (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:20
verses.text: ) For how could a profligate man, one more immersed in the practice of indiscriminate lewdness than the swine that wallow in the mire, and who is a lover of money, and has not so much as any desire after temperance, enter upon a life like this? They made the thing, saith he, their "work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:21
verses.text: Hence their "hardening" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:22
verses.text: ), hence the "darkness of their understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:23
verses.text: There is such a thing as being in the dark, even while the light is shining, when the eyes are weak; and weak they become, either by the influx of ill humors, or by superabundance of rheum.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:24
verses.text: And so surely is it also here; when the strong current of the affairs of this life overwhelms the perceptive power of the understanding, it is thrown into a state of darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:25
verses.text: And in the same way as if we were placed in the depths under water, we should be unable to see the sun through the quantity of water lying, like a sort of barrier, above us, so surely, in the eyes of the understanding also a blindness of the heart takes place, that is, an insensibility, whenever there is no fear to agitate the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:26
verses.text: "There is no fear of God," it saith, "before his eyes" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:27
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:28
verses.text: ); and again, "The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:29
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:30
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:31
verses.text: ) Now blindness arises from no other cause than from want of feeling; this clogs the channel; for whenever the fluids are curdled and collected into one place, the limb becomes dead and void of feeling; and though thou burn it, or cut it, or do what thou wilt with it, still it feels not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:32
verses.text: So is it also with those persons, when they have once given themselves over to lasciviousness: though thou apply the word to them like fire, or steel, yet nothing touches, nothing reaches them; their limb is utterly dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:33
verses.text: And unless thou canst remove the insensibility, so as to touch the healthy members, everything thou doest is vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:34
verses.text: "With greediness," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:35
verses.text: Here he has most completely taken away their excuse; for it was in their power, if at least they chose it, not to be "greedy," nor to be "lascivious," nor gluttonous, and yet to enjoy their desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:36
verses.text: It was in their power to partake in moderation of riches, and even of pleasure and of luxury; but when they indulged the thing immoderately, they destroyed all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:37
verses.text: "To work all uncleanness," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:38
verses.text: Ye see how he strips them of all excuse by speaking of "working uncleanness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:39
verses.text: They did not sin, he means, by making a false step, but they worked out these horrid deeds, and they made the thing a matter of study.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:40
verses.text: "All uncleanness"; uncleanness is all adultery, fornication, unnatural lust, envy, every kind of profligacy and lasciviousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:41
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:43
verses.text: "But ye did not so learn Christ," he continues, "if so be that ye heard Him, and were taught in Him even as truth is in Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:44
verses.text: The expression, "If so be that ye heard Him," is not that of one doubting, but of one even strongly affirming: as he also speaks elsewhere, "If so be that it is a righteous thing with God to recompense affliction to them that afflict you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:45
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:46
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:47
verses.text: ) That is to say, It was not for these purposes that "ye learned Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:48
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:49
verses.text: "That ye put away as concerning your former manner of life, the old man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:50
verses.text: This then surely is to learn Christ, to live rightly; for he that lives wickedly knows not God, neither is known of Him; for hear what he saith elsewhere, "They profess that they know God, but by their works they deny Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:51
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:52
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:53
verses.text: )  "As truth is in Jesus; that ye put away as concerning your former manner of life, the old man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:54
verses.text: That is to say, It was not on these terms that thou enteredst into covenant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:55
verses.text: What is found among us is not vanity, but truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:56
verses.text: As the doctrines are true, so is the life also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:57
verses.text: Sin is vanity and falsehood; but a right life is truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:58
verses.text: For temperance is indeed truth, for it has a great end; whereas profligacy ends in nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:59
verses.text: "Which waxeth corrupt," saith he, "after the lusts of deceit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:60
verses.text: As his lusts became corrupt, so himself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:61
verses.text: How then do his lusts become corrupt? By death all things are dissolved; for hear the Prophet, how he saith, "In that very day his thoughts perish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:62
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:63
verses.text: cxlvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:64
verses.text: ) And not by death only, but by many things besides; for instance, beauty, at the advance of either disease or old age, withdraws and dies away, and suffers corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:65
verses.text: Bodily vigor again is destroyed by the same means; nor does luxury itself afford the same pleasure in old age, as is evident from the case of Barzillai: the history, no doubt, ye know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:66
verses.text: Or again, in another sense, lust corrupts and destroys the old man; for as wool is destroyed by the very same means by which it is produced, so likewise is the old man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:67
verses.text: For love of glory destroys him, and pleasures will often destroy him, and "lust" will utterly "deceive" him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:68
verses.text: For this is not really pleasure but bitterness and deceit, all pretense and outward show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:69
verses.text: The surface, indeed, of the things is bright, but the things themselves are only full of misery and extreme wretchedness, and loathsomeness, and utter poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:70
verses.text: Take off the mask, and lay bare the true face, and thou shalt see the cheat, for cheat it is, when that which is, appears not, and that which is not, is displayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:71
verses.text: And it is thus that impositions are effected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:72
verses.text: The Apostle delineates for us four men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:73
verses.text: Of these I shall give an explanation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:74
verses.text: In this place he mentions two, speaking thus, "Putting away the old man, be ye renewed in the spirit of your mind, and put on the new man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:75
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Romans, two more, as where he saith, "But I see a different law in my members warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity under the law of sin which is in my members".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:76
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:77
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:78
verses.text: ) And these latter bear affinity to those former two, the "new man" to the "inner man," and the "old man" to the "outer man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:79
verses.text: However, three of these four were subject to corruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:80
verses.text: Or rather there are three, the new man, the old, and this, man in his substance and nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:81
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:82
verses.text: "And that ye be renewed," saith he, "in the spirit of your mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:83
verses.text: In order that no one may suppose that, whereas he speaks of old and new, he is introducing a different person, observe his expression, "That ye be renewed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:84
verses.text: To be renewed is, when the selfsame thing which has grown old is renewed, changed from one thing into the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:85
verses.text: So that the subject indeed is the same, but the change is in that which is accidental.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:86
verses.text: Just as the body indeed is the same, and the change in that which is accidental, so is it here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:87
verses.text: How then is the renewal to take place? "In the spirit of your mind," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:88
verses.text: Whosoever therefore has the Spirit, will perform no old deed, for the Spirit will not endure old deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:89
verses.text: "In the spirit," saith he, "of your mind," that is, in the spirit which is in your mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:90
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:91
verses.text: "And put on the new man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:92
verses.text: Seest thou that the subject is one, but the clothing is twofold, that which is put off, and that which is put on? "The new man," he continues, "which after God hath been created in righteousness and holiness of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:93
verses.text: Now wherefore does he call virtue a man? And wherefore vice, a man? Because a man cannot be shown without acting; so that these things, no less than nature, show a man, whether he be good or evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:94
verses.text: Now as to undress one's self and to dress one's self is easy, so may we see it is with virtue and vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:95
verses.text: The young man is strong; wherefore let us also become strong for the performance of good actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:96
verses.text: The young man has no wrinkle, therefore neither should we have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:97
verses.text: The young man wavers not, nor is he easily taken with diseases, therefore neither should we be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:98
verses.text: Observe here how he calls this realizing of virtue, this bringing of it into being from nothing, a "creation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:99
verses.text: But what? was not that other former creation after God? No, in no-wise, but after the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:100
verses.text: He is the sole creator of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:101
verses.text: How is this? For man is created henceforth, not of water, nor of earth, but "in righteousness and holiness of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:102
verses.text: What is this? He straightway created him, he means, to be a son: for this takes place from Baptism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:103
verses.text: This it is which is the reality, "in righteousness and holiness of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:104
verses.text: There was of old a righteousness, there was likewise a holiness with the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:105
verses.text: Yet was that righteousness not in truth, but in figure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:106
verses.text: For the being clean in body was a type of purity, not the truth of purity; was a type of righteousness, not the truth of righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:107
verses.text: "In righteousness," saith he, "and holiness," which are "of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:108
verses.text: And this expression is used with reference to falsehood; for many there are, who to them that are without, seem to be righteous, yet are false.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:109
verses.text: Now by righteousness is meant universal virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:110
verses.text: For hearken to Christ, how He saith, "Except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in nowise enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:111
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:112
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:113
verses.text: ) And again, he is called righteous, who has no charge against him; for so even in courts of justice we say that that man is righteous, who has been unrighteously treated, and has not done unrighteously in return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:114
verses.text: If therefore we also before the terrible Tribunal shall be able to appear righteous one towards another, we may meet with some lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:115
verses.text: Toward God indeed it is impossible we should appear so, whatever we may have to show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:116
verses.text: For everywhere He overcometh in what is righteous, as the Prophet also saith, "That Thou mightest prevail when Thou comest into judgment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:117
verses.text: But if we violate not what is righteous towards each other, then shall we be righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:118
verses.text: If we shall be able to show that we have been treated unrighteously, then shall we be righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:119
verses.text: How does he say to them who are already clothed, "put on"? He is now speaking of that clothing which is from life and good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:120
verses.text: Before, the clothing was from Baptism, whereas now it is from the daily life and from works; no longer "after the lusts of deceit," but "after God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:121
verses.text: But what means the word "holy"? It is that which is pure, that which is due; hence also we use the word of the last duty in the case of the departed, as much as to say, "I owe them nothing further, I have nothing else to answer for".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:122
verses.text: Thus it is usual for us to say, "I have acquitted myself of all obligations," and the like, meaning, "I owe nothing more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:123
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:124
