verses.text: Our part then is, never to put off the garment of righteousness, which also the Prophet calls, "the garment of salvation" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:125
verses.text: lxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:126
verses.text: ), that so we may be made like unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:127
verses.text: For He indeed hath put on righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:128
verses.text: This garment let us put on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:129
verses.text: Now the word, "put on," plainly declares nothing else, than that we should never at all put it off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:130
verses.text: For hear the Prophet, where he saith, "He clothed himself also with cursing as with his garment, and it came into his inward parts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:131
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:132
verses.text: cix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:133
verses.text: ) And again, "Who coverest Thyself with light as with a garment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:134
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:135
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:136
verses.text: ) And again, it is usual with us to speak concerning men, such an one has "put on" such an one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:137
verses.text: So then it is not for one day, nor for two, nor for three, but he would have us ever arrayed in virtue, and never stripped of this garment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:138
verses.text: For a man is not so disfigured when he is stripped of his clothing, as when he is stripped of his virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:139
verses.text: In the former case his fellow-servants behold his nakedness, in the latter his Lord and the Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:140
verses.text: If ever thou happen to see any one going out naked through the public square, tell me, art thou not distressed? When then thou goest about stripped of this garment, what shall we say? Seest not those beggars whom we are wont to call strollers, how they roam about, how we pity even them? And yet nevertheless they are without excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:141
verses.text: We do not excuse them when they have lost their clothes by gaming; and how then, if we lose this garment, shall God pardon us? For whenever the devil sees a man stripped of his virtue, he straightway disguises and disfigures his face, and wounds him, and drives him to great straits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:142
verses.text: Let us strip ourselves of our riches, that we be not stripped of righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:143
verses.text: The garb of wealth mars this garment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:144
verses.text: It is a robe of thorns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:145
verses.text: Thorns are of this nature; and the more closely they are wrapped around us, the more naked are we made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:146
verses.text: Lasciviousness strips us of this garment; for it is a fire, and the fire will consume this garment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:147
verses.text: Wealth is a moth; and as the moth eats through all things alike, and spares not even silken garments, so does this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:148
verses.text: All these therefore let us put off, that we may become righteous, that we may "put on the new man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:149
verses.text: Let us keep nothing old, nothing outward, nothing that is "corrupt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:150
verses.text: Virtue is not toilsome, she is not difficult to attain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:151
verses.text: Dost thou not see them that are in the mountains? They forsake both houses, and wives, and children, and all preëminence, and shut themselves away from the world, and clothe themselves in sackcloth, and strew ashes beneath them; they wear collars hung about their necks, and have pent themselves up in a narrow cell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:152
verses.text: Nor do they stop here, but torture themselves with fastings and continual hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:153
verses.text: Did I now enjoin you to do the like, would ye not all start away? Would ye not say, it is intolerable? But no, I say not that we must needs do anything like this:—I would fain indeed that it were so, still I lay down no law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:154
verses.text: What then? Enjoy thy baths, take care of thy body, and throw thyself freely into the world, and keep a household, have thy servants to wait on thee, and make free use of thy meats and drinks! But everywhere drive out excess, for that it is which causes sin, and the same thing, whatever it be, if it becomes excessive, becomes a sin; so that excess is nothing else than sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:155
verses.text: For observe, when anger is excited above what is meet, then it rushes out into insult, then it commits every sort of injury; so does inordinate passion for beauty, for riches, for glory, or for anything else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:156
verses.text: And tell me not, that indeed, those of whom I spoke were strong; for many far weaker and richer, and more luxurious than thou art, have taken upon them that austere and rugged life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:157
verses.text: And why speak I of men? Damsels not yet twenty years old, who have spent their whole time in inner chambers, and in a delicate and effeminate mode of life, in inner chambers full of sweet ointments and perfumes, reclining on soft couches, themselves soft in their nature, and rendered yet more tender by their over indulgence, who all the day long have had no other business than to adorn themselves, to wear jewels, and to enjoy every luxury, who never waited on themselves, but had numerous handmaids standing beside them, who wore soft raiment softer than their skin, fine linen and delicate, who reveled continually in roses and such like sweet odors,—yea, these very ones, in a moment, seized with Christ's flame, have put off all that indolence and even their very nature, have forgotten their delicateness and youth, and like so many noble wrestlers, have stripped themselves of that soft clothing, and rushed into the midst of the contest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:158
verses.text: And perhaps I shall appear to be telling things incredible, yet nevertheless are they true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:159
verses.text: These then, these very tender damsels, as I myself have heard, have brought themselves to such a degree of severe training, that they will wrap the coarsest horsehair about their own naked bodies, and go with those tender soles unsandaled, and will lie upon a bed of leaves: nay more, that they watch the greater part of the night, and that they take no heed of perfumes nor of any other of their old delights, but will even let their head, once so carefully dressed, go without special care, with the hair just plainly and simply bound up, so as not to fall into unseemliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:160
verses.text: And their only meal is in the evening, a meal not even of herbs nor of bread, but of flour and beans and pulse and olives and figs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:161
verses.text: They spin without intermission, and labor far harder than their handmaids at home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:162
verses.text: What more? they will take upon them to wait upon women who are sick, carrying their beds, and washing their feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:163
verses.text: Nay, many of them even cook.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:164
verses.text: So great is the power of the flame of Christ; so far does their zeal surpass their very nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:165
verses.text: However, I demand nothing like this of you, seeing ye have a mind to be outstripped by women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:166
verses.text: Yet at least, if there be any tasks not too laborious, at least perform these: restrain the rude hand, and the incontinent eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:167
verses.text: What is there, tell me, so hard, what so difficult? Do what is just and right, wrong no man, be ye poor or rich, shopkeepers or hired servants; for unrighteousness may extend even to the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:168
verses.text: Or see ye not how many broils these engage in, and turn all things upside down? Marry freely, and have children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:169
verses.text: Paul also gave charge to such, to such he wrote.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:170
verses.text: Is that struggle I spoke of too great, and the rock too lofty, and its top too nigh unto Heaven, and art thou unable to attain to such an height? At least then lay hold on lesser things, and aim at those which are lower.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:171
verses.text: Hast thou not courage to get rid of thine own riches? At least then forbear to seize on the things of others, and to do them wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:172
verses.text: Art thou unable to fast? At least then give not thyself to self-indulgence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:173
verses.text: Art thou unable to lie upon a bed of leaves? Still, prepare not for yourselves couches inlaid with silver; but use a couch and coverings formed not for display, but for refreshment; not couches of ivory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:174
verses.text: Make thyself small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:175
verses.text: Why fill thy vessel with overwhelming cargoes? If thou be lightly equipped, thou shalt have nothing to fear, no envy, no robbers, no liers in wait.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:176
verses.text: For indeed thou art not so rich in money as thou art in cares.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:177
verses.text: Thou aboundest not so much in possessions, as in anxieties and in perils, "which bring in many temptations and lusts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:178
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:179
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:180
verses.text: ) These things they endure, who desire to gain great possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:181
verses.text: I say not, minister unto the sick; yet, at least, bid thy servant do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:182
verses.text: Seest thou then how that this is no toilsome task? No, for how can it be, when tender damsels surpass us by so great a distance? Let us be ashamed of ourselves, I entreat you; for in worldly matters, to be sure, we in no point yield to them, neither in wars, nor in games; but in the spiritual contest they get the advantage of us, and are the first to seize the prize, and soar higher, like so many eagles: whilst we, like jackdaws, are ever living in the steam and smoke; for truly is it the business of jackdaws, and of greedy dogs, to be setting one's thoughts upon caterers and cooks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:183
verses.text: Hearken about the women of old; they were great characters, great women and admirable; such were Sarah, Rebekah, Rachel, Deborah, and Hannah; and such there were also in the days of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:184
verses.text: Yet did they in no case outstrip the men, but occupied the second rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:185
verses.text: But now it is the very contrary; women outstrip and eclipse us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:186
verses.text: How contemptible! What a shame is this! We hold the place of the head, and are surpassed by the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:187
verses.text: We are ordained to rule over them; not merely that we may rule, but that we may rule in goodness also; for he that ruleth, ought especially to rule in this respect, by excelling in virtue; whereas if he is surpassed, he is no longer ruler.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:188
verses.text: Perceive ye how great is the power of Christ's coming? how He dissolved the curse? For indeed there are more virgins than before among women, there is more modesty in those virgins, and there are more widows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:189
verses.text: No woman would lightly utter so much as an unseemly word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:190
verses.text: Wherefore then, tell me, dost thou use filthy speech? For tell me not that they were virgins in despondency or despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:191
verses.text: The sex is fond of ornament, and it has this failing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:192
verses.text: Yet even in this you husbands surpass them, who pride yourselves even upon them, as your own proper ornament; for I do not think that the wife is so ostentatious of her own jewels, as the husband is of those of his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:193
verses.text: He is not so proud of his own golden girdle, as he is of his wife's wearing jewels of gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:194
verses.text: So that even of this you are the causes, who light the spark and kindle up the flame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:195
verses.text: But what is more, it is not so great a sin in a woman as in a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:196
verses.text: Thou art ordained to regulate her; in every way thou claimest to have the preëminence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:197
verses.text: Show her then in this also, that thou takest no interest in this costliness of hers, by thine own apparel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:198
verses.text: It is more suitable for a woman to adorn herself, than for a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:199
verses.text: If then thou escape not the temptation, how shall she escape it? They have moreover their share of vainglory, but this is common to them with men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:200
verses.text: They are in a measure passionate, and this again is common to them with men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:201
verses.text: But as to those things wherein they excel, these are no longer common to them with men; their sanctity, I mean, their fervency, their devotion, their love towards Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:202
verses.text: Wherefore then, one may say, did Paul exclude them from the teacher's seat? And here again is a proof how great a distance they were from the men, and that the women of those days were great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:203
verses.text: For, tell me, while Paul was teaching, or Peter, or those saints of old, had it been right that a woman should intrude into the office? Whereas we have gone on till we have come so debased, that it is worthy of question, why women are not teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:204
verses.text: So truly have we come to the same weakness as they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:205
verses.text: These things I have said not from any desire to elate them, but to shame ourselves, to chastise, and to admonish us, that so we may resume the authority that belongs to us, not inasmuch as we are greater in size, but because of our foresight, our protection of them, and our virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:206
verses.text: For thus shall the body also be in the order which befits it, when it has the best head to rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 14:207
verses.text: And God grant that all, both wives and husbands, may live according to His good pleasure, that we may all in that terrible day be counted worthy to enjoy the lovingkindness of our Master, and to attain those good things which are promised in Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, and honor, now and forever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:1
verses.text: Homily XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:3
verses.text: –  "Wherefore, putting away falsehood, speak ye truth each one with his neighbor; for we are members one of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:4
verses.text: Be ye angry, and sin not; let not the sun go down upon your wrath: neither give place to the devil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:5
verses.text: Having spoken of the "old man" generally, he next draws him also in detail; for this kind of teaching is more easily learned when we learn by particulars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:6
verses.text: And what saith he? "Wherefore, putting away falsehood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:7
verses.text: What sort of falsehood? Idols does he mean? Surely not; not indeed but that they are falsehood also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:8
verses.text: However, he is not now speaking of them, because these persons had nothing to do with them; but he is speaking of that which passes between one man and another, meaning that which is deceitful and false.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:9
verses.text: "Speak ye truth, each one," saith he, "with his neighbor"; then what is more touching to the conscience still, "because we are members one of another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:10
verses.text: Let no man deceive his neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:11
verses.text: As the Psalmist says here and there; "With flattering lip and with a double heart do they speak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:12
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:13
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:14
verses.text: ) For there is nothing, no, nothing so productive of enmity as deceit and guile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:15
verses.text: Observe how everywhere he shames them by this similitude of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:16
verses.text: Let not the eye, saith he, lie to the foot, nor the foot to the eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:17
verses.text: For example, if there shall be a deep pit, and then by having reeds laid across upon the mouth of it upon the earth, and yet concealed under earth, it shall by its appearance furnish to the eye an expectation of solid ground, will not the eye use the foot, and discover whether it yields and is hollow underneath, or whether it is firm and resists? Will the foot tell a lie, and not report the truth as it is? And what again? If the eye were to spy a serpent or a wild beast, will it lie to the foot? Will it not at once inform it, and the foot thus informed by it refrain from going on? And what again, when neither the foot nor the eye shall know how to distinguish, but all shall depend upon the smelling, as, for example, whether a drug be deadly or not; will the smelling lie to the mouth? And why not? Because it will be destroying itself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:18
verses.text: But it tells the truth as it appears to itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:19
verses.text: And what again? Will the tongue lie to the stomach? Does it not, when a thing is bitter, reject it, and, if it is sweet, pass it on? Observe ministration, and interchange of service; observe a provident care arising from truth, and, as one might say, spontaneously from the heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:20
verses.text: So surely should it be with us also; let us not lie, since we are "members one of another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:21
verses.text: This is a sure token of friendship; whereas the contrary is of enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:22
verses.text: What then, thou wilt ask, if a man shall use treachery against thee? Hearken to the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:23
verses.text: If he use treachery, he is not a member; whereas he saith, "lie not towards the members".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:24
verses.text: "Be ye angry, and sin not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:25
verses.text: Observe his wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:26
verses.text: He both speaks to prevent our sinning, and, if we do not listen, still does not forsake us; for his fatherly compassion does not desert him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:27
verses.text: For just as the physician prescribes to the sick what he must do, and if he does not submit to it, still does not treat him with contempt, but proceeding to add what advice he can by persuasion, again goes on with the cure; so also does Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:28
verses.text: For he indeed who does otherwise, aims only at reputation, and is annoyed at being disregarded; whereas he who on all occasions aims at the recovery of the patient, has this single object in view, how he may restore the patient, and raise him up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:29
verses.text: This then is what Paul is doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:30
verses.text: He has said, "Lie not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:31
verses.text: Yet if ever lying should produce anger, he goes on again to cure this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:32
verses.text: For what saith he? "Be ye angry, and sin not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:33
verses.text: It were good indeed never to be angry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:34
verses.text: Yet if ever any one should fall into passion, still let him not fall into so great a degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:35
verses.text: "For let not the sun," saith he, "go down upon your wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:36
verses.text: Wouldest thou have thy fill of anger? One hour, or two, or three, is enough for thee; let not the sun depart, and leave you both at enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:37
verses.text: It was of God's goodness that he rose: let him not depart, having shone on unworthy men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:38
verses.text: For if the Lord of His great goodness sent him, and hath Himself forgiven thee thy sins, and yet thou forgivest not thy neighbor, look, how great an evil is this! And there is yet another besides this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:39
verses.text: The blessed Paul dreads the night, lest overtaking in solitude him that was wronged, still burning with anger, it should again kindle up the fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:40
verses.text: For as long as there are many things in the daytime to banish it, thou art free to indulge it; but as soon as ever the evening comes on, be reconciled, extinguish the evil whilst it is yet fresh; for should night overtake it, the morrow will not avail to extinguish the further evil which will have been collected in the night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:41
verses.text: Nay, even though thou shouldest cut off the greater portion, and yet not be able to cut off the whole, it will again supply from what is left for the following night, to make the blaze more violent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:42
verses.text: And just as, should the sun be unable by the heat of the day to soften and disperse that part of the air which has been during the night condensed into cloud, it affords material for a tempest, night overtaking the remainder, and feeding it again with fresh vapors: so also is it in the case of anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:43
verses.text: "Neither give place to the devil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:44
verses.text: So then to be at war with one another, is "to give place to the devil"; for, whereas we had need to be all in close array, and to make our stand against him, we have relaxed our enmity against him, and are giving the signal for turning against each other; for never has the devil such place as in our enmities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:45
verses.text: Numberless are the evils thence produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:46
verses.text: And as stones in a building, so long as they are closely fitted together and leave no interstice, will stand firm, while if there is but a single needle's passage through, or a crevice no broader than a hair, this destroys and ruins all; so is it with the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:47
verses.text: So long indeed as we are closely set and compacted together, he cannot introduce one of his wiles; but when he causes us to relax a little, he rushes in like a torrent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:48
verses.text: In every case he needs only a beginning, and this is the thing which it is difficult to accomplish; but this done, he makes room on all sides for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:49
verses.text: For henceforth he opens the ear to slanders, and they who speak lies are the more trusted: they have enmity which plays the advocate, not truth which judges justly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:50
verses.text: And as, where friendship is, even those evils which are true appear false, so where there is enmity, even the false appear true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:51
verses.text: There is a different mind, a different tribunal, which does not hear fairly, but with great bias and partiality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:52
verses.text: As, in a balance, if lead is cast into the scale, it will drag down the whole; so is it also here, only that the weight of enmity is far heavier than any lead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:53
verses.text: Wherefore, let us, I beseech you, do all we can to extinguish our enmities before the going down of the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:54
verses.text: For if you fail to master it on the very first day, both on the following, and oftentimes even for a year, you will be protracting it, and the enmity will thenceforward augment itself, and require nothing to aid it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:55
verses.text: For by causing us to suspect that words spoken in one sense were meant in another, and gestures also, and everything, it infuriates and exasperates us, and makes us more distempered than madmen, not enduring either to utter a name, or to hear it, but saying everything in invective and abuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:56
verses.text: How then are we to allay this passion? How shall we extinguish the flame? By reflecting on our own sins, and how much we have to answer for to God; by reflecting that we are wreaking vengeance, not on an enemy, but on ourselves; by reflecting that we are delighting the devil, that we are strengthening our enemy, our real enemy, and that for him we are doing wrong to our own members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:57
verses.text: Wouldest thou be revengeful and be at enmity? Be at enmity, but be so with the devil, and not with a member of thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:58
verses.text: For this purpose it is that God hath armed us with anger, not that we should thrust the sword against our own bodies, but that we should baptize the whole blade in the devil's breast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:59
verses.text: There bury the sword up to the hilt; yea, if thou wilt, hilt and all, and never draw it out again, but add yet another and another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:60
verses.text: And this actually comes to pass when we are merciful to those of our own spiritual family and peaceably disposed one towards another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:61
verses.text: Perish money, perish glory and reputation; mine own member is dearer to me than they all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:62
verses.text: Thus let us say to ourselves; let us not do violence to our own nature to gain wealth, to obtain glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:63
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:64
verses.text: "Let him that stole," saith he, "steal no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:65
verses.text: Seest thou what are the members of the old man? Falsehood, revenge, theft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:66
verses.text: Why said he not, "Let him that stole" be punished, be tortured, be racked; but, "let him steal no more"? "But rather let him labor, working with his hands the thing that is good, that he may have whereof to give to him that hath need".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:67
verses.text: Where are they which are called pure; they that are full of all defilement, and yet dare to give themselves a name like this? For it is possible, very possible, to put off the reproach, not only by ceasing from the sin, but by working some good thing also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:68
verses.text: Perceive ye how we ought to get quit of the sin? "They stole".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:69
verses.text: This is the sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:70
verses.text: "They steal no more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:71
verses.text: This is not to do away the sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:72
verses.text: But how shall they? If they labor, and charitably communicate to others, thus will they do away the sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:73
verses.text: He does not simply desire that we should work, but so "work" as to "labor," so as that we may "communicate" to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:74
verses.text: For the thief indeed works, but it is that which is evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:76
verses.text: "Let no corrupt speech proceed out of your mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:77
verses.text: What is "corrupt speech"? That which is said elsewhere to be also "idle, backbiting, filthy communication, jesting, foolish talking".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:78
verses.text: See ye how he is cutting up the very roots of anger? Lying, theft, unseasonable conversation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:79
verses.text: The words, however, "Let him steal no more," he does not say so much excusing them, as to pacify the injured parties, and to recommend them to be content, if they never suffer the like again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:80
verses.text: And well too does he give advice concerning conversation; inasmuch as we shall pay the penalty, not for our deeds only, but also for our words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:81
verses.text: "But such as is good," he proceeds, "for edifying, as the need may be, that it may give grace to them that hear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:82
verses.text: That is to say, What edifies thy neighbor, that only speak, not a word more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:83
verses.text: For to this end God gave thee a mouth and a tongue, that thou mightest give thanks to Him, that thou mightest build up thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:84
verses.text: So that if thou destroy that building, better were it to be silent, and never to speak at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:85
verses.text: For indeed the hands of the workmen, if instead of raising the walls, they should learn to pull them down, would justly deserve to be cut off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:86
verses.text: For so also saith the Psalmist; "The Lord shall cut off all flattering lips".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:87
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:88
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:89
verses.text: ) The mouth,—this is the cause of all evil; or rather not the mouth, but they that make an evil use of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:90
verses.text: From thence proceed insults, revilings, blasphemies, incentives to lusts, murders, adulteries, thefts, all have their origin from this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:91
verses.text: And how, you will say, do murders? Because from insult thou wilt go on to anger, from anger to blows, from blows to murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:92
verses.text: And how, again, adultery? "Such a woman," one will say, "loves thee, she said something nice about thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:93
verses.text: This at once unstrings thy firmness, and thus are thy passions kindled within thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:94
verses.text: Therefore Paul said, "such as is good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:95
verses.text: Since then there is so vast a flow of words, he with good reason speaks indefinitely, charging us to use expressions of that kind, and giving us a pattern of communication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:96
verses.text: What then is this? By saying, "for edifying," either he means this, that he who hears thee may be grateful to thee: as, for instance, a brother has committed fornication; do not make a display of the offense, nor revel in it; thou wilt be doing no good to him that hears thee; rather, it is likely, thou wilt hurt him, by giving him a stimulus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:97
verses.text: Whereas, advise him what to do, and thou art conferring on him a great obligation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:98
verses.text: Discipline him how to keep silence, teach him to revile no man, and thou hast taught him his best lesson, thou wilt have conferred upon him the highest obligation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:99
verses.text: Discourse with him on contrition, on piety, on almsgiving; all these things will soften his soul, for all these things he will own his obligation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:100
verses.text: Whereas by exciting his laughter, or by filthy communication, thou wilt rather be inflaming him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:101
verses.text: Applaud the wickedness, and thou wilt overturn and ruin him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:102
verses.text: Or else he means thus, "that it may make them, the hearers, full of grace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:103
verses.text: For as sweet ointment gives grace to them that partake of it, so also does good speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:104
verses.text: Hence it was moreover that one said, "Thy name is as ointment poured forth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:105
verses.text: (Cant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:106
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:107
verses.text: ) It caused them to exhale that sweet perfume.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:108
verses.text: Thou seest that what he continually recommends, he is saying now also, charging every one according to his several ability to edify his neighbors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:109
verses.text: Thou then that givest such advice to others, how much more to thyself!  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:110
verses.text: "And grieve not," he adds, "the Holy Spirit of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:111
verses.text: A matter this more terrible and startling, as he also says in the Epistle to the Thessalonians; for there too he uses an expression of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:112
verses.text: "He that rejecteth, rejecteth not man, but God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:113
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:114
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:115
verses.text: ) So also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:116
verses.text: If thou utter a reproachful word, if thou strike thy brother, thou art not striking him, thou art "grieving the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:117
verses.text: And then is added further the benefit bestowed, in order to heighten the rebuke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:118
verses.text: "And grieve not the Holy Spirit," saith He, "in whom ye were sealed unto the day of redemption".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:119
verses.text: He it is who marks us as a royal flock; He, who separates us from all former things; He, who suffers us not to lie amongst them that are exposed to the wrath of God,—and dost thou grieve Him? Look how startling are his words there; "For he that rejecteth," saith he, "rejecteth not man, but God:" and how cutting they are here, "Grieve not the Holy Spirit," saith he, "in whom ye were sealed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:120
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:121
verses.text: Let this seal then abide upon thy mouth, and never destroy the impression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:122
verses.text: A spiritual mouth never utters a thing of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:123
verses.text: Say not, "It is nothing, if I do utter an unseemly word, if I do insult such an one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:124
verses.text: For this very reason is it a great evil, because it seems to be nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:125
verses.text: For things which seem to be nothing are thus easily thought lightly of; and those which are thought lightly of go on increasing; and those which go on increasing become incurable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:126
verses.text: Thou hast a spiritual mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:127
verses.text: Think what words thou didst utter immediately upon being born,—what words are worthy of thy mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:128
verses.text: Thou callest God, "Father," and dost thou straightway revile thy brother? Think, whence is it thou callest God, "Father"? Is it from nature? No, thou couldest never say so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:129
verses.text: Is it from thy goodness? No, nor is it thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:130
verses.text: But whence then is it? It is from pure lovingkindness, from tenderness, from His great mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:131
verses.text: Whenever then thou callest God, "Father," consider not only this, that by reviling thou art committing things unworthy of that, thy high birth, but also that it is of lovingkindness that thou hast that high birth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:132
verses.text: Disgrace it not then, after receiving it from pure lovingkindness, by showing cruelty towards thy brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:133
verses.text: Dost thou call God "Father," and yet revile? No, these are not the works of the Son of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:134
verses.text: These are very far from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:135
verses.text: The work of the Son of God was to forgive His enemies, to pray for them that crucified Him, to shed His blood for them that hated Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:136
verses.text: These are works worthy of the Son of God, to make His enemies,—the ungrateful, the dishonest, the reckless, the treacherous,—to make these brethren and heirs: not to treat them that are become brethren with ignominy like slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:137
verses.text: Think what words thy mouth uttered,—of what table these words are worthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:138
verses.text: Think what thy mouth touches, what it tastes, of what manner of food it partakes! Dost thou deem thyself to be doing nothing grievous in railing at thy brother? How then dost thou call him brother? And yet if he be not a brother, how sayest thou, "Our Father"? For the word "Our" is indicative of many persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:139
verses.text: Think with whom thou standest at the time of the mysteries! With the Cherubim, with the Seraphim! The Seraphim revile not: no, their mouth fulfills this one only duty, to sing the Hymn of praise, to glorify God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:140
verses.text: And how then shalt thou be able to say with them, "Holy, Holy, Holy," if thou use thy mouth for reviling? Tell me, I pray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:141
verses.text: Suppose there were a royal vessel, and that always full of royal dainties, and set apart for that purpose, and then that any one of the servants were to take and use it for holding dung.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:142
verses.text: Would he ever venture again, after it had been filled with dung, to store it away with those other vessels, set apart for those other uses? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:143
verses.text: Now railing is like this, reviling is like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:144
verses.text: "Our Father!" But what? is this all? Hear also the words, which follow, "which art in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:145
verses.text: The moment thou sayest, "Our Father, which art in Heaven," the word raises thee up, it gives wings to thy mind, it points out to thee that thou hast a Father in Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:146
verses.text: Do then nothing, speak nothing of things upon earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:147
verses.text: He hath set thee amongst that host above, He hath numbered thee with that heavenly choir.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:148
verses.text: Why dost thou drag thyself down? Thou art standing beside the royal throne, and thou revilest? Art thou not afraid lest the king should deem it an outrage? Why, if a servant, even with us, beats his fellow-servant or assaults him, even though he do it justly, yet we at once rebuke him, and deem the act an outrage; and yet dost thou, who art standing with the Cherubim beside the king's throne, revile thy brother? Seest thou not these holy vessels? Are they not used continually for only one purpose? Does any one ever venture to use them for any other? Yet art thou holier than these vessels, yea, far holier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:149
verses.text: Why then defile, why contaminate thyself? Standest thou in Heaven, and dost thou revile? Hast thou thy citizenship with Angels, and dost thou revile? Art thou counted worthy the Lord's kiss, and dost thou revile? Hath God graced thy mouth with so many and great things, with hymns angelic, with food, not angelic, no, but more than angelic, with His own kiss, with His own embrace, and dost thou revile? Oh, no, I implore thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:150
verses.text: Vast are the evils of which this is the source; far be it from a Christian soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:151
verses.text: Do I not convince thee as I am speaking, do I not shame thee? Then does it now become my duty to alarm you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:152
verses.text: For hear what Christ saith: "Whosoever shall say to his brother, Thou fool, shall be in danger of the hell of fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:153
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:154
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:155
verses.text: ) Now if that which is lightest of all leads to hell, of what shall not he be worthy, who utters presumptuous words? Let us discipline our mouth to silence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:156
verses.text: Great is the advantage from this, great the mischief from ill language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:157
verses.text: We must not spend our riches here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:158
verses.text: Let us put door and bolt upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:159
verses.text: Let us devour ourselves alive if ever a vexatious word slip out of our mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:160
verses.text: Let us entreat God, let us entreat him whom we have reviled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:161
verses.text: Let us not think it beneath us to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:162
verses.text: It is ourselves we have wounded, not him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:163
verses.text: Let us apply the remedy, prayer, and reconciliation with him whom we have reviled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:164
verses.text: If in our words we are to take such forethought, much more let us impose laws upon ourselves in our deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:165
verses.text: Yea, and if we have friends, whoever they may be, and they should speak evil to any man or revile him, demand of them and exact satisfaction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:166
verses.text: Let us by all means learn that such conduct is even sin; for if we learn this, we shall soon depart from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 15:167
verses.text: Now the God of peace keep both your mind and your tongue, and fence you with a sure fence, even His fear, through Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory forever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:1
verses.text: Homily XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:3
verses.text: "Let all bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamor, and railing, be put away from you, with all malice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:4
verses.text: As bees will never settle down in an unclean vessel,—and this is the reason why those who are skilled in these matters sprinkle the spot with perfumes, and scented ointments, and sweet odors; and the wicker baskets also, in which they will have to settle as soon as they come out of the hives they sprinkle with fragrant wines, and all other sweets, that there may be no noisome smell to annoy them, and drive them away again,—so in truth is it also with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:5
verses.text: Our soul is a sort of vessel or basket, capable of receiving the swarms of spiritual gifts; but if there shall be within it gall, and "bitterness, and wrath," the swarms will fly away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:6
verses.text: Hence this blessed and wise husbandman well and thoroughly cleanses our vessels, withholding neither knife nor any other instrument of iron, and invites us to this spiritual swarm; and as he gathers it, he cleanses us with prayers, and labors, and all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:7
verses.text: Mark then how he cleanses out our heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:8
verses.text: He has banished lying, he has banished anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:9
verses.text: Now, again, he is pointing out how that evil may be yet more entirely eradicated; if we be not, saith he, "bitter" in spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:10
verses.text: For it is as is wont to happen with our bile, if there chance to be but little of it, there will be but little disturbance if the receptacle should burst: but if ever the strength and acridness of this quality becomes excessive, the vessel which before held it, containing it no longer, is as if it were eaten through by a scorching fire, and it is no longer able to hold it and contain it within its appointed bounds, but, rent asunder by its intense sharpness, it lets it escape and injure the whole body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:11
verses.text: And it is like some very fierce and frightful wild beast, that has been brought into a city; as long as it is confined in the cages made for it, however it may rage, however it may roar, it will be unable to do harm to any one; but if it is overcome by rage, and breaks through the intervening bars, and is able to leap out, it fills the city with all sorts of confusion and disturbance, and puts everybody to flight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:12
verses.text: Such indeed is the nature also of bile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:13
verses.text: As long as it is kept within its proper limits, it will do us no great mischief; but as soon as ever the membrane that incloses it bursts, and there is nothing to hinder its being at once dispersed over the whole system, then, I say, at that moment, though it be so very trifling in quantity, yet by reason of the inordinate strength of its quality it taints all the other elements of our nature with its own peculiar virulence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:14
verses.text: For finding the blood, for instance, near to it, alike in place and in quality, and rendering the heat which is in that blood more acrid, and everything else in fact which is near it; passing from its just temperature it overflows its bounds, turns all into gall, and therewith at once attacks likewise the other parts of the body; and thus infusing into all its own poisonous quality, it renders the man speechless, and causes him to expire, expelling life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:15
verses.text: Now, why have I stated all these things with such minuteness? It is in order that, understanding from this bitterness which is of the body the intolerable evil of that bitterness which is of the soul, and how entirely it destroys first of all the very soul that engenders it, making everything bitter, we may escape experience of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:16
verses.text: For as the one inflames the whole constitution, so does the other the thoughts, and carries away its captive to the abyss of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:17
verses.text: In order then that by carefully examining these matters we may escape this evil, and bridle the monster, or rather utterly root it out, let us hearken to what Paul saith, "Let all bitterness be" (not destroyed, but) "put away" from you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:18
verses.text: For what need have I of trouble to restrain it, what necessity is there to keep watch on a monster, when it is in my power to expel him from my soul, to remove him and drive him out, as it were, into banishment? Let us hearken then to Paul when he saith, "Let all bitterness be put away from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:19
verses.text: But, ah, the perversity that possesses us! Though we ought to do everything to effect this, yet are there some so truly senseless as to congratulate themselves upon this evil, and to pride themselves upon it, and to glory in it, and who are envied by others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:20
verses.text: "Such a one," say they, "is a bitter man, he is a scorpion, a serpent, a viper".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:21
verses.text: They look upon him as one to be feared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:22
verses.text: But wherefore, good man, dost thou fear the bitter person? "I fear," you say, "lest he injure me, lest he destroy me; I am not proof against his malice, I am afraid lest he should take me who am a simple man, and unable to foresee any of his schemes, and throw me into his snares, and entangle us in the toils which he has set to deceive us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:23
verses.text: Now I cannot but smile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:24
verses.text: And why forsooth? Because these are the arguments of children, who fear things which are not to be feared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:25
verses.text: Surely there is nothing we ought so to despise, nothing we ought so to laugh to scorn, as a bitter and malicious man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:26
verses.text: For there is nothing so powerless as bitterness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:27
verses.text: It makes men fools and senseless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:28
verses.text: Do ye not see that malice is blind? Have ye never heard, that he that diggeth a pit for his neighbors, diggeth it for himself? How, it may be said, ought we not to fear a soul full of tumult? If indeed we are to fear the bitter in the same way as we fear evil spirits, and fools and madmen, (for they indeed do everything at random,) I grant it myself; but if we are to fear them as men skillful in the conduct of affairs, that never.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:29
verses.text: For nothing is so necessary for the proper conduct of affairs as prudence; and there is no greater hindrance to prudence than wickedness, and malice, and hollowness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:30
verses.text: Look at bilious persons, how unsightly they are, with all their bloom withered away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:31
verses.text: How weak they are, and puny, and unfit for anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:32
verses.text: So also are souls of this nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:33
verses.text: What else is wickedness, but a jaundice of the soul? Wickedness then has no strength in it, indeed it has not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:34
verses.text: Have ye a mind that I again make what I am saying plain to you by an instance, by setting before you the portraits of a treacherous and a guileless man? Absalom was a treacherous man, and "stole all men's hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:35
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:36
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:37
verses.text: ) And observe how great was his treachery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:38
verses.text: "He went about," it saith, "and said, 'Hast thou no judgment?'" wishing to conciliate every one to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:39
verses.text: But David was guileless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:40
verses.text: What then? Look at the end of them both, look, how full of utter madness was the former! For inasmuch as he looked solely to the hurt of his father, in all other things he was blinded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:41
verses.text: But not so David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:42
verses.text: For "he that walketh uprightly, walketh surely" (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:43
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:44
verses.text: ); and reasonably; he is one that manages nothing over-subtilely, the man who devises no evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:45
verses.text: Let us listen then to the blessed Paul, and let us pity, yea, let us weep for the bitter-minded, and let us practice every method, let us do everything to extirpate this vice from their souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:46
verses.text: For how is it not absurd, that when there is bile within us (though that indeed is a useful element, for without bile a man cannot possibly exist, that bile, I mean, which is an element of his nature,) how then, I say, is it not absurd that we should do all we can to get rid of this, though we are so highly benefited by it; and yet that we should do nothing, nor take any pains, to get rid of that which is in the soul, though it is in no case beneficial, but even in the highest degree injurious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:47
verses.text: He that thinketh that he is "wise among you," saith he, "let him become a fool, that he may become wise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:48
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:49
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:50
verses.text: ) Hearken too again to what Luke saith, "They did take their food with gladness and singleness of heart, praising God, and having favor with all the people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:51
verses.text: (Acts ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:53
verses.text: ) Why, do we not see even now that the simple and guileless enjoy the common esteem of all? No one envies such an one when he is in prosperity, no one tramples upon him when he is in adversity, but all rejoice with him when he does well, and grieve with him in misfortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:54
verses.text: Whereas whenever a bitter man fares prosperously, one and all lament it, as though some evil thing happened; but if he is unfortunate, one and all rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:55
verses.text: Let us then pity them, for they have common enemies all over the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:56
verses.text: Jacob was a guileless man, yet he overcame the treacherous Esau.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:57
verses.text: "For into a malicious soul wisdom shall not enter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:58
verses.text: (Wisd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:59
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:60
verses.text: ) "Let all bitterness be put away from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:61
verses.text: Let not even a remnant remain, for it will be sure, if stirred, as if from a smouldering brand, to turn all within to an entire blaze.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:62
verses.text: Let us then distinctly understand what this bitterness is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:63
verses.text: Take, for example, the hollow-hearted man, the crafty, the man who is on the watch to do mischief, the man of evil suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:64
verses.text: From him then "wrath" and "anger" are ever produced; for it is not possible for a soul like this to be in tranquillity, but the very root of "anger" and "wrath" is "bitterness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:65
verses.text: The man of this character is both sullen, and never unbends his soul; he is always moody, always gloomy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:66
verses.text: For as I was saying, they themselves are the first to reap the fruit of their own evil ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:67
verses.text: "And clamor," he adds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:68
verses.text: What now, and dost thou take away clamor also? Yes, for the mild man must needs be of such a character, because clamor carries anger, as a horse his rider; trip the horse, and you will throw the rider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:69
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:70
verses.text: This let women above all attend to, them who on every occasion cry aloud and bawl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:71
verses.text: There is but one thing in which it is useful to cry aloud, in preaching and in teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:72
verses.text: But in no other case whatever, no, not even in prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:73
verses.text: And if thou wouldest learn a practical lesson, never cry aloud at all, and then wilt thou never be angry at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:74
verses.text: Behold a way to keep your temper; for as it is not possible that the man that does not cry out should be enraged, so is it not that the man who does cry out should be otherwise than enraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:75
verses.text: For tell me not of a man being implacable, and revengeful, and of pure natural bitterness, and natural choler.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:76
verses.text: We are now speaking of the sudden paroxysm of this passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:77
verses.text: It contributes then no little to this end, to discipline the soul never to raise the voice and cry aloud at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:78
verses.text: Cut off clamor, and thou wilt clip the wings of anger, thou dost repress the first rising of the heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:79
verses.text: For as it is impossible for a man to wrestle without lifting up his hands, so is it not possible that he should be entangled in a quarrel without lifting up his voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:80
verses.text: Bind the hands of the boxer, and then bid him strike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:81
verses.text: He will be unable to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:82
verses.text: So likewise will wrath be disarmed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:83
verses.text: But clamor raises it, even where it does not exist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:84
verses.text: And hence it is especially that the female sex are so easily overtaken in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:85
verses.text: Women, whenever they are angry with their maid-servants, fill the whole house with their own clamor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:86
verses.text: And oftentimes too, if the house happens to be built along a narrow street, then all the passers-by hear the mistress scolding, and the maid weeping and wailing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:87
verses.text: What can possibly be more disgraceful than the sound of those wailings? What in the world has happened there? All the women round immediately peep in and one of them says, "Such a one is beating her own maid".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:88
verses.text: Whatever can be more shameless than this? "What then, ought one not to strike at all?" No, I say not so, (for it must be done,) but then it must be neither frequently, nor immoderately, nor for any wrongs of thine own, as I am constantly saying, nor for any little failure in her service, but only if she is doing harm to her own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:89
verses.text: If thou chastise her for a fault of this kind, all will applaud, and there will be none to upbraid thee; but if thou do it for any reasons of thine own, all will condemn thy cruelty and harshness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:90
verses.text: And what is more base than all, there are some so fierce and so savage as to lash them to such a degree, that the bruises will not disappear with the day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:91
verses.text: For they will strip the damsels, and call their husbands for the purpose, and oftentimes tie them to the pallets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:92
verses.text: Alas! at that moment, tell me, does no recollection of hell come over thee? What? dost thou strip thy handmaid, and expose her to thy husband? And art thou not ashamed, lest he should condemn thee for it? And then dost thou exasperate him yet more, and threaten to put her in chains, having first taunted the wretched and pitiable creature with ten thousand reproachful names, and called her "Thessalian witch, runaway, and prostitute"?  For her passion allows her not to spare even her own mouth, but she looks to one single object, how she may wreak her vengeance on the other, even though she disgrace herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:93
verses.text: And then after all these things forsooth, she will sit in state like any tyrant, and call her children, and summon her foolish husband, and treat him as a hangman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:94
verses.text: Ought these things to take place in the houses of Christians? "Aye" say ye, "but slaves are a troublesome, audacious, impudent, incorrigible race".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:95
verses.text: True, I know it myself, but there are other ways to keep them in order; by terrors, by threats, by words; which may both touch her more powerfully, and save thee from disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:96
verses.text: Thou who art a free woman hast uttered foul words, and dost thou not disgrace thyself more than her? Then if she shall have occasion to go out to the bath, there are bruises on her back when she is naked, and she carries about with her the marks of thy cruelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:97
verses.text: "But," say ye, "the whole tribe of slaves is intolerable if it meet with indulgence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:98
verses.text: True, I know it myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:99
verses.text: But then, as I was saying, correct them in some other way, not by the scourge only, and by terror, but even by flattering them, and by acts of kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:100
verses.text: If she is a believer, she is thy sister.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:101
verses.text: Consider that thou art her mistress, and that she ministers unto thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:102
verses.text: If she be intemperate, cut off the occasions of drunkenness; call thy husband, and admonish her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:103
verses.text: Or dost thou not feel how disgraceful a thing it is for a woman to be beaten? They at least who have enacted ten thousand punishments for men,—the stake, and the rack,—will scarcely ever hang a woman, but limit men's anger to smiting her on the cheek; and so great respect have they observed towards the sex, that not even when there is absolute necessity have they often hung a woman, if she happen to be pregnant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:104
verses.text: For it is a disgrace for a man to strike a woman; and if for a man, much more for one of her own sex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:105
verses.text: It is moreover by these things that women become odious to their husbands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:106
verses.text: "What then," ye may say, "if she shall act the harlot?" Marry her to a husband; cut off the occasions of fornication, suffer her not to be too high fed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:107
verses.text: "What then, if she shall steal?" Take care of her, and watch her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:108
verses.text: —"Extravagant!" thou wilt say; "What, am I to be her keeper? How absurd!" And why, I pray, art thou not to be her keeper? Has she not the same kind of soul as thou? Has she not been vouchsafed the same privileges by God? Does she not partake of the same table? Does she not share with thee the same high birth? "But what then," ye will say, "if she shall be a railer, or a gossip, or a drunkard?" Yet, how many free women are such? Now, with all the failings of women God hath charged men to bear: only, He saith, let not a woman be an harlot, but every other failing besides bear with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:109
verses.text: Yea, be she drunkard, or railer, or gossip, or evil-eyed, or extravagant, and a squanderer of thy substance, thou hast her for the partner of thy life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:110
verses.text: Train and restrain her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:111
verses.text: Necessity is upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:112
verses.text: It is for this thou art the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:113
verses.text: Regulate her therefore, do thy own part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:114
verses.text: Yea, and if she remain incorrigible, yea, though she steal, take care of thy goods, and do not punish her so much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:115
verses.text: If she be a gossip, silence her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:116
verses.text: This is the very highest philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:117
verses.text: Now, however, some are come to such a height of indecency as to uncover the head, and to drag their maid-servants by the hair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:118
verses.text: —Why do ye all blush? I am not addressing myself to all, but to those who are carried away into such brutal conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:119
verses.text: Paul saith, "Let not a woman be uncovered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:120
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:121
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:123
verses.text: ) And dost thou then entirely strip off her headdress? Dost thou see how thou art doing outrage to thyself? If indeed she makes her appearance to thee with her head bare, thou callest it an insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:124
verses.text: And dost thou say that there is nothing shocking when thou barest it thyself? Then ye will say, "What if she be not corrected?" Chasten her then with the rod and with stripes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:125
verses.text: And yet how many failings hast thou also thyself, and yet thou art not corrected! These things I am saying not for their sakes, but for the sake of you free-women, that ye do nothing so unworthy, nothing to disgrace you, that ye do yourselves no wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:126
verses.text: If thou wilt learn this lesson in thy household in dealing with thy maid-servant, and not be harsh but gentle and forbearing, much more wilt thou be so in thy behavior to thy husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:127
verses.text: For she who, though having authority, does nothing of the sort, will do it much less where there is a check.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:128
verses.text: So that the discipline employed about your maid-servants, will be of the greatest service to you in gaining the goodwill of your husbands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:129
verses.text: "For with what measure ye mete," He saith, "it shall be measured unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:130
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:131
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:132
verses.text: ) Set a bridle upon thy mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:133
verses.text: If thou art disciplined to bear bravely with a servant when she answers back, thou wilt not be annoyed with the insolence of an equal, and in being above annoyance, wilt have attained to the highest philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:134
verses.text: But some there are who add even oaths, but there is nothing more shocking than a woman so enraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:135
verses.text: But what again, ye will say, if she dress gaily? Why then, forbid this; thou hast my consent; but check it by first beginning with thyself, not so much by fear as by example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:136
verses.text: Be in everything thyself a perfect pattern.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:137
verses.text: "And let railing," saith he, "be put away from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:138
verses.text: Observe the progress of mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:139
verses.text: Bitterness produces wrath, wrath anger, anger clamor, clamor railing, that is, revilings; next from evil-speaking it goes on to blows, from blows to wounds, from wounds to death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:140
verses.text: Paul, however, did not wish to mention any of these, but only this, "let this," saith he, "be put away from you, with all malice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:141
verses.text: What is "with all malice"? It ends with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:142
verses.text: For there are some, like those dogs that bite secretly, which do not bark at all at those that come near them, nor are angry, but which fawn, and display a gentle aspect; but when they catch us off our guard, will fix their teeth in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:143
verses.text: These are more dangerous than those that take up open enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:144
verses.text: Now since there are men too that are dogs, who neither cry out, nor fly in a passion, nor threaten us when they are offended, yet in secret are weaving plots, and contriving ten thousand mischiefs, and revenging themselves not in words but in deeds; he hints at these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:145
verses.text: Let those things be put away from you, saith he, "with all malice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:146
verses.text: Do not spare thy words, and then revenge thyself in acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:147
verses.text: My purpose in chastising my tongue and curtailing its clamor, is to prevent its kindling up a more violent blaze.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:148
verses.text: But if thou without any clamor art doing the same thing, and art cherishing the fire and the live coals within, where is the good of thy silence? Dost thou not know that those conflagrations are the most destructive of all which are fed within, and appear not to those that are without? And that those wounds are the deadliest which never break out to the surface; and those fevers the worst which burn up the vitals? So also is this anger the most dangerous that preys upon the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:149
verses.text: But let this too be put away from you, saith he, "with all malice," of every kind and degree, great and little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:150
verses.text: Let us then hearken to him, let us cast out all "bitterness and all malice," that we "grieve not the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:151
verses.text: Let us destroy all bitterness; let us cut it up by the very roots.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:152
verses.text: Nothing good, nothing healthful, can ever come from a bitter soul; nothing but misfortunes, nothing but tears, nothing but weeping and wailing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:153
verses.text: Do ye not see those beasts that roar or cry out, how we turn away from them; the lion, for instance, and the bear? But not so from the sheep; for there is no roaring, but a mild and gentle voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:154
verses.text: And so again with musical instruments, those which are loud and harsh are the most unpleasant to the ear, such as the drum and trumpet; whereas those which are not so, but are soothing, these are pleasant, as the flute and lyre and pipe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:155
verses.text: Let us then prepare our soul so as never to cry aloud, and thus shall we be enabled also to gain the mastery over our anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 16:156
verses.text: And when we have cut out this, we ourselves shall be the first to enjoy the calm, and we shall sail into that peaceful haven, which God grant we may all attain, in Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom, together with the Holy Ghost, be unto the Father, glory, might, and honor, now, and ever, and throughout all ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:1
verses.text: Homily XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:3
verses.text: ,  "Let all bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamor, and railing be put away from you, with all malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:4
verses.text: And be ye kind one to another, tender-hearted, forgiving each other, even as God also in Christ forgave you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:5
verses.text: If we are to attain to the kingdom of Heaven, it is not enough to abandon wickedness, but there must be abundant practice of that which is good also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:6
verses.text: To be delivered indeed from hell we must abstain from wickedness; but to attain to the kingdom we must cleave fast to virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:7
verses.text: Know ye not that even in the tribunals of the heathen, when examination is made of men's deeds, and the whole city is assembled, this is the case? Nay, there was an ancient custom amongst the heathen, to crown with a golden crown,—not the man who had done no evil to his country, for this were in itself no more than enough to save him from punishment;—but him who had displayed great public services.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:8
verses.text: It was thus that a man was to be advanced to this distinction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:9
verses.text: But what I had especial need to say, had, I know not how, well nigh escaped me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:10
verses.text: Accordingly having made some slight correction of what I have said, I retract the first portion of this division.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:11
verses.text: For as I was saying that the departure from evil is sufficient to prevent our falling into hell, whilst I was speaking, there stole upon me a certain awful sentence, which does not merely bring down vengeance on them that dare to commit evil, but which also punishes those who omit any opportunity of doing good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:12
verses.text: What sentence then is this? When the day, the dreadful day, He saith, was arrived, and the set time was come, the Judge, seated on the judgment seat, set the sheep on the right hand and the goats on the left; and to the sheep He said, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world: for I was an hungered, and ye gave me meat".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:13
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:14
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:15
verses.text: ) So far, well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:16
verses.text: For it was meet that for such compassion they should receive this reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:17
verses.text: That those, however, who did not communicate of their own possessions to them that were in need, that they should be punished, not merely by the loss of blessings, but by being also sent to hell-fire, what just reason, I say, can there be in this? Most certainly this too will have a fair show of reason, no less than the other case: for we are hence instructed, that they that have done good shall enjoy those good things that are in heaven, but they, who, though they have no evil indeed to be charged with, yet have omitted to do good, will be hurried away with them that have done evil into hell-fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:18
