verses.text: Unless one might indeed say this, that the very not doing good is a part of wickedness, inasmuch as it comes of indolence, and indolence is a part of vice, or rather, not a part, but a source and baneful root of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:19
verses.text: For idleness is the teacher of all vice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:20
verses.text: Let us not then foolishly ask such questions as these, what place shall he occupy, who has done neither any evil nor any good? For the very not doing good, is in itself doing evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:21
verses.text: Tell me, if thou hadst a servant, who should neither steal, nor insult, nor contradict thee, who moreover should keep from drunkenness and every other kind of vice, and yet should sit perpetually in idleness, and not doing one of those duties which a servant owes to his master, wouldest thou not chastise him, wouldest thou not put him to the rack? Tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:22
verses.text: And yet forsooth he has done no evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:23
verses.text: No, but this is in itself doing evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:24
verses.text: But let us, if you please, apply this to other cases in life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:25
verses.text: Suppose then that of an husbandman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:26
verses.text: He does no damage to our property, he lays no plots against us, and he is not a thief, he only ties his hands behind him, and sits at home, neither sowing, nor cutting a single furrow, nor harnessing oxen to the yoke, nor looking after a vine, nor in fact discharging any one of those other labors required in husbandry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:27
verses.text: Now, I say, should we not punish such a man? And yet he has done no wrong to any one; we have no charge to make against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:28
verses.text: No, but by this very thing has he done wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:29
verses.text: He does wrong in that he does not contribute his own share to the common stock of good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:30
verses.text: And what again, tell me, if every single artisan or mechanic were only to do no harm, say to one of a different craft,—nay, were to do no harm, even to one of his own, but only were to be idle, would not our whole life at that rate be utterly at an end and perish? Do you wish that I yet further extend the discourse with reference to the body also? Let the hand then neither strike the head, nor cut out the tongue, nor pluck out the eye, nor do any evil of this sort, but only remain idle, and not render its due service to the body at large; would it not be more fitting that it should be cut off, than that one should carry it about in idleness, and a detriment to the whole body? And what too, if the mouth, without either devouring the hand, or biting the breast, should nevertheless fail in all its proper duties; were it not far better that it should be stopped up? If therefore both in the case of servants, and of mechanics, and of the whole body, not only the commission of evil, but also the omission of what is good, is great unrighteousness, much more will this be the case in regard to the body of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:31
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:32
verses.text: And therefore the blessed Paul also, in leading us away from sin, leads us on to virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:33
verses.text: For where, tell me, is the advantage of all the thorns being cut out, if the good seeds be not sown? For our labor, remaining unfinished, will come round and end in the same mischief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:34
verses.text: And therefore Paul also, in his deep and affectionate anxiety for us, does not let his admonitions stop at eradicating and destroying evil tempers, but urges us at once to evidence the implanting of good ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:35
verses.text: For having said, "Let all bitterness, and wrath, and clamor, and railing be put away from you, with all malice," he adds, "And be ye kind one to another, tender-hearted, forgiving each other".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:36
verses.text: For all these are habits and dispositions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:37
verses.text: And our abandonment of the one thing is not sufficient to settle us in the habitual practice of the other, but there is need again of some fresh impulse, and of an effort not less than that made in our avoidance of evil dispositions, in order to our acquiring good ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:38
verses.text: For so in the case of the body, the black man, if he gets rid of this complexion, does not straightway become white.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:39
verses.text: Or rather let us not conduct our discourse with an argument from physical subjects, but draw our example from those which concern moral choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:40
verses.text: He who is not our enemy, is not necessarily our friend; but there is an intermediate state, neither of enmity nor of friendship, which is perhaps that in which the greater part of mankind stand toward us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:41
verses.text: He that is not crying is not therefore necessarily also laughing, but there is a state between the two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:42
verses.text: And so, I say, is the case here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:43
verses.text: He that is not "bitter" is not necessarily "kind," neither is he that is not "wrathful" necessarily "tender-hearted"; but there is need of a distinct effort, in order to acquire this excellence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:44
verses.text: And now look how the blessed Paul, according to the rules of the best husbandry, thoroughly cleans and works the land entrusted to him by the Husbandman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:45
verses.text: He has taken away the bad seeds; he now exhorts us to retain the good plants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:46
verses.text: "Be ye kind," saith he, for if, when the thorns are plucked up, the field remains idle, it will again bear unprofitable weeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:47
verses.text: And therefore there is need to preoccupy its unoccupied and fallow state by the setting of good seeds and plants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:48
verses.text: He takes away "anger," he puts in "kindness"; he takes away "bitterness," he puts in "tender-heartedness"; he extirpates "malice" and "railing," he plants "forgiveness" in their stead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:49
verses.text: For the expression, "forgiving one another," is this; be disposed, he means, to forgive one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:50
verses.text: And this forgiveness is greater than that which is shown in money-matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:51
verses.text: For he indeed who forgives a debt of money to him that has borrowed of him, does, it is true, a noble and admirable deed, but then the kindness is confined to the body, though to himself indeed he repays a full recompense by that benefit which is spiritual and concerns the soul; whereas he who forgives trespasses will be benefiting alike his own soul, and the soul of him who receives the forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:52
verses.text: For by this way of acting, he not only renders himself, but the other also, more charitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:53
verses.text: Because we do not so deeply touch the souls of those who have wronged us by revenging ourselves, as by pardoning them, and thus shaming them and putting them out of countenance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:54
verses.text: For by the other course we shall be doing no good, either to ourselves or to them, but shall be doing harm to both by seeking ourselves for retaliation, like the rulers of the Jews, and by kindling up the wrath that is in them; but if we return injustice with gentleness, we shall disarm all his anger, and shall be setting up in his breast a tribunal which will give a verdict in our favor, and will condemn him more severely than we ourselves could.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:55
verses.text: For he will convict and will pass sentence upon himself, and will look for every pretext for repaying the share of long-suffering granted him with fuller measure, knowing that, if he repay it in equal measure, he is thus at a disadvantage, in not having himself made the beginning, but received the example from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:56
verses.text: He will strive accordingly to exceed in measure, in order to eclipse, by the excess of his recompense, the disadvantage he himself sustains in having been second in making advances towards requital; and the disadvantage again which accrues to the other from the time, if he was the first sufferer, this he will make up by excess of kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:57
verses.text: For men, if they are right-minded, are not so affected by evil as by the good treatment they may receive at the hands of those whom they have injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:58
verses.text: For it is a base sin, and it is matter of reproach and scorn for a man who is well-treated not to return it; whilst for a man who is ill-treated, not to go about to resent it, this has the praise and applause, and the good word of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:59
verses.text: And therefore they are more deeply touched by this conduct than any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:60
verses.text: So that if thou hast a wish to revenge thyself, revenge thyself in this manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:61
verses.text: Return good for evil, that thou mayest render him even thy debtor, and achieve a glorious victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:62
verses.text: Hast thou suffered evil? Do good; thus avenge thee of thine enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:63
verses.text: For if thou shalt go about to resent it, all will blame both thee and him alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:64
verses.text: Whereas if thou shalt endure it, it will be otherwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:65
verses.text: Thee they will applaud and admire; but him they will reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:66
verses.text: And what greater punishment can there be to an enemy, than to behold his enemy admired and applauded by all men? What more bitter to an enemy, than to behold himself reproached by all before his enemy's face? If thou shalt avenge thee on him, thou wilt both be condemned perhaps thyself, and wilt be the sole avenger; whereas, if thou shalt forgive him, all will be avengers in thy stead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:67
verses.text: And this will be far more severe than any evil he can suffer, that his enemy should have so many to avenge him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:68
verses.text: If thou openest thy mouth, they will be silent; but if thou art silent, not with one tongue only, but with ten thousand tongues of others, thou smitest him, and art the more avenged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:69
verses.text: And on thee indeed, if thou shalt reproach him, many again will cast imputations (for they will say that thy words are those of passion); but when others who have suffered no wrong from him thus overwhelm him with reproaches, then is the revenge especially clear of all suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:70
verses.text: For when they who have suffered no mischief, in consequence of thy excessive forbearance feel and sympathize with thee, as though they had been wronged themselves, this is a vengeance clear of all suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:71
verses.text: "But what then," ye will say, "if no man should take vengeance?" It cannot be that men will be such stones, as to behold such wisdom and not admire it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:72
verses.text: And though they wreak not their vengeance on him at the time; still, afterwards, when they are in the mood, they will do so, and they will continue to scoff at him and abuse him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:73
verses.text: And if no one else admire thee, the man himself will most surely admire thee, though he may not own it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:74
verses.text: For our judgment of what is right, even though we be come to the very depth of wickedness, remains impartial and unbiased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:75
verses.text: Why, suppose ye, did our Lord Christ say, "Whosoever smiteth thee on the right cheek, turn to him the other also"? (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:76
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:77
verses.text: ) Is it not because the more long-suffering a man is, the more signal the benefit he confers both on himself and on the other? For this cause He charges us to "turn the other also," to satisfy the desire of the enraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:78
verses.text: For who is such a monster as not to be at once put to shame? The very dogs are said to feel it; for if they bark and attack a man, and he throws himself on his back and does nothing, he puts a stop to all their wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:79
verses.text: If they then reverence the man who is ready to suffer evil from them, much more will the race of man do so, inasmuch as they are more rational.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:80
verses.text: However, it is right not to overlook what a little before came into my recollection, and was brought forward for a testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:81
verses.text: And what then was this? We were speaking of the Jews, and of the chief rulers amongst them, how that they were blamed, as seeking retaliation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:82
verses.text: And yet this the law permitted them; "eye for eye, and tooth for tooth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:83
verses.text: (Lev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:84
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:85
verses.text: ) True, but not to the intent that men should pluck out each other's eyes, but that they should check boldness in aggression, by fear of suffering in return, and thus should neither do any evil to others, nor suffer any evil from others themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:86
verses.text: Therefore it was said, "eye for eye," to bind the hands of the aggressor, not to let thine loose against him; not to ward off the hurt from thine eyes only, but also to preserve his eyes safe and sound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:87
verses.text: But, as to what I was enquiring about,—why, if retaliation was allowed, were they arraigned who practiced it? Whatever can this mean? He here speaks of vindictiveness; for on the spur of the moment he allows the sufferer to act, as I was saying, in order to check the aggressor; but to bear a grudge he permits no longer; because the act then is no longer one of passion, nor of boiling rage, but of malice premeditated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:88
verses.text: Now God forgives those who may be carried away, perhaps upon a sense of outrage, and rush out to resent it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:89
verses.text: Hence He says, "eye for eye"; and yet again, "the ways of the revengeful lead to death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:90
verses.text: Now, if, where it was permitted to put out eye for eye, so great a punishment is reserved for the revengeful, how much more for those who are bidden even to expose themselves to ill-treatment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:91
verses.text: Let us not then be revengeful, but let us quench our anger, that we may be counted worthy of the lovingkindness, which comes from God ("for with what measure," saith Christ, "ye mete, it shall be measured unto you, and with what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged") (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:92
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 17:93
verses.text: ), and that we may both escape the snares of this present life, and in the day that is at hand, may obtain pardon at His hands, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, both now and forever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:1
verses.text: Homily XVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:2
verses.text: Ephesians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:3
verses.text: and v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:4
verses.text: ,  "And be ye kind one to another, tender hearted, forgiving each other, even as God also in Christ forgave you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:5
verses.text: Be ye therefore imitators of God, as beloved children; and walk in love, even as Christ also loved you, and gave Himself up for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for an odor of a sweet smell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:6
verses.text: The events which are past have greater force than those which are yet to come, and appear to be both more wonderful and more convincing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:7
verses.text: And hence accordingly Paul founds his exhortation upon the things which have already been done for us, inasmuch as they, on Christ's account, have a greater force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:8
verses.text: For to say, "Forgive, and ye shall be forgiven" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:9
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:10
verses.text: ), and "if ye forgive not, ye shall in nowise be forgiven" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:11
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:12
verses.text: ),—this addressed to men of understanding, and men who believe in the things to come, is of great weight; but Paul appeals to the conscience not by these arguments only, but also by things already done for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:13
verses.text: In the former way we may escape punishment, whereas in this latter we may have our share of some positive good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:14
verses.text: Thou imitatest Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:15
verses.text: This alone is enough to recommend virtue, that it is "to imitate God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:16
verses.text: This is a higher principle than the other, "for He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sendeth rain on the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:17
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:18
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:19
verses.text: ) Because he does not merely say that we are "imitating God," but that we do so in those things wherein we receive ourselves such benefits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:20
verses.text: He would have us cherish the tender heart of fathers towards each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:21
verses.text: For by heart, here, is meant lovingkindness and compassion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:22
verses.text: For inasmuch as it cannot be that, being men, we shall avoid either giving pain or suffering it, he does the next thing, he devises a remedy,—that we should forgive one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:23
verses.text: And yet there is no comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:24
verses.text: For if thou indeed shouldest at this moment forgive any one, he will forgive thee again in return; whereas to God thou hast neither given nor forgiven anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:25
verses.text: And thou indeed art forgiving a fellow-servant; whereas God is forgiving a servant, and an enemy, and one that hates Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:26
verses.text: "Even as God," saith he, "also in Christ forgave you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:27
verses.text: And this, moreover, contains a high allusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:28
verses.text: Not simply, he would say, hath He forgiven us, and at no risk or cost, but at the sacrifice of His Son; for that He might forgive thee, He sacrificed the Son; whereas thou, oftentimes, even when thou seest pardon to be both without risk and without cost, yet dost not grant it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:29
verses.text: "Be ye therefore imitators of God as beloved children; and walk in love, even as Christ also loved you, and gave Himself up for us an offering and sacrifice to God for an odor of a sweet smell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:30
verses.text: That thou mayest not then think it an act of necessity, hear how He saith, that "He gave Himself up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:31
verses.text: As thy Master loved thee, love thou thy friend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:32
verses.text: Nay, but neither wilt thou be able so to love; yet still do so as far as thou art able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:33
verses.text: Oh, what can be more blessed than a sound like this! Tell me of royalty or whatever else thou wilt, there is no comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:34
verses.text: Forgive another, and thou art "imitating God," thou art made like unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:35
verses.text: It is more our duty to forgive trespasses than debts of money; for if thou forgive debts, thou hast not "imitated God"; whereas if thou shalt forgive trespasses, thou art "imitating God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:36
verses.text: And yet how shalt thou be able to say, "I am poor, and am not able to forgive it," that is, a debt, when thou forgivest not that which thou art able to forgive, that is, a trespass? And surely thou dost not deem that in this case there is any loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:37
verses.text: Yea, is it not rather wealth, is it not abundance, is it not a plentiful store?  And behold yet another and a nobler incitement:—"as beloved children," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:38
verses.text: Ye have yet another cogent reason to imitate Him, not only in that ye have received such good at His hands, but also in that ye are called His children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:39
verses.text: And since not all children imitate their fathers, but those which are beloved, therefore he saith, "as beloved children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:40
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:41
verses.text: "Walk in love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:42
verses.text: Behold, here, the groundwork of all! So then where this is, there is no "wrath, no anger, no clamor, no railing," but all are done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:43
verses.text: Accordingly he puts the chief point last.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:44
verses.text: Whence wast thou made a child? Because thou wast forgiven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:45
verses.text: On the same ground on which thou hast had so vast a privilege vouch-safed thee, on that selfsame ground forgive thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:46
verses.text: Tell me, I say, if thou wert in prison, and hadst ten thousand misdeeds to answer for, and some one were to bring thee into the palace; or rather to pass over this argument, suppose thou wert in a fever and in the agonies of death, and some one were to benefit thee by some medicine, wouldest thou not value him more than all, yea and the very name of the medicine? For if we thus regard occasions and places by which we are benefited, even as our own souls, much more shall we the things themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:47
verses.text: Be a lover then of love; for by this art thou saved, by this hast thou been made a son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:48
verses.text: And if thou shalt have it in thy power to save another, wilt thou not use the same remedy, and give the advice to all, "Forgive, that ye may be forgiven"? Thus to incite one another, were the part of grateful, of generous, and noble spirits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:49
verses.text: "Even as Christ also," he adds, "loved you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:50
verses.text: Thou art only sparing friends, He enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:51
verses.text: So then far greater is that boon which cometh from our Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:52
verses.text: For how in our case is the "even as" preserved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:53
verses.text: Surely it is clear that it will be, by our doing good to our enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:54
verses.text: "And gave Himself up for us an offering and a sacrifice to God for an odor of a sweet smell".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:55
verses.text: Seest thou that to suffer for one's enemies is "a sweet-smelling savor," and an "acceptable sacrifice"? And if thou shalt die, then wilt thou be indeed a sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:56
verses.text: This it is to "imitate God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:58
verses.text: "But fornication, and all uncleanness or covetousness, let it not even be named among you, as becometh saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:59
verses.text: He has spoken of the bitter passion, of wrath; he now comes to the lesser evil: for that lust is the lesser evil, hear how Moses also in the law says, first, "Thou shalt do no murder" (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:60
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:61
verses.text: ), which is the work of wrath, and then, "Thou shalt not commit adultery" (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:62
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:63
verses.text: ), which is of lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:64
verses.text: For as "bitterness," and "clamor," and "all malice," and "railing," and the like, are the works of the passionate man, so likewise are "fornication, uncleanness, covetousness," those of the lustful; since avarice and sensuality spring from the same passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:65
verses.text: But just as in the former case he took away "clamor" as being the vehicle of "anger," so now does he "filthy talking" and "jesting" as being the vehicle of lust; for he proceeds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:66
verses.text: "Nor filthiness, nor foolish talking, or jesting, which are not befitting; but rather giving of thanks".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:67
verses.text: Have no witticisms, no obscenities, either in word or in deed, and thou wilt quench the flame—"let them not even be named," saith he, "among you," that is, let them not anywhere even make their appearance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:68
verses.text: This he says also in writing to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:69
verses.text: "It is actually reported that there is fornication among you" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:70
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:71
verses.text: ); as much as to say, Be ye all pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:72
verses.text: For words are the way to acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:73
verses.text: Then, that he may not appear a forbidding kind of person and austere, and a destroyer of playfulness, he goes on to add the reason, by saying, "which are not befitting," which have nothing to do with us—"but rather giving of thanks".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:74
verses.text: What good is there in uttering a witticism? thou only raisest a laugh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:75
verses.text: Tell me, will the shoemaker ever busy himself about anything which does not belong to or befit his trade? or will he purchase any tool of that kind? No, never.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:76
verses.text: Because the things we do not need, are nothing to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:77
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:78
verses.text: Let there not be one idle word; for from idle words we fall also into foul words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:79
verses.text: The present is no season of loose merriment, but of mourning, of tribulation, and lamentation: and dost thou play the jester? What wrestler on entering the ring neglects the struggle with his adversary, and utters witticisms? The devil stands hard at hand, "he is going about roaring" ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:80
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:81
verses.text: ) to catch thee, he is moving everything, and turning everything against thy life, and is scheming to force thee from thy retreat, he is grinding his teeth and bellowing, he is breathing fire against thy salvation; and dost thou sit uttering witticisms, and "talking folly," and uttering things "which are not befitting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:82
verses.text: Full nobly then wilt thou be able to overcome him! We are in sport, beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:83
verses.text: Wouldest thou know the life of the saints? Listen to what Paul saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:84
verses.text: "By the space of three years I ceased not to admonish every one night and day with tears".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:85
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:86
verses.text: ) And if so great was the zeal he exerted in behalf of them of Miletus and Ephesus, not making pleasant speeches, but introducing his admonition with tears, what should one say of the rest? But hearken again to what he says to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:87
verses.text: "Out of much affliction and anguish of heart I wrote unto you with many tears".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:88
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:89
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:90
verses.text: ) And again, "Who is weak, and I am not weak?" "Who is made to stumble, and I burn not?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:91
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:92
verses.text: ) And hearken again to what he says elsewhere, desiring every day, as one might say, to depart out of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:93
verses.text: "For indeed we that are in this tabernacle do groan" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:94
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:95
verses.text: ); and dost thou laugh and play? It is war-time, and art thou handling the dancers' instruments? Look at the countenances of men in battle, their dark and contracted mien, their brow terrible and full of awe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:96
verses.text: Mark the stern eye, the heart eager and beating and throbbing, their spirit collected, and trembling and intensely anxious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:97
verses.text: All is good order, all is good discipline, all is silence in the camps of those who are arrayed against each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:98
verses.text: They speak not, I do not say, an impertinent word, but they utter not a single sound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:99
verses.text: Now if they who have visible enemies, and who are in nowise injured by words, yet observe so great silence, dost thou who hast thy warfare, and the chief of thy warfare in words, dost thou leave this part naked and exposed? Or art thou ignorant that it is here that we are most beset with snares? Art thou amusing and enjoying thyself, and uttering witticisms and raising a laugh, and regarding the matter as a mere nothing? How many perjuries, how many injuries, how many filthy speeches have arisen from witticisms! "But no," ye will say, "pleasantries are not like this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:100
verses.text: Yet hear how he excludes all kinds of jesting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:101
verses.text: It is a time now of war and fighting, of watch and guard, of arming and arraying ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:102
verses.text: The time of laughter can have no place here; for that is of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:103
verses.text: Hear what Christ saith: "The world shall rejoice, but ye shall be sorrowful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:104
verses.text: (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:105
verses.text: ) Christ was crucified for thy ills, and dost thou laugh? He was buffeted, and endured so great sufferings because of thy calamity, and the tempest that had overtaken thee; and dost thou play the reveler? And how wilt thou not then rather provoke Him?  But since the matter appears to some to be one of indifference, which moreover is difficult to be guarded against, let us discuss this point a little, to show you how vast an evil it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:106
verses.text: For indeed this is a work of the devil, to make us disregard things indifferent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:107
verses.text: First of all then, even if it were indifferent, not even in that case were it right to disregard it, when one knows that the greatest evils are both produced and increased by it, and that it oftentimes terminates in fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:108
verses.text: However, that it is not even indifferent is evident from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:109
verses.text: Let us see then whence it is produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:110
verses.text: Or rather, let us see what sort of a person a saint ought to be:—gentle, meek, sorrowful, mournful, contrite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:111
verses.text: The man then who deals in jests is no saint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:112
verses.text: Nay, were he even a Greek, such an one would be scorned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:113
verses.text: These are things allowed to those only who are on the stage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:114
verses.text: Where filthiness is, there also is jesting; where unseasonable laughter is, there also is jesting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:115
verses.text: Hearken to what the Prophet saith, "Serve the Lord in fear, and rejoice with trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:116
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:117
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:118
verses.text: ) Jesting renders the soul soft and indolent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:119
verses.text: It excites the soul unduly, and often it teems with acts of violence, and creates wars.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:120
verses.text: But what more? In fine, hast thou not come to be among men? then "put away childish things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:121
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:122
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:123
verses.text: ) Why, thou wilt not allow thine own servant in the market place to speak an impertinent word: and dost thou then, who sayest thou art a servant of God, go uttering thy witticisms in the public square? It is well if the soul that is "sober" be not stolen away; but one that is relaxed and dissolute, who cannot carry off? It will be its own murderer, and will stand in no need of the crafts or assaults of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:124
verses.text: But, moreover, in order to understand this, look too at the very name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:125
verses.text: It means the versatile man, the man of all complexions, the unstable, the pliable, the man that can be anything and everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:126
verses.text: But far is this from those who are servants to the Rock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:127
verses.text: Such a character quickly turns and changes; for he must needs mimic both gesture and speech, and laugh and gait, and everything, aye, and such an one is obliged to invent jokes: for he needs this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:128
verses.text: But far be this from a Christian, to play the buffoon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:129
verses.text: Farther, the man who plays the jester must of necessity incur the signal hatred of the objects of his random ridicule, whether they be present, or being absent hear of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:130
verses.text: If the thing is creditable, why is it left to mountebanks? What, dost thou make thyself a mountebank, and yet art not ashamed? Why is it ye permit not your gentlewomen to do so? Is it not that ye set it down as a mark of an immodest, and not of a discreet character? Great are the evils that dwell in a soul given to jesting; great is the ruin and desolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:131
verses.text: Its consistency is broken, the building is decayed, fear is banished, reverence is gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:132
verses.text: A tongue thou hast, not that thou mayest ridicule another man, but that thou mayest give thanks unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:133
verses.text: Look at your merriment-makers, as they are called, those buffoons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:134
verses.text: These are your jesters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:135
verses.text: Banish from your souls, I entreat you, this graceless accomplishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:136
verses.text: It is the business of parasites, of mountebanks, of dancers, of harlots; far be it from a generous, far be it from a highborn soul, aye, far too even from slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:137
verses.text: If there be any one who has lost respect, if there be any vile person, that man is also a jester.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:138
verses.text: To many indeed the thing appears to be even a virtue, and this truly calls for our sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:139
verses.text: Just as lust by little and little drives headlong into fornication, so also does a turn for jesting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:140
verses.text: It seems to have a grace about it, yet there is nothing more graceless than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:141
verses.text: For hear the Scripture which says, "Before the thunder goeth lightning, and before a shamefaced man shall go favor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:142
verses.text: Now there is nothing more shameless than the jester; so that his mouth is not full of favor, but of pain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:143
verses.text: Let us banish this custom from our tables.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:144
verses.text: Yet are there some who teach it even to the poor! O monstrous! they make men in affliction play the jester.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:145
verses.text: Why, where shall not this pest be found next? Already has it been brought into the Church itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:146
verses.text: Already has it laid hold of the very Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:147
verses.text: Need I say anything to prove the enormity of the evil? I am ashamed indeed, but still nevertheless I will speak; for I am desirous to show to what a length the mischief has advanced, that I may not appear to be trifling, or to be discoursing to you on some trifling subject; that even thus I may be enabled to withdraw you from this delusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:148
verses.text: And let no one think that I am fabricating, but I will tell you what I have really heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:149
verses.text: A certain person happened to be in company with one of those who pride themselves highly on their knowledge (now I know I shall excite a smile, but still I will say it notwithstanding); and when the platter was set before him, he said, "Take and eat, children, lest your belly be angry!" And again, others say, "Woe unto thee, Mammon, and to him that hath thee not;" and many like enormities has jesting introduced; as when they say, "Now is there no nativity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:150
verses.text: And this I say to show the enormity of this base temper; for these are the expressions of a soul destitute of all reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:151
verses.text: And are not these things enough to call down thunderbolts? And one might find many other such things which have been said by these men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:152
verses.text: Wherefore, I entreat you, let us banish the custom universally, and speak those things which become us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:153
verses.text: Let not holy mouths utter the words of dishonorable and base men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:154
verses.text: "For what fellowship have righteousness and iniquity, or what communion hath light with darkness?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:155
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:156
verses.text: ) Happy will it be for us, if, having kept ourselves aloof from all such foul things, we be thus able to attain to the promised blessings; far indeed from dragging such a train after us, and sullying the purity of our minds by so many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:157
verses.text: For the man who will play the jester will soon go on to be a railer, and the railer will go on to heap ten thousand other mischiefs on himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:158
verses.text: When then we shall have disciplined these two faculties of the soul, anger and desire (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:159
verses.text: Plat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:160
verses.text: Phaedr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:161
verses.text: cc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:162
verses.text: , ), and have put them like well-broken horses under the yoke of reason, then let us set over them the mind as charioteer, that we may "gain the prize of our high calling" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:163
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 18:164
verses.text: ); which God grant that we may all attain, through Jesus Christ our Lord, with Whom, together with the Holy Ghost, be unto the Father, glory, might, and honor, now, and ever, and throughout all ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:1
verses.text: Homily XVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:2
verses.text: Ephesians v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:3
verses.text: ,  "For this ye know of a surety, that no fornicator, nor unclean person, nor covetous man, which is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:4
verses.text: Let no man deceive you with empty words: for because of these things cometh the wrath of God upon the sons of disobedience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:5
verses.text: There were, it is likely, in the time of our forefathers also, some who "weakened the hands of the people" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:6
verses.text: xxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:7
verses.text: ), and brought into practice that which is mentioned by Ezekiel,—or rather who did the works of the false prophets, who "profaned God among His people for handfuls of barley" (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:8
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:9
verses.text: ); a thing, by the way, done methinks by some even at this day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:10
verses.text: When, for example, we say that he who calleth his brother a fool shall depart into hell-fire, others say, "What? Is he that calls his brother a fool to depart into hell-fire? Impossible," say they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:11
verses.text: And again, when we say that "the covetous man is an idolater," in this too again they make abatements, and say the expression is hyperbolical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:12
verses.text: And in this manner they underrate and explain away all the commandments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:13
verses.text: It was in allusion then to these that the blessed Paul, at this time when he wrote to the Ephesians, spoke thus, "For this ye know, that no fornicator, nor unclean person, nor covetous man, which is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and God"; adding, "let no man deceive you with empty words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:14
verses.text: Now "empty words" are those which for a while are gratifying, but are in nowise borne out in facts; because the whole case is a deception.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:15
verses.text: "Because of these things cometh the wrath of God upon the sons of disobedience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:16
verses.text: Because of "fornication," he means, because of "covetousness," because of "uncleanness," or both because of these things, and because of the "deceit," inasmuch as there are deceivers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:17
verses.text: "Sons of disobedience"; he thus calls those who are utterly disobedient, those who disobey Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:18
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:20
verses.text: "Be not ye, therefore, partakers with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:21
verses.text: For ye were once darkness, but are now light in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:22
verses.text: Observe how wisely he urges them forward; first, from the thought of Christ, that ye love one another, and do injury to no man; then, on the other hand, from the thought of punishment and hell-fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:23
verses.text: "For ye were once darkness," says he, "but are now light in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:24
verses.text: Which is what he says also in the Epistle to the Romans; "What fruit then had ye at that time in the things whereof ye are now ashamed?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:25
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:26
verses.text: ), and reminds them of their former wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:27
verses.text: That is to say, thinking what ye once were, and what ye are now become, do not run back into your former wickedness, nor do "despite to the grace" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:28
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:29
verses.text: ) of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:30
verses.text: "Ye were once darkness, but are now light in the Lord!"  Not, he says, by your own virtue, but through the grace of God has this accrued to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:31
verses.text: That is to say, ye also were sometime worthy of the same punishments, but now are so no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:32
verses.text: "Walk" therefore "as children of light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:33
verses.text: What is meant however by "children of light," he adds afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:34
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:36
verses.text: "For the fruit of the light is in all goodness and righteousness and truth, proving what is well-pleasing unto the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:37
verses.text: "In all goodness," he says: this is opposed to the angry, and the bitter: "and righteousness"; this to the covetous: "and truth"; this to false pleasure: not those former things, he says, which I was mentioning, but their opposites.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:38
verses.text: "In all"; that is, the fruit of the Spirit ought to be evinced in everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:39
verses.text: "Proving what is well-pleasing unto the Lord"; so that those things are tokens of a childish and imperfect mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:40
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:42
verses.text: "And have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather even reprove them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:43
verses.text: For the things which are done by them in secret it is a shame even to speak of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:44
verses.text: But all things when they are reproved, are made manifest by the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:45
verses.text: He had said, "ye are light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:46
verses.text: Now the light reproves by exposing the things which take place in the darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:47
verses.text: So that if ye, says he, are virtuous, and conspicuous, the wicked will be unable to lie hidden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:48
verses.text: For just as when a candle is set, all are brought to light, and the thief cannot enter; so if your light shine, the wicked being discovered shall be caught.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:49
verses.text: So then it is our duty to expose them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:50
verses.text: How then does our Lord say, "Judge not, that ye be not judged"? (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:51
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:53
verses.text: ) Paul did not say "judge," he said "reprove," that is, correct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:54
verses.text: And the words, "Judge not, that ye be not judged," He spoke with reference to very small errors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:55
verses.text: Indeed, He added, "Why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye?" But what Paul is saying is of this sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:56
verses.text: As a wound, so long as it is imbedded and concealed outwardly, and runs beneath the surface, receives no attention, so also sin, as long as it is concealed, being as it were in darkness, is daringly committed in full security; but as soon as "it is made manifest," becomes "light"; not indeed the sin itself, (for how could that be?) but the sinner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:57
verses.text: For when he has been brought out to light, when he has been admonished, when he has repented, when he has obtained pardon, hast thou not cleared away all his darkness? Hast thou not then healed his wound? Hast thou not called his unfruitfulness into fruit? Either this is his meaning, or else what I said above, that your life "being manifest, is light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:58
verses.text: For no one hides an irreproachable life; whereas things which are hidden, are hidden by darkness covering them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:59
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:60
verses.text: "Wherefore he saith, Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall shine upon thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:61
verses.text: By the "sleeper" and the "dead," he means the man that is in sin; for he both exhales noisome odors like the dead, and is inactive like one that is asleep, and like him he sees nothing, but is dreaming, and forming fancies and illusions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:62
verses.text: Some indeed read, "And thou shalt touch Christ"; but others, "And Christ shall shine upon thee"; and it is rather this latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:63
verses.text: Depart from sin, and thou shalt be able to behold Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:64
verses.text: "For every one that doeth ill, hateth the light, and cometh not to the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:65
verses.text: (John iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:66
verses.text: ) He therefore that doeth it not, cometh to the light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:67
verses.text: Now he is not saying this with reference to the unbelievers only, for many of the faithful, no less than unbelievers, hold fast by wickedness; nay, some far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:68
verses.text: Therefore to these also it is necessary to exclaim, "Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall shine upon thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:69
verses.text: To these it is fitting to say this also, "God is not the God of the dead, but of the living".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:70
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:71
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:72
verses.text: ) If then he is not the God of the dead, let us live.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:73
verses.text: Now there are some who say that the words, "the covetous man is an idolater," are hyperbolical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:74
verses.text: However, the statement is not hyperbolical, it is true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:75
verses.text: How, and in what way? Because the covetous man apostatizes from God, just as the idolater does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:76
verses.text: And lest you should imagine this is a bare assertion, there is a declaration of Christ which saith, "Ye cannot serve God and Mammon".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:77
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:78
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:79
verses.text: ) If then it is not possible to serve God and Mammon, they who serve Mammon have thrown themselves out of the service of God; and they who have denied His sovereignty, and serve lifeless gold, it is plain enough that they are idolaters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:80
verses.text: "But I never made an idol," a man will say, "nor set up an altar, nor sacrificed sheep, nor poured libations of wine; no, I came into the church, and lifted up my hands to the Only-begotten Son of God; I partake of the mysteries, I communicate in prayer, and in everything else which is a Christian's duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:81
verses.text: How then," he will say, "am I a worshiper of idols?" Yes, and this is the very thing which is the most astonishing of all, that when thou hast had experience, and hast "tasted" the lovingkindness of God, and "hast seen that the Lord is gracious" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:82
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:83
verses.text: ), thou shouldest abandon Him who is gracious, and take to thyself a cruel tyrant, and shouldest pretend to be serving Him, whilst in reality thou hast submitted thyself to the hard and galling yoke of covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:84
verses.text: Thou hast not yet told me of thy own duty done, but only of thy Master's gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:85
verses.text: For tell me, I beseech thee, whence do we judge of a soldier? Is it when he is on duty guarding the king, and is fed by him, and called the king's own, or is it when he is minding his own affairs and interests? To pretend to be with him, and to be attentive to his interests, whilst he is advancing the cause of the enemy, we declare to be worse than if he breaks away from the king's service, and joins the enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:86
verses.text: Now then thou art doing despite to God, just as an idolater does, not with thine own mouth singly, but with the ten thousands of those whom thou hast wronged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:87
verses.text: Yet you will say, "an idolater he is not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:88
verses.text: But surely, whenever they say, "Oh! that Christian, that covetous fellow," then not only is he himself committing outrage by his own act, but he frequently forces those also whom he has wronged to use these words; and if they use them not, this is to be set to the account of their reverence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:89
verses.text: Do we not see that such is the fact? What else is an idolater? Or does not he too worship passions, oftentimes not mastering his passions? I mean, for example, when we say that the pagan idolater worships idols, he will say, "No, but it is Venus, or it is Mars".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:90
verses.text: And if we say, Who is this Venus? the more modest amongst them will say, It is pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:91
verses.text: Or what is this Mars? It is wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:92
verses.text: And in the same way dost thou worship Mammon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:93
verses.text: If we say, Who is this Mammon? It is covetousness, and this thou art worshiping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:94
verses.text: "I worship it not," thou wilt say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:95
verses.text: Why not? Because thou dost not bow thyself down? Nay, but as it is, thou art far more a worshiper in thy deeds and practices; for this is the higher kind of worship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:96
verses.text: And that you may understand this, look in the case of God; who more truly worship Him, they who merely stand up at the prayers, or they who do His will? Clearly enough, these latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:97
verses.text: The same also is it with the worshipers of Mammon; they who do his will, they truly are his worshipers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:98
verses.text: However, they who worship the passions are oftentimes free from the passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:99
verses.text: One may see a worshiper of Mars oftentimes governing his wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:100
verses.text: But this is not true of thee; thou makest thyself a slave to thy passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:101
verses.text: Yes, but thou slayest no sheep? No, thou slayest men, reasonable souls, some by famine, others by blasphemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:102
verses.text: Nothing can be more frenzied than a sacrifice like this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:103
verses.text: Who ever beheld souls sacrificed? How accursed is the altar of covetousness! When thou passest by this idol's altar here, thou shalt see it reeking with the blood of bullocks and goats; but when thou shalt pass by the altar of covetousness, thou shalt see it breathing the shocking odor of human blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:104
verses.text: Stand here before it in this world, and thou shalt see, not the wings of birds burning, no vapor, no smoke exhaled, but the bodies of men perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:105
verses.text: For some throw themselves among precipices, others tie the halter, others thrust the dagger through their throat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:106
verses.text: Hast thou seen the cruel and inhuman sacrifices? Wouldest thou see yet more shocking ones than these? Then I will show thee no longer the bodies of men, but the souls of men slaughtered in the other world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:107
verses.text: Yes, for it is possible for a soul to be slain with the slaughter peculiar to the soul; for as there is a death of the body, so is there also of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:108
verses.text: "The soul that sinneth," saith the Prophet, "it shall die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:109
verses.text: (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:110
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:111
verses.text: ) The death of the soul, however, is not like the death of the body; it is far more shocking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:112
verses.text: For this bodily death, separating the soul and the body the one from the other, releases the one from many anxieties and toils, and transmits the other into a manifest abode: then when the body has been in time dissolved and crumbled away, it is again gathered together in incorruption, and receives back its own proper soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:113
verses.text: Such we see is this bodily death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:114
verses.text: But that of the soul is awful and terrific.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:115
verses.text: For this death, when dissolution takes place, does not let it pass, as the body does, but binds it down again to an imperishable body, and consigns it to the unquenchable fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:116
verses.text: This then is the death of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:117
verses.text: And as therefore there is a death of the soul, so is there also a slaughter of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:118
verses.text: What is the slaughter of the body? It is the being turned into a corpse, the being stripped of the energy derived from the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:119
verses.text: What is the slaughter of the soul? It is its being made a corpse also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:120
verses.text: And how is the soul made a corpse? Because as the body then becomes a corpse when the soul leaves it destitute of its own vital energy, so also does the soul then become a corpse, when the Holy Spirit leaves it destitute of His spiritual energy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:121
verses.text: Such for the most part are the slaughters made at the altar of covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:122
verses.text: They are not satisfied, they do not stop at men's blood; no, the altar of covetousness is not glutted, unless it sacrifice the very soul itself also, unless it receive the souls of both, the sacrificer and the sacrificed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:123
verses.text: For he who sacrifices must first be sacrificed, and then he sacrifices; and the dead sacrifices him who is yet living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:124
verses.text: For when he utters blasphemies, when he reviles, when he is irritated, are not these so many incurable wounds of the soul?  Thou hast seen that the expression is no hyperbole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:125
verses.text: Wouldest thou hear again another argument, to teach you how covetousness is idolatry, and more shocking than idolatry? Idolaters worship the creatures of God ("for they worshiped," it is said, "and served the creature rather than the Creator") (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:126
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:127
verses.text: ); but thou art worshiping a creature of thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:128
verses.text: For God made not covetousness but thine own insatiable appetite invented it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:129
verses.text: And look at the madness and folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:130
verses.text: They that worship idols, honor also the idols they worship; and if any one speak of them with disrespect or ridicule, they stand up in their defense; whereas thou, as if in a sort of intoxication, art worshiping an object, which is so far from being free from accusation, that it is even full of impiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:131
verses.text: So that thou, even more than they, excellest in wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:132
verses.text: Thou canst never have it to say as an excuse, that it is no evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:133
verses.text: If even they are in the highest degree without excuse, yet art thou in a far higher, who art forever censuring covetousness, and reviling those who devote themselves to it, and who yet doth serve and obey it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:134
verses.text: We will examine, if you please, whence idolatry took its rise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:135
verses.text: A certain wise man (Wisd.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:136
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:137
verses.text: ) tells us, that a certain rich man afflicted with untimely mourning for his son, and having no consolation for his sorrow, consoled his passion in this way: having made a lifeless image of the dead, and constantly gazing at it, he seemed through the image to have his departed one still; whilst certain flatterers, "whose God was their belly" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:138
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:139
verses.text: ), treating the image with reverence in order to do him honor, carried on the custom into idolatry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:140
verses.text: So then it took its rise from weakness of soul, from a senseless custom, from extravagance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:141
verses.text: But not so covetousness: from weakness of soul indeed it is, only that it is from a worse weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:142
verses.text: It is not that any one has lost a son, nor that he is seeking for consolation in sorrow, nor that he is drawn on by flatterers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:143
verses.text: But how is it? I will tell you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:144
verses.text: Cain in covetousness overreached God; what ought to have been given to Him, he kept to himself; what he should have kept himself, this he offered to Him; and thus the evil began even from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:145
verses.text: For if we are God's, much more are the first-fruits of our possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:146
verses.text: Again, men's violent passion for women arose from covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:147
verses.text: "They saw the daughters of men" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:148
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:149
verses.text: ), and they rushed headlong into lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:150
verses.text: And from hence again it went on to money; for the wish to have more than one's neighbor of this world's goods, arises from no other source, than from "love waxing cold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:151
verses.text: The wish to have more than one's share arises from no other source than recklessness, misanthropy, and arrogance toward others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:152
verses.text: Look at the earth, how wide is its extent? How far greater than we can use the expanse of the sky and the heaven? It is that He might put an end to thy covetousness, that God hath thus widely extended the bounds of the creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:153
verses.text: And art thou then still grasping and even thus? And dost thou hear that covetousness is idolatry, and not shudder even at this? Dost thou wish to inherit the earth? Then hast thou no inheritance in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:154
verses.text: Art thou eager to leave an inheritance to others, that thou mayest rob thyself of it? Tell me, if any one were to offer thee power to possess all things, wouldest thou be unwilling? It is in thy power now, if thou wilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:155
verses.text: Some, however, say, that they are grieved when they transmit the inheritance to others, and would fain have consumed it themselves, rather than see others become its masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:156
verses.text: Nor do I acquit thee of this weakness; for this too is characteristic of a weak soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:157
verses.text: However, at least let as much as this be done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:158
verses.text: In thy will leave Christ thine heir.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:159
verses.text: It were thy duty indeed to do so in thy lifetime, for this would show a right disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:160
verses.text: Still, at all events, be a little generous, though it be but by necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:161
verses.text: For Christ indeed charged us to give to the poor with this object, to make us wise in our lifetime, to induce us to despise money, to teach us to look down upon earthly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:162
verses.text: It is no contempt of money, as you think, to bestow it upon this man and upon that man when one dies, and is no longer master of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:163
verses.text: Thou art then no longer giving of thine own, but of absolute necessity: thanks to death, not to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:164
verses.text: This is no act of affection, it is thy loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:165
verses.text: However, let it be done even thus; at least then give up thy passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:166
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:167
verses.text: Consider how many acts of plunder, how many acts of covetousness, thou hast committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:168
verses.text: Restore all fourfold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:169
verses.text: Thus plead thy cause to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:170
verses.text: Some, however, there are who are arrived at such a pitch of madness and blindness, as not even then to comprehend their duty; but who go on acting in all cases, just as if they were taking pains to make the judgment of God yet heavier to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:171
verses.text: This is the reason why our blessed Apostle writes and says, "Walk as children of light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:172
verses.text: Now the covetous man of all others lives in darkness, and spreads great darkness over all things around.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:173
verses.text: "And have no fellowship," he adds, "with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather even reprove them; for the things which are done by them in secret, it is a shame even to speak of; but all things when they are reproved are made manifest by the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:174
verses.text: Hearken, I entreat you, all, as many of you as like not to be hated for nothing, but to be loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:175
verses.text: "What need is there to be hated?" one says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:176
verses.text: A man commits a robbery, and dost thou not reprove him, but art afraid of his hatred? though this, however, is not being hated for nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:177
verses.text: But dost thou justly convict him, and yet fear the hatred? Convict thy brother, incur enmity for the love's sake which thou owest to Christ, for the love's sake which thou owest to thy brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:178
verses.text: Arrest him as he is on his road to the pit of destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:179
verses.text: For to admit him to our table, to treat him with civil speeches, with salutations, and with entertainments, these are no signal proofs of friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:180
verses.text: No, those I have mentioned are the boons which we must bestow upon our friends, that we may rescue their souls from the wrath of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:181
verses.text: When we see them lying prostrate in the furnace of wickedness, let us raise them up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:182
verses.text: "But," they say, "it is of no use, he is incorrigible".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:183
verses.text: However, do thou thy duty, and then thou hast excused thyself to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:184
verses.text: Hide not thy talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:185
verses.text: It is for this that thou hast speech, it is for this thou hast a mouth and a tongue, that thou mayest correct thy neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:186
verses.text: It is dumb and reasonless creatures only that have no care for their neighbor, and take no account of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:187
verses.text: But dost thou while calling God, "Father," and thy neighbor, "brother," when thou seest him committing unnumbered wickednesses, dost thou prefer his good-will to his welfare? No, do not so, I entreat you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:188
verses.text: There is no evidence of friendship so true as never to overlook the sins of our brethren.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:189
verses.text: Didst thou see them at enmity? Reconcile them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:190
verses.text: Didst thou see them guilty of covetousness? Check them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:191
verses.text: Didst thou see them wronged? Stand up in their defense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:192
verses.text: It is not on them, it is on thyself thou art conferring the chief benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:193
verses.text: It is for this we are friends, that we may be of use one to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:194
verses.text: A man will listen in a different spirit to a friend, and to any other chance person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:195
verses.text: A chance person he will regard perhaps with suspicion, and so in like manner will he a teacher, but not so a friend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:196
verses.text: "For," he says, "the things which are done by them in secret it is a shame even to speak of: but all things when they are reproved are made manifest by the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:197
verses.text: What is it he means to say here? He means this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:198
verses.text: That some sins in this world are done in secret, and some also openly; but in the other it shall not be so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:199
verses.text: Now there is no one who is not conscious to himself of some sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:200
verses.text: This is why he says, "But all the things when they are reproved are made manifest by the light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:201
verses.text: What then? Is this again, it will be said, meant concerning idolatry? It is not; the argument is about our life and our sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:202
verses.text: "For everything that is made manifest," says he, "is light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:203
verses.text: Wherefore, I entreat you, be ye never backward to reprove, nor displeased at being reproved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:204
verses.text: For as long indeed as anything is carried on in the dark, it is carried on with greater security; but when it has many to witness what is done, it is brought to light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:205
verses.text: By all means then let us do all we can to chase away the deadness which is in our brethren, to scatter the darkness, and to attract to us the "Sun of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:206
verses.text: For if there be many shining lights, the path of virtue will be easy to themselves, and they which are in darkness will be more easily detected, while the light is held forth and puts the darkness to flight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:207
verses.text: Whereas if it be the reverse, there is fear lest as the thick mist of darkness and of sin overpowers the light, and dispels its transparency, those shining lights themselves should be extinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 19:208
verses.text: Let us be then disposed to benefit one another, that one and all, we may offer up praise and glory to the God of lovingkindness, by the grace and lovingkindness of the only begotten Son with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, strength, honor now and forever and forever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:1
verses.text: Homily XIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:2
verses.text: Ephesians v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:3
verses.text: , ,  "Look then carefully how ye walk, not as unwise, but as wise; redeeming the time, because the days are evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:4
verses.text: Wherefore be ye not foolish, but understand what the will of the Lord is".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:5
verses.text: He is still cleansing away the root of bitterness, still cutting off the very groundwork of anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:6
verses.text: For what is he saying? "Look carefully how ye walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:7
verses.text: "They are sheep in the midst of wolves," and he charges them to be also "as doves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:8
verses.text: For "ye shall be harmless," saith he, "as doves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:9
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:10
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:11
verses.text: ) Forasmuch then as they were both amongst wolves, and were besides commanded not to defend themselves, but to suffer evil, they needed this admonition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:12
