verses.text: Not indeed but that the former was sufficient to render them stronger; but now that there is besides the addition of the two, reflect how exceedingly it is heightened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:13
verses.text: Observe then here also, how carefully he secures them, by saying, "Look how ye walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:14
verses.text: Whole cities were at war with them; yea, this war made its way also into houses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:15
verses.text: They were divided, father against son, and son against father, mother against daughter, and daughter against mother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:16
verses.text: What then? Whence these divisions? They heard Christ say, "He that loveth father or mother more than me, is not worthy of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:17
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:18
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:19
verses.text: ) Lest therefore they should think that he was without reason introducing wars and fightings, (since there was likely to be much anger produced, if they on their part were to retaliate,) to prevent this, he says, "See carefully how ye walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:20
verses.text: That is to say, "Except the Gospel message, give no other handle on any score whatever, for the hatred which you will incur".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:21
verses.text: Let this be the only ground of hatred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:22
verses.text: Let no one have any other charge to make against you; but show all deference and obedience, whenever it does no harm to the message, whenever it does not stand in the way of godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:23
verses.text: For it is said, "Render to all their dues, tribute to whom tribute, custom to whom custom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:24
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:25
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:26
verses.text: ) For when amongst the rest of the world they shall see us forbearing, they will be put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:27
verses.text: "Not as unwise, but as wise, redeeming the time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:28
verses.text: It is not from any wish that you should be artful, and versatile, that he gives this advice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:29
verses.text: But what he means is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:30
verses.text: The time is not yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:31
verses.text: At present ye are strangers, and sojourners, and foreigners, and aliens; seek not honors, seek not glory, seek not authority, nor revenge; bear all things, and in this way, "redeem the time"; give up many things, anything they may require.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:32
verses.text: Imagine now, I say, a man had a magnificent house, and persons were to make their way in, on purpose to murder him, and he were to give a large sum, and thus to rescue himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:33
verses.text: Then we should say, he has redeemed himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:34
verses.text: So also hast thou a large house, and a true faith in thy keeping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:35
verses.text: They will come to take all away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:36
verses.text: Give whatever they may demand, only preserve the principal thing, I mean the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:37
verses.text: "Because the days," saith he, "are evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:38
verses.text: What is the evil of the day? The evil of the day ought to belong to the day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:39
verses.text: What is the evil of a body? Disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:40
verses.text: And what again the evil of the soul? Wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:41
verses.text: What is the evil of water? Bitterness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:42
verses.text: And the evil of each particular thing, is with reference to that nature of it which is affected by the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:43
verses.text: If then there is an evil in the day, it ought to belong to the day, to the hours, to the day-light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:44
verses.text: So also Christ saith, "Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:45
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:46
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:47
verses.text: ) And from this expression we shall understand the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:48
verses.text: In what sense then does he call "the days evil"? In what sense the "time" evil? It is not the essence of the thing, not the things as so created, but it is the things transacted in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:49
verses.text: In the same way as we are in the habit of saying, "I have passed a disagreeable and wretched day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:50
verses.text: And yet how could it be disagreeable, except from the circumstances which took place in it? Now the events which take place in it are, good things from God, but evil things from bad men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:51
verses.text: So then of the evils which happen in the times, men are the creators, and hence it is that the times are said to be evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:52
verses.text: And thus we also call the times evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:53
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:55
verses.text: "Wherefore," he adds, "be ye not foolish, but understand what the will of the Lord is; and be not drunk with wine, wherein is riot".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:56
verses.text: For indeed intemperance in this renders men passionate and violent, and hot-headed, and irritable and savage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:57
verses.text: Wine has been given us for cheerfulness, not for drunkenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:58
verses.text: Whereas now it appears to be an unmanly and contemptible thing for a man not to get drunk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:59
verses.text: And what sort of hope then is there of salvation? What? contemptible, tell me, not to get drunk, where to get drunk ought of all things in the world to be most contemptible? For it is of all things right for even a private individual to keep himself far from drunkenness; but how much more so for a soldier, a man who lives amongst swords, and bloodshed, and slaughter: much more, I say, for the soldier, when his temper is sharpened by other causes also, by power, by authority, by being constantly in the midst of stratagems and battles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:60
verses.text: Wouldest thou know where wine is good? Hear what the Scripture saith, "Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto the bitter in soul".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:61
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:62
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:63
verses.text: ) And justly, because it can mitigate asperity and gloominess, and drive away clouds from the brow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:64
verses.text: "Wine maketh glad the heart of man" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:65
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:66
verses.text: ), says the Psalmist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:67
verses.text: How then does wine produce drunkenness? For it cannot be that one and the same thing should work opposite effects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:68
verses.text: Drunkenness then surely does not arise from wine, but from intemperance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:69
verses.text: Wine is bestowed upon us for no other purpose than for bodily health; but this purpose also is thwarted by immoderate use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:70
verses.text: But hear moreover what our blessed Apostle writes and says to Timothy, "Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake, and thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:71
verses.text: This is the reason why God has formed our bodies in moderate proportions, and so as to be satisfied with a little, from thence at once instructing us that He has made us adapted to another life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:72
verses.text: And that life He would fain have bestowed upon us even from the very beginning; but since we rendered ourselves unworthy of it, He deferred it; and in the time during which He deferred it, not even in that does He allow us immoderate indulgence; for a little cup of wine and a single loaf is enough to satisfy a man's hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:73
verses.text: And man the lord of all the brute creation has He formed so as to require less food in proportion than they, and his body small; thereby declaring to us nothing else than this, that we are hastening onward to another life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:74
verses.text: "Be not drunk," says he, "with wine, wherein is riot"; for it does not save but it destroys; and that, not the body only, but the soul also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:77
verses.text: "But be filled with the Spirit; speaking one to another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody with your heart to the Lord; giving thanks always for all things in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to God even the Father; subjecting yourselves one to another in the fear of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:78
verses.text: Dost thou wish, he says, to be cheerful, dost thou wish to employ the day? I give thee spiritual drink; for drunkenness even cuts off the articulate sound of our tongue; it makes us lisp and stammer, and distorts the eyes, and the whole frame together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:79
verses.text: Learn to sing psalms, and thou shalt see the delightfulness of the employment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:80
verses.text: For they who sing psalms are filled with the Holy Spirit, as they who sing satanic songs are filled with an unclean spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:81
verses.text: What is meant by "with your hearts to the Lord"? It means, with close attention and understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:82
verses.text: For they who do not attend closely, merely sing, uttering the words, whilst their heart is roaming elsewhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:83
verses.text: "Always," he says, "giving thanks for all things in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ unto God even the Father, subjecting yourselves one to another in the fear of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:84
verses.text: That is, "let your requests be made known unto God, with thanksgiving" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:85
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:86
verses.text: ); for there is nothing so pleasing to God, as for a man to be thankful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:87
verses.text: But we shall be best able to give thanks unto God, by withdrawing our souls from the things before mentioned, and by thoroughly cleansing them by the means he has told us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:88
verses.text: "But be filled," says he, "with the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:89
verses.text: And is then this Spirit within us? Yes, indeed, within us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:90
verses.text: For when we have driven away lying, and bitterness, and fornication, and uncleanness, and covetousness, from our souls, when we are become kind, tender-hearted, forgiving one another, when there is no jesting, when we have rendered ourselves worthy of it, what is there to hinder the Holy Spirit from coming and lighting upon us? And not only will He come unto us, but He will fill our hearts; and when we have so great a light kindled within us, then will the way of virtue be no longer difficult to attain, but will be easy and simple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:91
verses.text: "Giving thanks always," he says, "for all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:92
verses.text: What then? Are we to give thanks for everything that befalls us? Yes; be it even disease, be it even penury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:93
verses.text: For if a certain wise man gave this advice in the Old Testament, and said, "Whatsoever is brought upon thee take cheerfully, and be patient when thou art changed to a low estate" (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:94
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:95
verses.text: ); much more ought this to be the case in the New.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:96
verses.text: Yes, even though thou know not the word, give thanks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:97
verses.text: For this is thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:98
verses.text: But if thou give thanks when thou art in comfort and in affluence, in success and in prosperity, there is nothing great, nothing wonderful in that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:99
verses.text: What is required is, for a man to give thanks when he is in afflictions, in anguish, in discouragements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:100
verses.text: Utter no word in preference to this, "Lord, I thank thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:101
verses.text: And why do I speak of the afflictions of this world? It is our duty to give God thanks, even for hell itself, for the torments and punishments of the next world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:102
verses.text: For surely it is a thing beneficial to those who attend to it, when the dread of hell is laid like a bridle on our hearts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:103
verses.text: Let us therefore give thanks not only for blessings which we see, but also for those which we see not, and for those which we receive against our will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:104
verses.text: For many are the blessings He bestows upon us, without our desire, without our knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:105
verses.text: And if ye believe me not, I will at once proceed to make the case clear to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:106
verses.text: For consider, I pray, do not the impious and unbelieving Gentiles ascribe everything to the sun and to their idols? But what then? Doth He not bestow blessings even upon them? Is it not the work of His providence, that they both have life, and health, and children, and the like? And again they that are called Marcionites, and the Manichees, do they not even blaspheme Him? But what then? Does He not bestow blessings on them every day? Now if He bestows blessings on them that know them not, much more does he bestow them upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:107
verses.text: For what else is the peculiar work of God if it be not this, to do good to all mankind, alike by chastisements and by enjoyments? Let us not then give thanks only when we are in prosperity, for there is nothing great in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:108
verses.text: And this the devil also well knows, and therefore he said, "Doth Job fear God for nought? Hast Thou not made an hedge about him and about all that he hath on every side? Touch all that he hath; no doubt, he will renounce Thee to Thy face!" (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:110
verses.text: ) However, that cursed one gained no advantage; and God forbid he should gain any advantage of us either; but whenever we are either in penury, or in sicknesses, or in disasters, then let us increase our thanksgiving; thanksgiving, I mean, not in words, nor in tongue, but in deeds and works, in mind and in heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:111
verses.text: Let us give thanks unto Him with all our souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:112
verses.text: For He loves us more than our parents; and wide as is the difference between evil and goodness, so great is the difference between the love of God and that of our fathers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:113
verses.text: And these are not my words, but those of Christ Himself Who loveth us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:114
verses.text: And hear what He Himself saith, "What man is there of you, who, if his son shall ask him for a loaf, will give him a stone? If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your Father which is in Heaven give good things to them that ask Him?" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:115
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:117
verses.text: ) And again, bear what He saith also elsewhere: "Can a woman forget her sucking child that she should not have compassion on the son of her womb? Yea, they may forget, yet will not I forget thee, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:118
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:119
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:120
verses.text: ) For if He loveth us not, wherefore did He create us? Had He any necessity? Do we supply to Him any ministry and service? Needeth He anything that we can render? Hear what the Prophet says; "I have said unto the Lord, Thou art my Lord, I have no good beyond Thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:121
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:122
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:123
verses.text: )  The ungrateful, however, and unfeeling say, that this were worthy of God's goodness, that there should be an equality amongst all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:124
verses.text: Tell me, ungrateful mortal, what sort of things are they which thou deniest to be of God's goodness, and what equality meanest thou? "Such an one," thou wilt say, "has been a cripple from his childhood; another is mad, and is possessed; another has arrived at extreme old age, and has spent his whole life in poverty; another in the most painful diseases: are these works of Providence? One man is deaf, another dumb, another poor, whilst another, impious, yea, utterly impious, and full of ten thousand vices, enjoys wealth, and keeps concubines, and parasites, and is owner of a splendid mansion, and lives an idle life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:125
verses.text: And many instances of the sort they string together, and weave a long account of complaint against the providence of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:126
verses.text: What then are we to say to them? Now if they were Greeks, and were to tell us that the universe is governed by some one or other, we should in turn address to them the self-same words, "What then, are things without a providence? How then is it that ye reverence gods, and worship genii and heroes? For if there is a providence, some one or other superintends the whole".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:127
verses.text: But if any, whether Christians or Heathen, should be impatient at this, and be wavering, what shall we say to them? "Why, could so many good things, tell me, arise of themselves? The daily light? The beautiful order and the forethought that exist in all things? The mazy dances of the stars? The equable course of nights and days? The regular gradation of nature in vegetables, and animals, and men? Who, tell me, is it that ordereth these? If there were no superintending Being, but all things combined together of themselves, who then was it that made this vault revolve, so beautiful, so vast, I mean the sky, and set it upon the earth, nay more, upon the waters? Who is it that gives the fruitful seasons? Who implanted so great power in seeds and vegetables? For that which is accidental is necessarily disorderly; whereas that which is orderly implies design.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:128
verses.text: For which, tell me, of the things around us that are accidental, is not full of great disorder, and of great tumult and confusion? Nor do I speak of things accidental only, but of those also which imply some agent, but an unskillful agent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:129
verses.text: For example, let there be timber and stone, and let there be lime withal; and let a man unskilled in building take them, and begin building, and set hard to work; will he not spoil and destroy everything? Again, take a vessel without a pilot, containing everything which a vessel ought to contain, without a shipwright; I do not say that it is unequipped and unfinished, but though well equipped, it will not be able to sail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:130
verses.text: And could the vast extent of earth standing on the waters, tell me, ever stand so firmly, and so long a time, without some power to hold it together? And can these views have any reason? Is it not the extreme of absurdity to conceive such a notion? And if the earth supports the heaven, behold another burden still; but if the heaven also is borne upon the waters, there arises again another question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:131
verses.text: Or rather not another question, for it is the work of providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:132
verses.text: For things which are borne upon the water ought not to be made convex, but concave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:133
verses.text: Wherefore? Because the whole body of anything which is concave is immersed in the waters, as is the case with a ship; whereas of the convex the body is entirely above, and only the rim rests upon the surface; so that it requires a resisting body, hard, and able to sustain it, in order to bear the burden imposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:134
verses.text: But does the atmosphere then support the heaven? Why, that is far softer, and more yielding even than water, and cannot sustain anything, no, not the very lightest things, much less so vast a bulk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:135
verses.text: In fine, if we chose to follow out the argument of providence, both generally and in detail, time itself would fail us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:136
verses.text: For I will now ask him who would start those questions above mentioned, are these things the result of providence, or of the want of providence? And if he shall say, that they are not from providence, then again I will ask, how then did they arise? But no, he will never be able to give any account at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:137
verses.text: And dost thou not know that?  Much more then is it thy duty not to question, not to be over curious, in those things which concern man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:138
verses.text: And why not? Because man is nobler than all these, and these were made for his sake, not he for their sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:139
verses.text: If then thou knowest not so much as the skill and contrivance that are visible in His providence, how shalt thou be able to know the reasons, where he himself is the subject? Tell me, I pray, why did God form him so small, so far below the height of heaven, as that he should even doubt of the things which appear above him? Why are the northern and southern climes uninhabitable? Tell me, I say, why is the night made longer in winter and shorter in summer? Why are the degrees of cold and heat such as they are? Why is the body mortal? And ten thousand questions besides I will ask thee, and if thou wilt, will never cease asking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:140
verses.text: And in one and all thou wilt surely be at a loss to answer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:141
verses.text: And thus is this of all things most providential, that the reasons of things are kept secret from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:142
verses.text: For surely, one would have imagined man to be the cause of all things, were there not this to humble our understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:143
verses.text: "But such an one," you will say, "is poor, and poverty is an evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:144
verses.text: And what is it to be sick, and what is it to be crippled?" Oh, man, they are nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:145
verses.text: One thing alone is evil, that is to sin; this is the only thing we ought to search to the bottom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:146
verses.text: And yet we omit to search into the causes of what are really evils, and busy ourselves about other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:147
verses.text: Why is it that not one of us ever examines why he has sinned? To sin,—is it then in my power, or is it not in my power? And why need I go round about me for a number of reasons? I will seek for the matter within myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:148
verses.text: Now then did I ever master my wrath? Did I ever master my anger, either through shame, or through fear of man? Then whenever I discover this done, I shall discover that to sin is in my own power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:149
verses.text: No one examines these matters, no one busies himself about them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:150
verses.text: But only according to Job, "Man in a way altogether different swims upon words".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:151
verses.text: For why does it concern thee, if such an one is blind, or such an one poor? God hath not commanded thee to look to this, but to what thou thyself art doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:152
verses.text: For if on the one hand thou doubtest that there is any power superintending the world, thou art of all men the most senseless; but if thou art persuaded of this, why doubt that it is our duty to please God?  "Giving thanks always," he says, "for all things to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:153
verses.text: Go to the physician's, and thou wilt see him, whenever a man is discovered to have a wound, using the knife and the cautery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:154
verses.text: But no, in thy case, I say not so much as this; but go to the carpenter's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:155
verses.text: And yet thou dost not examine his reasons, although thou understandest not one of the things which are done there, and many things will appear to thee to be difficulties; as, for instance, when he hollows the wood, when he alters its outward shape.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:156
verses.text: Nay, I would bring thee to a more intelligible craft still, for instance, that of the painter, and there thy head will swim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:157
verses.text: For tell me, does he not seem to be doing what he does, at random? For what do his lines mean, and the turns and bends of the lines? But when he puts on the colors, then the beauty of the art will become conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:158
verses.text: Yet still, not even then wilt thou be able to attain to any accurate understanding of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:159
verses.text: But why do I speak of carpenters, and painters, our fellow-servants? Tell me, how does the bee frame her comb, and then shalt thou speak about God also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:160
verses.text: Master the handiwork of the ant, the spider, and the swallow, and then shalt thou speak about God also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:161
verses.text: Tell me these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:162
verses.text: But no, thou never canst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:163
verses.text: Wilt thou not cease then, O man, thy vain enquiries? For vain indeed they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:164
verses.text: Wilt thou not cease busying thyself in vain about many things? Nothing so wise as this ignorance, where they that profess they know nothing are wisest of all, and they that spend overmuch labor on these questions, the most foolish of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:165
verses.text: So that to profess knowledge is not everywhere a sign of wisdom, but sometimes of folly also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:166
verses.text: For tell me, suppose there were two men, and one of them should profess to stretch out his lines, and to measure the expanse that intervenes between the earth and heaven, and the other were to laugh at him, and declare that he did not understand it, tell me, I pray, which should we laugh at, him that said he knew, or him that knew not? Evidently, the man that said that he knew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:167
verses.text: He that is ignorant, therefore, is wiser than he that professes to know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:168
verses.text: And what again? If any one were to profess to tell us how many cups of water the sea contains, and another should profess his ignorance, is not the ignorance here again wiser than the knowledge? Surely, vastly so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:169
verses.text: And why so? Because that knowledge itself is but intense ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:170
verses.text: For he indeed who says that he is ignorant, knows something.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:171
verses.text: And what is that? That it is incomprehensible to man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:172
verses.text: Yes, and this is no small portion of knowledge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:173
verses.text: Whereas he that says he knows, he of all others knows not what he says he knows, and is for this very reason utterly ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:174
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:175
verses.text: Alas! how many things are there to teach us to bridle this unseasonable impertinence and idle curiosity; and yet we refrain not, but are curious about the lives of others; as, why one is a cripple, and why another is poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:176
verses.text: And so by this way of reasoning we shall fall into another sort of trifling which is endless, as, why such an one is a woman? and, why all are not men? why there is such a thing as an ass? why an ox? why a dog? why a wolf? why a stone? why wood? and thus the argument will run out to an interminable length.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:177
verses.text: This in truth is the reason, why God has marked out limits to our knowledge, and has laid them deep in nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:178
verses.text: And mark, now, the excess of this busy curiosity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:179
verses.text: For though we look up to so great a height as from earth to heaven, and are not at all affected by it; yet as soon as ever we go up to the top of a lofty tower, and have a mind to stoop over a little, and look down, a sort of giddiness and dizziness immediately seizes us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:180
verses.text: Now, tell me the reason of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:181
verses.text: No, thou couldest never find out a reason for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:182
verses.text: Why is it that the eye possesses greater power than other senses, and is caught by more distant objects? And one might see it by comparison with the case of hearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:183
verses.text: For no one will ever be able to shout so loudly, as to fill the air as far as the eye can reach, nor to hear at so great a distance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:184
verses.text: Why are not all the members of equal honor? Why have not all received one function and one place? Paul also searched into these questions; or rather he did not search into them, for he was wise; but where he comes by chance upon this topic, he says, "Each one of them, hath God set even as it hath pleased Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:185
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:186
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:187
verses.text: ) He assigns the whole to His will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:188
verses.text: And so then let us only "give thanks for all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:189
verses.text: "Wherefore," says he, "give thanks for all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:190
verses.text: This is the part of a well-disposed, of a wise, of an intelligent servant; the opposite is that of a tattler, and an idler, and a busy-body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:191
verses.text: Do we not see amongst servants, that those among them who are worthless and good for nothing, are both tattlers, and triflers and that they pry into the concerns of their masters, which they are desirous to conceal: whereas the intelligent and well-disposed look to one thing only, how they may fulfill their service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:192
verses.text: He that says much, does nothing: as he that does much, never says a word out of season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:193
verses.text: Hence Paul said, where he wrote concerning widows, "And they learn not only to be idle, but tattlers also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:194
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:195
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:196
verses.text: ) Tell me, now, which is the widest difference, between our age and that of children, or between God and men? between ourselves compared with gnats, or God compared with us? Plainly between God and us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:197
verses.text: Why then dost thou busy thyself to such an extent in all these questions? "Give thanks for all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:198
verses.text: "But what," say you, "if a heathen should ask the question? How am I to answer him? He desires to learn from me whether there is a Providence, for he himself denies that there is any being thus exercising foresight".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:199
verses.text: Turn round then, and ask him the same question thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:200
verses.text: He will deny therefore that there is a Providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:201
verses.text: Yet that there is a Providence, is plain from what thou hast said; but that it is incomprehensible, is plain from those things whereof we cannot discover the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:202
verses.text: For if in things where men are the disposers, we oftentimes do not understand the method of the disposition, and in truth many of them appear to us inconsistent, and yet at the same time we acquiesce, how much more will this be so in the case of God? However, with God nothing either is inconsistent, or appears so to the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:203
verses.text: Wherefore let us "give thanks for all things," let us give Him glory for all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:204
verses.text: "Subjecting yourselves one to another," he says, "in the fear of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:205
verses.text: For if thou submit thyself for a ruler's sake, or for money's sake, or from respectfulness, much more from the fear of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:206
verses.text: Let there be an interchange of service and submission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:207
verses.text: For then will there be no such thing as slavish service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:208
verses.text: Let not one sit down in the rank of a freeman, and the other in the rank of a slave; rather it were better that both masters and slaves be servants to one another;—far better to be a slave in this way than free in any other; as will be evident from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:209
verses.text: Suppose the case of a man who should have an hundred slaves, and he should in no way serve them; and suppose again a different case, of an hundred friends, all waiting upon one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:210
verses.text: Which will lead the happier life? Which with the greater pleasure, with the more enjoyment? In the one case there is no anger, no provocation, no wrath, nor anything else of the kind whatever; in the other all is fear and apprehension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:211
verses.text: In the one case too the whole is forced, in the other is of free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:212
verses.text: In the one case they serve one another because they are forced to do so, in the other with mutual gratification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:213
verses.text: Thus does God will it to be; for this He washed His disciples' feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:214
verses.text: Nay more, if thou hast a mind to examine the matter nicely, there is indeed on the part of masters a return of service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:215
verses.text: For what if pride suffer not that return of service to appear? Yet if the slave on the one hand render his bodily service, and thou maintain that body, and supply it with food and clothing and shoes, this is an exchange of service: because unless thou render thy service as well, neither will he render his, but will be free, and no law will compel him to do it if he is not supported.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:216
verses.text: If this then is the case with servants, where is the absurdity, if it should also become the case with free men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:217
verses.text: "Subjecting yourselves in the fear," saith he, "of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:218
verses.text: How great then the obligation, when we shall also have a reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:219
verses.text: But he does not choose to submit himself to thee? However do thou submit thyself; not simply yield, but submit thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:220
verses.text: Entertain this feeling towards all, as if all were thy masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:221
verses.text: For thus shalt thou soon have all as thy slaves, enslaved to thee with the most abject slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:222
verses.text: For thou wilt then more surely make them thine, when without receiving anything of theirs, thou of thyself renderest them of thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:223
verses.text: This is "subjecting yourselves one to another in the fear of Christ," in order that we may subdue all the passions, be servants of God, and preserve the love we owe to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 20:224
verses.text: And then shall we be able also to be counted worthy of the lovingkindness which cometh of God, through the grace and mercies of His only-begotten Son, with whom to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and forever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:1
verses.text: Homily XX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:2
verses.text: Ephesians v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:3
verses.text: –  "Wives, be in subjection unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:4
verses.text: For the husband is the head of the wife, as Christ also is the head of the Church: being Himself the Saviour of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:5
verses.text: But as the Church is subject to Christ, so let the wives also be to their husbands in everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:6
verses.text: A certain wise man, setting down a number of things in the rank of blessings, set down this also in the rank of a blessing, "A wife agreeing with her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:7
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:8
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:9
verses.text: ) And elsewhere again he sets it down among blessings, that a woman should dwell in harmony with her husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:10
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:11
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:12
verses.text: ) And indeed from the beginning, God appears to have made special provision for this union; and discoursing of the twain as one, He said thus, "Male and female created He them" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:13
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:14
verses.text: ); and again, "There is neither male nor female".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:15
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:16
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:17
verses.text: ) For there is no relationship between man and man so close as that between man and wife, if they be joined together as they should be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:18
verses.text: And therefore a certain blessed man too, when he would express surpassing love, and was mourning for one that was dear to him, and of one soul with him, did not mention father, nor mother, nor child, nor brother, nor friend, but what? "Thy love to me was wonderful," saith he, "passing the love of women".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:19
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:20
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:21
verses.text: ) For indeed, in very deed, this love is more despotic than any despotism: for others indeed may be strong, but this passion is not only strong, but unfading.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:22
verses.text: For there is a certain love deeply seated in our nature, which imperceptibly to ourselves knits together these bodies of ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:23
verses.text: Thus even from the very beginning woman sprang from man, and afterwards from man and woman sprang both man and woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:24
verses.text: Perceivest thou the close bond and connection? And how that God suffered not a different kind of nature to enter in from without? And mark, how many providential arrangements He made.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:25
verses.text: He permitted the man to marry his own sister; or rather not his sister, but his daughter; nay, nor yet his daughter, but something more than his daughter, even his own flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:26
verses.text: And thus the whole He framed from one beginning, gathering all together, like stones in a building, into one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:27
verses.text: For neither on the one hand did He form her from without, and this was that the man might not feel towards her as towards an alien; nor again did He confine marriage to her, that she might not, by contracting herself, and making all center in herself, be cut off from the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:28
verses.text: Thus as in the case of plants, they are of all others the best, which have but a single stem, and spread out into a number of branches; (since were all confined to the root alone, all would be to no purpose, whereas again had it a number of roots, the tree would be no longer worthy of admiration;) so, I say, is the case here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:29
verses.text: From one, namely Adam, He made the whole race to spring, preventing them by the strongest necessity from being ever torn asunder, or separated; and afterwards, making it more restricted, He no longer allowed sisters and daughters to be wives, lest we should on the other hand contract our love to one point, and thus in another manner be cut off from one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:30
verses.text: Hence Christ said, "He which made them from the beginning, made them male and female".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:31
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:32
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:33
verses.text: )  For great evils are hence produced, and great benefits, both to families and to states.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:34
verses.text: For there is nothing which so welds our life together as the love of man and wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:35
verses.text: For this many will lay aside even their arms, for this they will give up life itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:36
verses.text: And Paul would never without a reason and without an object have spent so much pains on this subject, as when he says here, "Wives, be in subjection unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:37
verses.text: And why so? Because when they are in harmony, the children are well brought up, and the domestics are in good order, and neighbors, and friends, and relations enjoy the fragrance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:38
verses.text: But if it be otherwise, all is turned upside down, and thrown into confusion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:39
verses.text: And just as when the generals of an army are at peace one with another, all things are in due subordination, whereas on the other hand, if they are at variance, everything is turned upside down; so, I say, is it also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:40
verses.text: Wherefore, saith he, "Wives, be in subjection unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:41
verses.text: Yet how strange! for how then is it, that it is said elsewhere, "If one bid not farewell both to wife and to husband, he cannot follow me"? (Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:42
verses.text: ) For if it is their duty to be in subjection "as unto the Lord," how saith He that they must depart from them for the Lord's sake? Yet their duty indeed it is, their bounden duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:43
verses.text: But the word "as" is not necessarily and universally expressive of exact equality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:44
verses.text: He either means this, "'as' knowing that ye are servants to the Lord"; (which, by the way, is what he says elsewhere, that, even though they do it not for the husband's sake, yet must they primarily for the Lord's sake;) or else he means, "when thou obeyest thy husband, do so as serving the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:45
verses.text: For if he who resisteth these external authorities, those of governments, I mean, "withstandeth the ordinance of God" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:46
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:47
verses.text: ), much more does she who submits not herself to her husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:48
verses.text: Such was God's will from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:49
verses.text: Let us take as our fundamental position then that the husband occupies the place of the "head," and the wife the place of the "body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:50
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:52
verses.text: Then, he proceeds with arguments and says that "the husband is the head of the wife, as Christ also is the head of the Church, being Himself the Saviour of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:53
verses.text: But as the Church is subject to Christ, so let the wives be to their husbands in everything".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:54
verses.text: Then after saying, "The husband is the head of the wife, as Christ also is of the Church," he further adds, "and He is the Saviour of the body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:55
verses.text: For indeed the head is the saving health of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:56
verses.text: He had already laid down beforehand for man and wife, the ground and provision of their love, assigning to each their proper place, to the one that of authority and forethought, to the other that of submission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:57
verses.text: As then "the Church," that is, both husbands and wives, "is subject unto Christ, so also ye wives submit yourselves to your husbands, as unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:58
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:59
verses.text: "Husbands, love your wives, even as Christ also loved the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:60
verses.text: Thou hast heard how great the submission; thou hast extolled and marvelled at Paul, how, like an admirable and spiritual man, he welds together our whole life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:61
verses.text: Thou didst well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:62
verses.text: But now hear what he also requires at thy hands; for again he employs the same example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:63
verses.text: "Husbands," saith he, "love your wives, even as Christ also loved the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:64
verses.text: Thou hast seen the measure of obedience, hear also the measure of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:65
verses.text: Wouldest thou have thy wife obedient unto thee, as the Church is to Christ? Take then thyself the same provident care for her, as Christ takes for the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:66
verses.text: Yea, even if it shall be needful for thee to give thy life for her, yea, and to be cut into pieces ten thousand times, yea, and to endure and undergo any suffering whatever,—refuse it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:67
verses.text: Though thou shouldest undergo all this, yet wilt thou not, no, not even then, have done anything like Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:68
verses.text: For thou indeed art doing it for one to whom thou art already knit; but He for one who turned her back on Him and hated Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:69
verses.text: In the same way then as He laid at His feet her who turned her back on Him, who hated, and spurned, and disdained Him, not by menaces, nor by violence, nor by terror, nor by anything else of the kind, but by his unwearied affection; so also do thou behave thyself toward thy wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:70
verses.text: Yea, though thou see her looking down upon thee, and disdaining, and scorning thee, yet by thy great thoughtfulness for her, by affection, by kindness, thou wilt be able to lay her at thy feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:71
verses.text: For there is nothing more powerful to sway than these bonds, and especially for husband and wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:72
verses.text: A servant, indeed, one will be able, perhaps, to bind down by fear; nay not even him, for he will soon start away and be gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:73
verses.text: But the partner of one's life, the mother of one's children, the foundation of one's every joy, one ought never to chain down by fear and menaces, but with love and good temper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:74
verses.text: For what sort of union is that, where the wife trembles at her husband? And what sort of pleasure will the husband himself enjoy, if he dwells with his wife as with a slave, and not as with a free-woman? Yea, though thou shouldest suffer anything on her account, do not upbraid her; for neither did Christ do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:76
verses.text: "And gave Himself up," he says, "for it, that He might sanctify and cleanse it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:77
verses.text: So then she was unclean! So then she had blemishes, so then she was unsightly, so then she was worthless! Whatsoever kind of wife thou shalt take, yet shalt thou never take such a bride as the Church, when Christ took her, nor one so far removed from thee as the Church was from Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:78
verses.text: And yet for all that, He did not abhor her, nor loathe her for her surpassing deformity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:79
verses.text: Wouldest thou hear her deformity described? Hear what Paul saith, "For ye were once darkness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:80
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:81
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:82
verses.text: ) Didst thou see the blackness of her hue? What blacker than darkness? But look again at her boldness, "living," saith he, "in malice and envy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:83
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:84
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:85
verses.text: ) Look again at her impurity; "disobedient, foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:86
verses.text: But what am I saying? She was both foolish, and of an evil tongue; and yet notwithstanding, though so many were her blemishes, yet did He give Himself up for her in her deformity, as for one in the bloom of youth, as for one dearly beloved, as for one of wonderful beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:87
verses.text: And it was in admiration of this that Paul said, "For scarcely for a righteous man will one die (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:88
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:89
verses.text: ); and again, "in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:90
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:91
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:92
verses.text: ) And though such as this, He took her, He arrayed her in beauty, and washed her, and refused not even this, to give Himself for her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:95
verses.text: "That He might sanctify it having cleansed it," he proceeds, "by the washing of water with the word; that He might present the Church to Himself a glorious Church, not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing, but that it should be holy and without blemish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:96
verses.text: "By the washing or laver" He washeth her uncleanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:97
verses.text: "By the word," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:98
verses.text: What word? "In the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:99
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:100
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:101
verses.text: ) And not simply hath He adorned her, but hath made her "glorious, not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:102
verses.text: Let us then also seek after this beauty ourselves, and we shall be able to create it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:103
verses.text: Seek not thou at thy wife's hand, things which she is not able to possess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:104
verses.text: Seest thou that the Church had all things at her Lord's hands? By Him was made glorious, by Him was made pure, by Him made without blemish? Turn not thy back on thy wife because of her deformity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:105
verses.text: Hear the Scripture that saith, "The bee is little among such as fly, but her fruit is the chief of sweet things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:106
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:107
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:108
verses.text: ) She is of God's fashioning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:109
verses.text: Thou reproachest not her, but Him that made her; what can the woman do? Praise her not for her beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:110
verses.text: Praise and hatred and love based on personal beauty belong to unchastened souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:111
verses.text: Seek thou for beauty of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:112
verses.text: Imitate the Bridegroom of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:113
verses.text: Outward beauty is full of conceit and great license, and throws men into jealousy, and the thing often makes thee suspect monstrous things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:114
verses.text: But has it any pleasure? For the first or second month, perhaps, or at most for the year: but then no longer; the admiration by familiarity wastes away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:115
verses.text: Meanwhile the evils which arose from the beauty still abide, the pride, the folly, the contemptuousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:116
verses.text: Whereas in one who is not such, there is nothing of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:117
verses.text: But the love having begun on just grounds, still continues ardent, since its object is beauty of soul, and not of body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:118
verses.text: What better, tell me, than heaven? What better than the stars? Tell me of what body you will, yet is there none so fair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:119
verses.text: Tell me of what eyes you will, yet are there none so sparkling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:120
verses.text: When these were created, the very Angels gazed with wonder, and we gaze with wonder now; yet not in the same degree as at first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:121
verses.text: Such is familiarity; things do not strike us in the same degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:122
verses.text: How much more in the case of a wife! And if moreover disease come too, all is at once fled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:123
verses.text: Let us seek in a wife affectionateness, modest-mindedness, gentleness; these are the characteristics of beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:124
verses.text: But loveliness of person let us not seek, nor upbraid her upon these points, over which she has no power, nay, rather, let us not upbraid at all, (it were rudeness,) nor let us be impatient, nor sullen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:125
verses.text: Do ye not see how many, after living with beautiful wives, have ended their lives pitiably, and how many, who have lived with those of no great beauty, have run on to extreme old age with great enjoyment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:126
verses.text: Let us wipe off the "spot" that is within, let us smooth the "wrinkles" that are within, let us do away the "blemishes" that are on the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:127
verses.text: Such is the beauty God requires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:128
verses.text: Let us make her fair in God's sight, not in our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:129
verses.text: Let us not look for wealth, nor for that high-birth which is outward, but for that true nobility which is in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:130
verses.text: Let no one endure to get rich by a wife; for such riches are base and disgraceful; no, by no means let any one seek to get rich from this source.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:131
verses.text: "For they that desire to be rich, fall into a temptation and a snare, and many foolish and hurtful lusts, and into destruction and perdition".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:132
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:133
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:134
verses.text: ) Seek not therefore in thy wife abundance of wealth, and thou shalt find everything else go well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:135
verses.text: Who, tell me, would overlook the most important things, to attend to those which are less so? And yet, alas! this is in every case our feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:136
verses.text: Yes, if we have a son, we concern ourselves not how he may be made virtuous, but how we may get him a rich wife; not how he may be well-mannered, but well-monied: if we follow a business, we enquire not how it may be clear of sin, but how it may bring us in most profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:137
verses.text: And everything has become money; and thus is everything corrupted and ruined, because that passion possesses us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:138
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:139
verses.text: "Even so ought husbands to love their own wives," saith he, "as their own bodies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:140
verses.text: What, again, means this? To how much greater a similitude, and stronger example has he come; and not only so, but also to one how much nearer and clearer, and to a fresh obligation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:141
verses.text: For that other one was of no very constraining force, for He was Christ, and was God, and gave Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:142
verses.text: He now manages his argument on a different ground, saying, "so ought men"; because the thing is not a favor, but a debt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:143
verses.text: Then, "as their own bodies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:144
verses.text: And why?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:145
verses.text: "For no man ever hated his own flesh, but nourisheth and cherisheth it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:146
verses.text: That is, tends it with exceeding care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:147
verses.text: And how is she his flesh? Hearken; "This now is bone of my bones," saith Adam, "and flesh of my flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:148
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:149
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:150
verses.text: ) For she is made of matter taken from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:151
verses.text: And not only so, but also, "they shall be," saith God, "one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:152
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:153
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:154
verses.text: )  "Even as Christ also the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:155
verses.text: Here he returns to the former example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:156
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:157
verses.text: "Because we are members of His body, of His flesh and of His bones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:158
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:159
verses.text: "For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and the twain shall become one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:160
verses.text: Behold again a third ground of obligation; for he shows that a man leaving them that begat him, and from whom he was born, is knit to his wife; and that then the one flesh is, father, and mother, and the child, from the substance of the two commingled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:161
verses.text: For indeed by the commingling of their seeds is the child produced, so that the three are one flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:162
verses.text: Thus then are we in relation to Christ; we become one flesh by participation, and we much more than the child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:163
verses.text: And why and how so? Because so it has been from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:164
verses.text: Tell me not that such and such things are so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:165
verses.text: Seest thou not that we have in our own flesh itself many defects? For one man, for instance, is lame, another has his feet distorted, another his hands withered, another some other member weak; and yet nevertheless he does not grieve at it, nor cut it off, but oftentimes prefers it even to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:166
verses.text: Naturally enough; for it is part of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:167
verses.text: As great love as each entertains towards himself, so great he would have us entertain towards a wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:168
verses.text: Not because we partake of the same nature; no, this ground of duty towards a wife is far greater than that; it is that there are not two bodies but one; he the head, she the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:169
verses.text: And how saith he elsewhere "and the Head of Christ is God"? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:170
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:171
verses.text: ) This I too say, that as we are one body, so also are Christ and the Father One.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:172
verses.text: And thus then is the Father also found to be our Head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:173
verses.text: He sets down two examples, that of the natural body and that of Christ's body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:174
verses.text: And hence he further adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:175
verses.text: "This is great mystery: but I speak in regard of Christ and of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:176
verses.text: Why does he call it a great mystery? That it was something great and wonderful, the blessed Moses, or rather God, intimated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:177
verses.text: For the present, however, saith he, I speak regarding Christ, that having left the Father, He came down, and came to the Bride, and became one Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:178
verses.text: "For he that is joined unto the Lord is one Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:179
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:180
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:181
verses.text: ) And well saith he, "it is a great mystery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:182
verses.text: And then as though he were saying, "But still nevertheless the allegory does not destroy affection," he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:183
verses.text: "Nevertheless do ye also severally love each one his own wife even as himself; and let the wife see that she fear her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:184
verses.text: For indeed, in very deed, a mystery it is, yea, a great mystery, that a man should leave him that gave him being, him that begat him, and that brought him up, and her that travailed with him and had sorrow, those that have bestowed upon him so many and great benefits, those with whom he has been in familiar intercourse, and be joined to one who was never even seen by him and who has nothing in common with him, and should honor her before all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:185
verses.text: A mystery it is indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:186
verses.text: And yet are parents not distressed when these events take place, but rather, when they do not take place; and are delighted when their wealth is spent and lavished upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:187
verses.text: —A great mystery indeed! and one that contains some hidden wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:188
verses.text: Such Moses prophetically showed it to be from the very first; such now also Paul proclaims it, where he saith, "concerning Christ and the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:189
verses.text: However not for the husband's sake alone it is thus said, but for the wife's sake also, that "he cherish her as his own flesh, as Christ also the Church," and, "that the wife fear her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:190
verses.text: He is no longer setting down the duties of love only, but what? "That she fear her husband".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:191
verses.text: The wife is a second authority; let not her then demand equality, for she is under the head; nor let him despise her as being in subjection, for she is the body; and if the head despise the body, it will itself also perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:192
verses.text: But let him bring in love on his part as a counterpoise to obedience on her part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:193
verses.text: For example, let the hands and the feet, and all the rest of the members be given up for service to the head, but let the head provide for the body, seeing it contains every sense in itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:194
verses.text: Nothing can be better than this union.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:195
verses.text: And yet how can there ever be love, one may say, where there is fear? It will exist there, I say, preëminently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:196
verses.text: For she that fears and reverences, loves also; and she that loves, fears and reverences him as being the head, and loves him as being a member, since the head itself is a member of the body at large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:197
verses.text: Hence he places the one in subjection, and the other in authority, that there may be peace; for where there is equal authority there can never be peace; neither where a house is a democracy, nor where all are rulers; but the ruling power must of necessity be one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:198
verses.text: And this is universally the case with matters referring to the body, inasmuch as when men are spiritual, there will be peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:199
verses.text: There were "five thousand souls," and not one of them said, "that aught of the things which he possessed was his own" (Acts iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:200
verses.text: ), but they were subject one to another; an indication this of wisdom, and of the fear of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:201
verses.text: The principle of love, however, he explains; that of fear he does not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:202
verses.text: And mark, how on that of love he enlarges, stating the arguments relating to Christ and those relating to one's own flesh, the words, "For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:203
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:204
verses.text: ) Whereas upon those drawn from fear he forbears to enlarge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:205
verses.text: And why so? Because he would rather that this principle prevail, this, namely, of love; for where this exists, everything else follows of course, but where the other exists, not necessarily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:206
verses.text: For the man who loves his wife, even though she be not a very obedient one, still will bear with everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:207
verses.text: So difficult and impracticable is unanimity, where persons are not bound together by that love which is founded in supreme authority; at all events, fear will not necessarily effect this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:208
verses.text: Accordingly, he dwells the more upon this, which is the strong tie.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:209
verses.text: And the wife though seeming to be the loser in that she was charged to fear, is the gainer, because the principal duty, love, is charged upon the husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:210
verses.text: "But what," one may say, "if a wife reverence me not?" Never mind, thou art to love, fulfill thine own duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:211
verses.text: For though that which is due from others may not follow, we ought of course to do our duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:212
verses.text: This is an example of what I mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:213
verses.text: He says, "submitting yourselves one to another in the fear of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:214
verses.text: And what then if another submit not himself? Still obey thou the law of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:215
verses.text: Just so, I say, is it also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:216
verses.text: Let the wife at least, though she be not loved, still reverence notwithstanding, that nothing may lie at her door; and let the husband, though his wife reverence him not, still show her love notwithstanding, that he himself be not wanting in any point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:217
verses.text: For each has received his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:218
verses.text: This then is marriage when it takes place according to Christ, spiritual marriage, and spiritual birth, not of blood, nor of travail, nor of the will of the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:219
verses.text: Such was the birth of Christ, not of blood, nor of travail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:220
verses.text: Such also was that of Isaac.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:221
verses.text: Hear how the Scripture saith, "And it ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:222
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:223
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:224
verses.text: ) Yea, a marriage it is, not of passion, nor of the flesh, but wholly spiritual, the soul being united to God by a union unspeakable, and which He alone knoweth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:225
verses.text: Therefore he saith, "He that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:226
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:227
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:228
verses.text: ) Mark how earnestly he endeavors to unite both flesh with flesh, and spirit with spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:229
verses.text: And where are the heretics? Never surely, if marriage were a thing to be condemned, would he have called Christ and the Church a bride and bridegroom; never would he have brought forward by way of exhortation the words, "A man shall leave his father and his mother"; and again have added, that it was "spoken in regard of Christ and of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:230
verses.text: For of her it is that the Psalmist also saith, "Hearken, O daughter, and consider, and incline thine ear; forget also thine own people, and thy father's house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:231
verses.text: So shall the king desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:232
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:233
verses.text: xlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:235
verses.text: ) Therefore also Christ saith, "I came out from the Father, and am come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:236
verses.text: (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:237
verses.text: ) But when I say, that He left the Father, imagine not such a thing as happens among men, a change of place; for just in the same way as the word "go forth" is used, not because He literally came forth, but because of His incarnation, so also is the expression, "He left the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:238
verses.text: Now why did he not say of the wife also, She shall be joined unto her husband? Why, I say, is this? Because he was discoursing concerning love, and was discoursing to the husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:239
verses.text: For to her indeed he discourses concerning reverence, and says, "the husband is the head of the wife" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:240
verses.text: ), and again, "Christ is the Head of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:241
verses.text: Whereas to him he discourses concerning love, and commits to him this province of love, and declares to him that which pertains to love, thus binding him and cementing him to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:242
verses.text: For the man that leaves his father for the sake of his wife, and then again, leaves this very wife herself and abandons her, what forbearance can he deserve?  Seest thou not how great a share of honor God would have her enjoy, in that he hath taken thee away from thy father, and hath linked thee to her? What then, a man may say, if our duty is done, and yet she does not follow the example? "Yet if the unbelieving departeth, let him depart; the brother or the sister is not under bondage in such cases".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:243
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:244
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:245
verses.text: )  However, when thou hearest of "fear," demand that fear which becomes a free woman, not as though thou wert exacting it of a slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:246
verses.text: For she is thine own body; and if thou do this, thou reproachest thyself in dishonoring thine own body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:247
verses.text: And of what nature is this "fear"? It is the not contradicting, the not rebelling, the not being fond of the preëminence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:248
verses.text: It is enough that fear be kept within these bounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:249
verses.text: But if thou love, as thou art commanded, thou wilt make it yet greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:250
