verses.text: Or rather it will not be any longer by fear that thou wilt be doing this, but love itself will have its effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:251
verses.text: The sex is somehow weaker, and needs much support, much condescension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:252
verses.text: But what will they say, who are knit together in second marriages? I speak not at all in condemnation of them, God forbid; for the Apostle himself permits them, though indeed by way of condescension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:253
verses.text: Supply her with everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:254
verses.text: Do everything and endure trouble for her sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:255
verses.text: Necessity is laid upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:256
verses.text: Here he does not think it right to introduce his counsel, as he in many cases does, with examples from them that are without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:257
verses.text: That of Christ, so great and forcible, were alone enough; and more especially as regards the argument of subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:258
verses.text: "A man shall leave," he saith, "his father and mother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:259
verses.text: Behold, this then is from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:260
verses.text: But he does not say, and "shall dwell with," but "shall cleave unto," thus showing the closeness of the union, and the fervent love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:261
verses.text: Nay, he is not content with this, but further by what he adds, he explains the subjection in such a way as that the twain appear no longer twain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:262
verses.text: He does not say, "one spirit," he does not say, "one soul" (for that is manifest, and is possible to any one), but so as to be "one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:263
verses.text: She is a second authority, possessing indeed an authority, and a considerable equality of dignity; but at the same time the husband has somewhat of superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:264
verses.text: In this consists most chiefly the well-being of the house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:265
verses.text: For he took that former argument, the example of Christ, to show that we ought not only to love, but also to govern; "that she may be," saith he, "holy and without blemish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:266
verses.text: But the word "flesh" has reference to love—and the word "shall cleave" has in like manner reference to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:267
verses.text: For if thou shalt make her "holy and without blemish," everything else will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:268
verses.text: Seek the things which are of God, and those which are of man will follow readily enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:269
verses.text: Govern thy wife, and thus will the whole house be in harmony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:270
verses.text: Hear what Paul saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:271
verses.text: "And if they would learn anything, let them ask their own husbands at home".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:272
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:273
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:274
verses.text: ) If we thus regulate our own houses, we shall be also fit for the management of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:275
verses.text: For indeed a house is a little Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:276
verses.text: Thus it is possible for us by becoming good husbands and wives, to surpass all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:277
verses.text: Consider Abraham, and Sarah, and Isaac, and the three hundred and eighteen born in his house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:278
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:279
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:280
verses.text: ) How the whole house was harmoniously knit together, how the whole was full of piety and fulfilled the Apostolic injunction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:281
verses.text: She also "reverenced her husband"; for hear her own words, "It hath not yet happened unto me even until now, and my lord is old also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:282
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:283
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:284
verses.text: ) And he again so loved her, that in all things he obeyed her commands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:285
verses.text: And the young child was virtuous, and the servants born in the house, they too were so excellent that they refused not even to hazard their lives with their master; they delayed not, nor asked the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:286
verses.text: Nay, one of them, the chief, was so admirable, that he was even entrusted with the marriage of the only-begotten child, and with a journey into a foreign country.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:287
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:288
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:290
verses.text: ) For just as with a general, when his soldiery also is well organized, the enemy has no quarter to attack; so, I say, is it also here: when husband and wife and children and servants are all interested in the same things, great is the harmony of the house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:291
verses.text: Since where this is not the case, the whole is oftentimes overthrown and broken up by one bad servant; and that single one will often mar and utterly destroy the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:292
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:293
verses.text: Let us then be very thoughtful both for our wives, and children, and servants; knowing that we shall thus be establishing for ourselves an easy government, and shall have our accounts with them gentle and lenient, and say, "Behold I, and the children which God hath given me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:294
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:295
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:296
verses.text: ) If the husband command respect, and the head be honorable, then will the rest of the body sustain no violence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:297
verses.text: Now what is the wife's fitting behavior, and what the husband's, he states accurately, charging her to reverence him as the head, and him to love her as a wife; but how, it may be said, can these things be? That they ought indeed so to be, he has proved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:298
verses.text: But how they can be so, I will tell you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:299
verses.text: They will be so, if we will despise money, if we will look but to one thing only, excellence of soul, if we will keep the fear of God before our eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:300
verses.text: For what he says in his discourse to servants, "whatsoever any man doeth, whether it be good or evil, the same shall he receive of the Lord" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:301
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:302
verses.text: ); this is also the case here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:303
verses.text: Love her therefore not for her sake so much as for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:304
verses.text: This, at least, he as much as intimates, in saying, "as unto the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:305
verses.text: So then do everything, as in obedience to the Lord, and as doing everything for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:306
verses.text: This were enough to induce and to persuade us, and not to suffer that there should be any teasing and dissension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:307
verses.text: Let none be believed when slandering the husband to his wife; no, nor let the husband believe anything at random against the wife, nor let the wife be without reason inquisitive about his goings out and his comings in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:308
verses.text: No, nor on any account let the husband ever render himself worthy of any suspicion whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:309
verses.text: For what, tell me, what if thou shalt devote thyself all the day to thy friends, and give the evening to thy wife, and not even thus be able to content her, and place her out of reach of suspicion? Though thy wife complain, yet be not annoyed—it is her love, not her folly—they are the complaints of fervent attachment, and burning affection, and fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:310
verses.text: Yes, she is afraid lest any one have stolen her marriage bed, lest any one have injured her in that which is the summit of her blessings, lest any one have taken away from her him who is her head, lest any one have broken through her marriage chamber.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:311
verses.text: There is also another ground of petty jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:312
verses.text: Let neither claim too much service of the servants, neither the husband from the maid-servant, nor the wife from the man-servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:313
verses.text: For these things also are enough to beget suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:314
verses.text: For consider, I say, that righteous household I spoke of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:315
verses.text: Sarah herself bade the patriarch take Hagar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:316
verses.text: She herself directed it, no one compelled her, nor did the husband attempt it; no, although he had dragged on so long a period childless, yet he chose never to become a father, rather than to grieve his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:317
verses.text: And yet even after all this, what said Sarah? "The Lord judge between me and thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:318
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:319
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:320
verses.text: ) Now, I say, had he been any one else would he not have been moved to anger? Would he not also have stretched forth his hand, saying as it were, "What meanest thou? I had no desire to have anything to do with the woman; it was all thine own doing; and dost thou turn again and accuse me?"—But no, he says nothing of the sort;—but what? "Behold, thy maid is in thy hand; do to her that which is good in thine eyes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:321
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:322
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:323
verses.text: ) He delivered up the partner of his bed, that he might not grieve Sarah.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:324
verses.text: And yet surely is there nothing greater than this for producing affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:325
verses.text: For if partaking of the same table produces unanimity even in robbers towards their foes, (and the Psalmist saith, "Who didst eat sweet food at the same table with me"); much more will the becoming one flesh—for such is the being the partner of the bed—be effectual to draw us together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:326
verses.text: Yet did none of these things avail to overcome him; but he delivered Hagar up to his wife, to show that nothing had been done by his own fault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:327
verses.text: Nay, and what is more, he sent her forth when with child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:328
verses.text: Who would not have pitied one that had conceived a child by himself? Yet was the just man unmoved, for he set before everything else the love he owed his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:329
verses.text: Let us then imitate him ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:330
verses.text: Let no one reproach his neighbor with his poverty; let no one be in love with money; and then all difficulties will be at an end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:331
verses.text: Neither let a wife say to her husband, "Unmanly coward that thou art, full of sluggishness and dullness, and fast asleep! here is such a one, a low man, and of low parentage, who runs his risks, and makes his voyages, and has made a good fortune; and his wife wears her jewels, and goes out with her pair of milk-white mules; she rides about everywhere, she has troops of slaves, and a swarm of eunuchs, but thou hast cowered down and livest to no purpose".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:332
verses.text: Let not a wife say these things, nor anything like them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:333
verses.text: For she is the body, not to dictate to the head, but to submit herself and obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:334
verses.text: "But how," some one will say, "is she to endure poverty? Where is she to look for consolation?" Let her select and put beside her those who are poorer still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:335
verses.text: Let her again consider how many noble and high-born maidens have not only received nothing of their husbands, but have even given dowries to them, and have spent their all upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:336
verses.text: Let her reflect on the perils which arise from such riches, and she will cling to this quiet life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:337
verses.text: In short, if she is affectionately disposed towards her husband, she will utter nothing of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:338
verses.text: No, she will rather choose to have him near her, though gaining nothing, than gaining ten thousand talents of gold, accompanied with that care and anxiety which always arise to wives from those distant voyages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:339
verses.text: Neither, however, let the husband, when he hears these things, on the score of his having the supreme authority, betake himself to revilings and to blows; but let him exhort, let him admonish her, as being less perfect, let him persuade her with arguments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:340
verses.text: Let him never once lift his hand,—far be this from a noble spirit,—no, nor give expression to insults, or taunts, or revilings; but let him regulate and direct her as being wanting in wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:341
verses.text: Yet how shall this be done? If she be instructed in the true riches, in the heavenly philosophy, she will make no complaints like these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:342
verses.text: Let him teach her then, that poverty is no evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:343
verses.text: Let him teach her, not by what he says only, but also by what he does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:344
verses.text: Let him teach her to despise glory; and then his wife will speak of nothing, and will desire nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:345
verses.text: Let him, as if he had an image given into his hands to mould, let him, from that very evening on which he first receives her into the bridal chamber, teach her temperance, gentleness, and how to live, casting down the love of money at once from the outset, and from the very threshold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:346
verses.text: Let him discipline her in wisdom, and advise her never to have bits of gold hanging at her ears, and down her cheeks, and laid round about her neck, nor laid up about the chamber, nor golden and costly garments stored up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:347
verses.text: But let her chamber be handsome, still let not what is handsome degenerate into finery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:348
verses.text: No, leave these things to the people of the stage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:349
verses.text: Adorn thine house thyself with all possible neatness, so as rather to breathe an air of soberness than much perfume.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:350
verses.text: For hence will arise two or three good results.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:351
verses.text: First then, the bride will not be grieved, when the apartments are opened, and the tissues, and the golden ornaments, and silver vessels, are sent back to their several owners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:352
verses.text: Next, the bridegroom will have no anxiety about the loss, nor for the security of the accumulated treasures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:353
verses.text: Thirdly again, in addition to this, which is the crown of all these benefits, by these very points he will be showing his own judgment, that indeed he has no pleasure in any of these things, and that he will moreover put an end to everything else in keeping with them, and will never so much as allow the existence either of dances, or of immodest songs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:354
verses.text: I am aware that I shall appear perhaps ridiculous to many persons, in giving such admonitions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:355
verses.text: Still nevertheless, if ye will but listen to me, as time goes on, and the benefit of the practice accrues to you, then ye will understand the advantage of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:356
verses.text: And the laughter will pass off, and ye will laugh at the present fashion, and will see that the present practice is really that of silly children and of drunken men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:357
verses.text: Whereas what I recommend is the part of soberness, and wisdom, and of the sublimest way of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:358
verses.text: What then do I say is our duty? Take away from marriage all those shameful, those Satanic, those immodest songs, those companies of profligate young people, and this will avail to chasten the spirit of thy bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:359
verses.text: For she will at once thus reason with herself; "Wonderful! What a philosopher this man is! he regards the present life as nothing, he has brought me here into his house, to be a mother, to bring up his children, to manage his household affairs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:360
verses.text: "Yes, but these things are distasteful to a bride?" Just for the first or second day;—but not afterwards; nay, she will even reap from them the greatest delight, and relieve herself of all suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:361
verses.text: For a man who can endure neither flute-players, nor dancers, nor broken songs, and that too at the very time of his wedding, that man will scarcely endure ever to do or say anything shameful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:362
verses.text: And then after this, when thou hast stripped the marriage of all these things, then take her, and form and mould her carefully, encouraging her bashfulness to a considerable length of time, and not destroying it suddenly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:363
verses.text: For even if the damsel be very bold, yet for a time she will keep silence out of reverence for her husband, and feeling herself a novice in the circumstances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:364
verses.text: Thou then break not off this reserve too hastily, as unchaste husbands do, but encourage it for a long time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:365
verses.text: For this will be a great advantage to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:366
verses.text: Meanwhile she will not complain, she will not find fault with any laws thou mayest frame for her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:367
verses.text: During that time therefore, during which shame, like a sort of bridle laid upon the soul, suffers her not to make any murmur, nor to complain of what is done, lay down all thy laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:368
verses.text: For as soon as ever she acquires boldness, she will overturn and confound everything without any sense of fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:369
verses.text: When is there then another time so advantageous for moulding a wife, as that during which she reverences her husband, and is still timid, and still shy? Then lay down all thy laws for her, and willing or unwilling, she will certainly obey them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:370
verses.text: But how shalt thou help spoiling her modesty? By showing her that thou thyself art no less modest than she is, addressing to her but few words, and those too with great gravity and collectedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:371
verses.text: Then entrust her with the discourses of wisdom, for her soul will receive them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:372
verses.text: And establish her in that loveliest habit, I mean modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:373
verses.text: If you wish me, I will also tell you by way of specimen, what sort of language should be addressed to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:374
verses.text: For if Paul shrank not from saying, "Defraud ye not one the other" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:375
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:376
verses.text: ), and spoke the language of a bridesmaid, or rather not of a bridesmaid, but of a spiritual soul, much more will not we shrink from speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:377
verses.text: What then is the language we ought to address to her? With great delicacy then we may say to her, "I have taken thee, my child, to be partner of my life, and have brought thee in to share with me in the closest and most honorable ties, in my children, and the superintendence of my house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:378
verses.text: And what advice then shall I now recommend thee?" But rather, first talk with her of your love for her; for there is nothing that so contributes to persuade a hearer to admit sincerely the things that are said, as to be assured that they are said with hearty affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:379
verses.text: How then art thou to show that affection? By saying, "when it was in my power to take many to wife, both with better fortunes, and of noble family, I did not so choose, but I was enamoured of thee, and thy beautiful life, thy modesty, thy gentleness, and soberness of mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:380
verses.text: Then immediately from these beginnings open the way to your discourse on true wisdom, and with some circumlocution make a protest against riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:381
verses.text: For if you direct your argument at once against riches, you will bear too heavily upon her; but if you do it by taking an occasion, you will succeed entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:382
verses.text: For you will appear to be doing it in the way of an apology, not as a morose sort of person, and ungracious, and over-nice about trifles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:383
verses.text: But when you take occasion from what relates to herself, she will be even pleased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:384
verses.text: You will say then, (for I must now take up the discourse again,) that "whereas I might have married a rich woman, and with good fortune, I could not endure it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:385
verses.text: And why so? Not capriciously, and without reason; but I was taught well and truly, that money is no real possession, but a most despicable thing, a thing which moreover belongs as well to thieves, and to harlots, and to grave-robbers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:386
verses.text: So I gave up these things, and went on till I fell in with the excellence of thy soul, which I value above all gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:387
verses.text: For a young damsel who is discreet and ingenuous, and whose heart is set on piety, is worth the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:388
verses.text: For these reasons then, I courted thee, and I love thee, and prefer thee to my own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:389
verses.text: For the present life is nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:390
verses.text: And I pray, and beseech, and do all I can, that we may be counted worthy so to live this present life, as that we may be able also there in the world to come to be united to one another in perfect security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:391
verses.text: For our time here is brief and fleeting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:392
verses.text: But if we shall be counted worthy by having pleased God to so exchange this life for that one, then shall we ever be both with Christ and with each other, with more abundant pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:393
verses.text: I value thy affection above all things, and nothing is so bitter or so painful to me, as ever to be at variance with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:394
verses.text: Yes, though it should be my lot to lose my all, and to become poorer than Irus, and undergo the extremest hazards, and suffer any pain whatsoever, all will be tolerable and endurable, so long as thy feelings are true towards me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:395
verses.text: And then will my children be most dear to me, whilst thou art affectionately disposed towards me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:396
verses.text: But thou must do these duties too".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:397
verses.text: Then mingle also with your discourse the Apostle's words, that "thus God would have our affections blended together; for listen to the Scripture, which saith, 'For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and cleave to his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:398
verses.text: ' Let us have no pretext for narrow-minded jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:399
verses.text: Perish riches, and retinue of slaves, and all your outward pomps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:400
verses.text: To me this is more valuable than all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:401
verses.text: What weight of gold, what amount of treasures, are so dear to a wife as these words? Never fear that because she is beloved she will ever rave against thee, but confess that thou lovest her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:402
verses.text: For courtezans indeed, who now attach themselves to one and now to another, would naturally enough feel contempt towards their lovers, should they hear such expressions as these; but a free-born wife or a noble damsel would never be so affected with such words; no, she will be so much the more subdued.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:403
verses.text: Show her too, that you set a high value on her company, and that you are more desirous to be at home for her sake, than in the market-place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:404
verses.text: And esteem her before all your friends, and above the children that are born of her, and let these very children be beloved by thee for her sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:405
verses.text: If she does any good act, praise and admire it; if any foolish one, and such as girls may chance to do, advise her and remind her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:406
verses.text: Condemn out and out all riches and extravagance, and gently point out the ornament that there is in neatness and in modesty; and be continually teaching her the things that are profitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:407
verses.text: Let your prayers be common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:408
verses.text: Let each go to Church; and let the husband ask his wife at home, and she again ask her husband, the account of the things which were said and read there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:409
verses.text: If any poverty should overtake you, cite the case of those holy men, Paul and Peter, who were more honored than any kings or rich men; and yet how they spent their lives, in hunger and in thirst.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:410
verses.text: Teach her that there is nothing in life that is to be feared, save only offending against God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:411
verses.text: If any marry thus, with these views, he will be but little inferior to monks; the married but little below the unmarried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:412
verses.text: If thou hast a mind to give dinners, and to make entertainments, let there be nothing immodest, nothing disorderly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:413
verses.text: If thou shouldest find any poor saint able to bless your house, able only just by setting his foot in it to bring in the whole blessing of God, invite him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:414
verses.text: And shalt I say moreover another thing? Let no one of you make it his endeavor to marry a rich woman, but much rather a poor one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:415
verses.text: When she comes in, she will not bring so great a source of pleasure from her riches, as she will annoyance from her taunts, from her demanding more than she brought, from her insolence, her extravagance, her vexatious language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:416
verses.text: For she will say perhaps, "I have not yet spent anything of thine, I am still wearing my own apparel, bought with what my parents settled upon me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:417
verses.text: What sayest thou, O woman? Still wearing thine own! And what can be more miserable than this language? Why, thou hast no longer a body of thine own, and hast thou money of thine own? After marriage ye are no longer twain, but are become one flesh, and are then your possessions twain, and not one? Oh! this love of money! Ye both are become one man, one living creature; and dost thou still say "mine own"? Cursed and abominable word that it is, it was brought in by the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:418
verses.text: Things far nearer and dearer to us than these hath God made all common to us, and are these then not common? We cannot say, "my own light, my own sun, my own water": all our greater blessings are common, and are riches not common? Perish the riches ten thousand times over! Or rather not the riches, but those tempers of mind which know not how to make use of riches, but esteem them above all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:419
verses.text: Teach her these lessons also with the rest, but with much graciousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:420
verses.text: For since the recommendation of virtue has in itself much that is stern, and especially to a young and tender damsel, whenever discourses on true wisdom are to be made, contrive that your manner be full of grace and kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:421
verses.text: And above all banish this notion from her soul, of "mine and thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:422
verses.text: If she say the word "mine," say unto her, "What things dost thou call thine? For in truth I know not; I for my part have nothing of mine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:423
verses.text: How then speakest thou of 'mine,' when all things are thine?" Freely grant her the word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:424
verses.text: Dost thou not perceive that such is our practice with children? When, whilst we are holding anything, a child snatches it, and wishes again to get hold of some other thing, we allow it, and say, "Yes, and this is thine, and that is thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:425
verses.text: The same also let us do with a wife; for her temper is more or less like a child's; and if she says "mine," say, "why, everything is thine, and I am thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:426
verses.text: Nor is the expression one of flattery, but of exceeding wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:427
verses.text: Thus wilt thou be able to abate her wrath, and put an end to her disappointment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:428
verses.text: For it is flattery when a man does an unworthy act with an evil object: whereas this is the highest philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:429
verses.text: Say then, "Even I am thine, my child; this advice Paul gives me where he says, 'The husband hath not power over his own body, but the wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:430
verses.text: ' ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:431
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:432
verses.text: ) If I have no power over my body, but thou hast, much more hast thou over my possessions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:433
verses.text: By saying these things thou wilt have quieted her, thou wilt have quenched the fire, thou wilt have shamed the devil, thou wilt have made her more thy slave than one bought with money, with this language thou wilt have bound her fast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:434
verses.text: Thus then, by thine own language, teach her never to speak of "mine and thine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:435
verses.text: And again, never call her simply by her name, but with terms of endearment, with honor, with much love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:436
verses.text: Honor her, and she will not need honor from others; she will not want the glory that comes from others, if she enjoys that which comes from thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:437
verses.text: Prefer her before all, on every account, both for her beauty and her discernment, and praise her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:438
verses.text: Thou wilt thus persuade her to give heed to none that are without, but to scorn all the world except thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:439
verses.text: Teach her the fear of God, and all good things will flow from this as from a fountain, and the house will be full of ten thousand blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:440
verses.text: If we seek the things that are incorruptible, these corruptible things will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:441
verses.text: "For," saith He, "seek first His kingdom, and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:442
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:443
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:444
verses.text: ) What sort of persons, think you, must the children of such parents be? What the servants of such masters? What all others who come near them? Will not they too eventually be loaded with blessings out of number? For generally the servants also have their characters formed after their master's, and are fashioned after their humors, love the same objects, which they have been taught to love, speak the same language, and engage with them in the same pursuits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:445
verses.text: If thus we regulate ourselves, and attentively study the Scriptures, in most things we shall derive instruction from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 21:446
verses.text: And thus shall be able to please God, and to pass through the whole of the present life virtuously, and to attain those blessings which are promised to those that love Him, of which God grant that we may all be counted worthy, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, together with the Holy Ghost, be unto the Father, glory, power, and honor, now, and ever, through all ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:1
verses.text: Homily XXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:2
verses.text: Ephesians vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:3
verses.text: –  "Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:4
verses.text: Honor thy father and mother (which is the first commandment with promise), that it may be well with thee, and thou mayest live long on the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:5
verses.text: As a man in forming a body, places the head first, after that the neck, then the feet, so does the blessed Paul proceed in his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:6
verses.text: He has spoken of the husband, he has spoken of the wife, who is second in authority, he now goes on by gradual advances to the third rank—which is that of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:7
verses.text: For the husband has authority over the wife, and the husband and the wife over the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:8
verses.text: Now then mark what he is saying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:9
verses.text: "Children, obey your parents in the Lord; for this is the first commandment with promise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:10
verses.text: Here he has not a word of discourse concerning Christ, not a word on high subjects, for he is as yet addressing his discourse to tender understandings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:11
verses.text: And it is for this reason, moreover, that he makes his exhortation short, inasmuch as children cannot follow up a long argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:12
verses.text: For this reason also he does not discourse at all about a kingdom, (because it does not belong to the tender age of childhood to understand these subjects,) but what a child's soul most especially longs to hear, that he says, namely, that it shall "live long".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:13
verses.text: For if any one shall enquire why it is that he omitted to discourse concerning a kingdom, but set before them the commandment laid down in the law, he does this because he speaks to them as infantile, and because he is well aware that if the husband and the wife are thus disposed according to the law which he has laid down, there will be but little trouble in securing the submission of the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:14
verses.text: For whenever any matter has a good and sound and orderly principle and foundation, everything will thenceforward go on with method and regularity, with much facility: the more difficult thing is to settle the foundation, to lay down a firm basis.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:15
verses.text: "Children," saith he, "obey your parents in the Lord," that is, according to the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:16
verses.text: This, he means to say, is what God commands you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:17
verses.text: But what then if they shall command foolish things? Generally a father, however foolish he may be himself, does not command foolish things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:18
verses.text: However, even in that case, the Apostle has guarded the matter, by saying, "in the Lord"; that is, wherever you will not be offending against God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:19
verses.text: So that if the father be a gentile or a heretic, we ought no longer to obey, because the command is not then, "in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:20
verses.text: But how is it that he says, "Which is the first commandment"? For the first is, "Thou shalt not commit adultery;—Thou shalt not kill".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:21
verses.text: He does not speak of it then as first in rank, but in respect of the promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:22
verses.text: For upon those others there is no reward annexed, as being enacted with reference to evil things, and to departure from evil things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:23
verses.text: Whereas in these others, where there is the practice of good, there is further a promise held out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:24
verses.text: And observe how admirable a foundation he has laid for the path of virtue, that is, honor and reverence towards parents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:25
verses.text: When he would lead us away from wicked practices, and is just about to enter upon virtuous ones, this is the first thing he enjoins, honor towards parents; inasmuch as they before all others are, after God, the authors of our being, so that it is reasonable they should be the first to reap the fruits of our right actions; and then all the rest of mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:26
verses.text: For if a man have not this honor for parents he will never be gentle toward those unconnected with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:27
verses.text: However, having given the necessary injunctions to children, he passes to the fathers, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:28
verses.text: "And ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath; but nurture them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:29
verses.text: He does not say, "love them," because to this nature draws them even against their own will, and it were superfluous to lay down a law on such subjects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:30
verses.text: But what does he say? "Provoke not your children to wrath," as many do by disinheriting them, and disowning them, and treating them overbearingly, not as free, but as slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:31
verses.text: This is why he says, "Provoke not your children to wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:32
verses.text: Then, which is the chief thing of all, he shows how they will be led to obedience, referring the whole source of it to the head and chief authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:33
verses.text: And in the same way as he has shown the husband to be the cause of the wife's obedience, (which is the reason also why he addresses the greater part of his arguments to him, advising him to attach her to himself by the power of love,) so, I say, here also, he refers the efficiency to him, by saying, "But bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:34
verses.text: Thou seest that where there are spiritual ties, the natural ties will follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:35
verses.text: Do you wish your son to be obedient? From the very first "Bring him up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:36
verses.text: Never deem it an unnecessary thing that he should be a diligent hearer of the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:37
verses.text: For there the first thing he hears will be this, "Honor thy father and thy mother"; so that this makes for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:38
verses.text: Never say, this is the business of monks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:39
verses.text: Am I making a monk of him? No.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:40
verses.text: There is no need he should become a monk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:41
verses.text: Why be so afraid of a thing so replete with so much advantage? Make him a Christian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:42
verses.text: For it is of all things necessary for laymen to be acquainted with the lessons derived from this source; but especially for children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:43
verses.text: For theirs is an age full of folly; and to this folly are superadded the bad examples derived from the heathen tales, where they are made acquainted with those heroes so admired amongst them, slaves of their passions, and cowards with regard to death; as, for example, Achilles, when he relents, when he dies for his concubine, when another gets drunk, and many other things of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:44
verses.text: He requires therefore the remedies against these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:45
verses.text: How is it not absurd to send children out to trades, and to school, and to do all you can for these objects, and yet, not to "bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord"? And for this reason truly we are the first to reap the fruits, because we bring up our children to be insolent and profligate, disobedient, and mere vulgar fellows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:46
verses.text: Let us not then do this; no, let us listen to this blessed Apostle's admonition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:47
verses.text: "Let us bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:48
verses.text: Let us give them a pattern.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:49
verses.text: Let us make them from the earliest age apply themselves to the reading of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:50
verses.text: Alas, that so constantly as I repeat this, I am looked upon as trifling! Still, I shall not cease to do my duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:51
verses.text: Why, tell me, do ye not imitate them of old? Ye women, especially, emulate those admirable women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:52
verses.text: Has a child been born to any one? Imitate Hannah's example ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:53
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:54
verses.text: ); look at what she did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:55
verses.text: She brought him up at once to the temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:56
verses.text: Who amongst you would not rather that his son should become a Samuel than that he should be king of the whole world ten thousand times over? "And how," you will say, "is it possible he should become such a one?" Why is it not possible? It is because thou dost not choose it thyself, nor committest him to the care of those who are able to make him such a one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:57
verses.text: "And who," it will be said, "is such a one as this?" God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:58
verses.text: Since she put him into the hands of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:59
verses.text: For not even Eli himself was one of those in any great degree qualified to form him; (how could he be, he who was not able to form even his own children?) No, it was the faith of the mother and her earnest zeal that wrought the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:60
verses.text: He was her first child, and her only one, and she knew not whether she should ever have others besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:61
verses.text: Yet she did not say, "I will wait till the child is grown up, that he may have a taste of the things of this life, I will allow him to have his pastime in them a little in his childish years".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:62
verses.text: No, all these thoughts the woman repudiated, she was absorbed in one object, how from the very beginning she might dedicate the spiritual image to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:63
verses.text: Well may we men be put to the blush at the wisdom of this woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:64
verses.text: She offered him up to God, and there she left him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:65
verses.text: And therefore was her married state more glorious, in that she had made spiritual objects her first care, in that she dedicated the first-fruits to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:66
verses.text: Therefore was her womb fruitful, and she obtained other children besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:67
verses.text: And therefore she saw him honorable even in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:68
verses.text: For if men when they are honored, render honor in return, will not God much more, He who does this, even without being honored? How long are we to be mere lumps of flesh? How long are we to be stooping to the earth? Let everything be secondary with us to the provident care we should take of our children, and to our "bringing them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:69
verses.text: If from the very first he is taught to be a lover of true wisdom, then wealth greater than all wealth has he acquired and a more imposing name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:70
verses.text: You will effect nothing so great by teaching him an art, and giving him that outward learning by which he will gain riches, as if you teach him the art of despising riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:71
verses.text: If you desire to make him rich, do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:72
verses.text: For the rich man is not he who desires great riches, and is encircled with great riches; but the man who has need of nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:73
verses.text: Discipline your son in this, teach him this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:74
verses.text: This is the greatest riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:75
verses.text: Seek not how to give him reputation and high character in outward learning, but consider deeply how you shall teach him to despise the glory that belongs to this present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:76
verses.text: By this means would he become more distinguished and more truly glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:77
verses.text: This it is possible for the poor man and the rich man alike to accomplish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:78
verses.text: These are lessons which a man does not learn from a master, nor by art, but by means of the divine oracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:79
verses.text: Seek not how he shall enjoy a long life here, but how he shall enjoy a boundless and endless life hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:80
verses.text: Give him the great things, not the little things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:81
verses.text: Hear what Paul saith, "Bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord"; study not to make him an orator, but train him up to be a philosopher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:82
verses.text: In the want of the one there will be no harm whatever; in the absence of the other, all the rhetoric in the world will be of no advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:83
verses.text: Tempers are wanted, not talking; character, not cleverness; deeds, not words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:84
verses.text: These gain a man the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:85
verses.text: These confer what are benefits indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:86
verses.text: Whet not his tongue, but cleanse his soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:87
verses.text: I do not say this to prevent your teaching him these things, but to prevent your attending to them exclusively.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:88
verses.text: Do not imagine that the monk alone stands in need of these lessons from Scripture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:89
verses.text: Of all others, the children just about to enter into the world specially need them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:90
verses.text: For just in the same way as the man who is always at anchor in harbor, is not the man who requires his ship to be fitted out and who needs a pilot and a crew, but he who is always out at sea; so is it with the man of the world and the monk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:91
verses.text: The one is entered as it were into a waveless harbor, and lives an untroubled life, and far removed from every storm; whilst the other is ever on the ocean, and lives out at sea in the very midst of the ocean, battling with billows without number.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:92
verses.text: And though he may not need it himself, still he ought to be so prepared as to stop the mouths of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:93
verses.text: Thus the more distinguished he is in the present life, so much the more he stands in need of this education.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:94
verses.text: If he passes his life in courts, there are many Heathens, and philosophers, and persons puffed up with the glory of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:95
verses.text: It is like a place full of dropsical people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:96
verses.text: Such in some sort is the court.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:97
verses.text: All are, as it were, puffed up, and in a state of inflammation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:98
verses.text: And they who are not so are studying to become so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:99
verses.text: Now then reflect how vast a benefit it is, that your son on entering there, should enter like an excellent physician, furnished with instruments which may allay every one's peculiar inflammation, and should go up to every one, and converse with him, and restore the diseased body to health, applying the remedies derived from the Scriptures, and pouring forth discourses of the true philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:100
verses.text: For with whom is the recluse to converse? with his wall and his ceiling? yea, or again with the wilderness and the woods? or with the birds and the trees? He therefore has not so great need of this sort of discipline.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:101
verses.text: Still, however, he makes it his business to perfect this work, not so much with a view of disciplining others as himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:102
verses.text: There is then every need of much discipline of this sort to those that are to mix in the present world, because such an one has a stronger temptation to sin than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:103
verses.text: And if you have a mind to understand it, he will further be a more useful person even in the world itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:104
verses.text: For all will have a reverence for him from these words, when they see him in the fire without being burnt, and not desirous of power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:105
verses.text: But power he will then obtain, when he least desires it, and will be a still higher object of respect to the king; for it is not possible that such a character should be hid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:106
verses.text: Amongst a number of healthy persons, indeed, a healthy man will not be noticed; but when there is one healthy man amongst a number of sick, the report will quickly spread and reach the king's ears, and he will make him ruler over many nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:107
verses.text: Knowing then these things, "bring up your children in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:108
verses.text: "But suppose a man is poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:109
verses.text: Still he will be in no wise more insignificant than the man who lives in kings' courts, because he is not in kings' courts; no, he will be held in admiration, and will soon gain that authority which is yielded voluntarily, and not by any compulsion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:110
verses.text: For if a set of Greeks, men worthless as they are, and dogs, by taking up that worthless philosophy of theirs, (for such the Grecian philosophy is,) or rather not itself but only its mere name, and wearing the threadbare cloak, and letting their hair grow, impress many; how much more will he who is a true philosopher? If a false appearance, if a mere shadow of philosophy at first sight so catches us, what if we should love the true and pure philosophy? Will not all court it, and entrust both houses, and wives, and children, with full confidence to such men? But there is not, no, there is not such a philosopher existing now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:111
verses.text: And therefore, it is not possible to find an example of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:112
verses.text: Amongst recluses, indeed, there are such, but amongst people in the world no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:113
verses.text: And that amongst recluses there are such, it would be possible to adduce a number of instances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:114
verses.text: However, I will mention one out of many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:115
verses.text: Ye know, doubtless, and have heard of, and some, perhaps, have also seen, the man whom I am now about to mention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:116
verses.text: I mean, the admirable Julian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:117
verses.text: This man was a rustic, in humble life, and of humble parentage, and totally uninstructed in all outward accomplishments, but full of unadorned wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:118
verses.text: When he came into the cities, (and this was but rarely,) never did such a concourse take place, not when orators, or sophists, or any one else rode in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:119
verses.text: But what am I saying? Is not his very name more glorious than that of any king's, and celebrated even to this day? And if these things were in this world, in the world in which the Lord promised us no one good thing, in which He hath told us we are strangers, let us consider how great will be the blessings laid up for us in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:120
verses.text: If, where they were sojourners they enjoyed so great honor, how great glory shall they enjoy where their own city is! If, where He promised tribulation, they meet with such attentive care, then where He promises true honors, how great shall be their rest!  And now would ye have me exhibit examples of secular men? At present, indeed, we have none; still there are perhaps even secular men who are excellent, though not arrived at the highest philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:121
verses.text: I shall therefore quote you examples from the saints of the ancient times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:122
verses.text: How many, who had wives to keep and children to bring up, were inferior in no respect, no, in no respect to those who have been mentioned? Now, however, it is no longer so, "by reason of the present distress" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:123
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:124
verses.text: ), as this blessed Apostle saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:125
verses.text: Now then whom would ye have me mention? Noah, or Abraham? The son of the one or of the other? Or again, Joseph? Or would ye have me go to the Prophets? Moses I mean, or Isaiah? However, if you will, let us carry our discourse to Abraham, whom all are continually bringing forward to us above all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:126
verses.text: Had he not a wife? Had he not children? Yes, for I too use the same language to you, as you do to me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:127
verses.text: He had a wife, but it was not because he had a wife that he was so remarkable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:128
verses.text: He had riches, but it was not because he had riches that he pleased God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:129
verses.text: He begat children, but it was not because he begat children that he was pronounced blessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:130
verses.text: He had three hundred and eighteen servants born in his house, but it was not on this account that he was accounted wonderful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:131
verses.text: But would you know why it was? It was for his hospitality, for his contempt of riches, for his chastened conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:132
verses.text: For what, tell me, is the duty of a philosopher? Is it not to despise both riches and glory? Is it not to be above both envy and every other passion? Come now then, let us bring him forward and strip him, and show you what a philosopher he was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:133
verses.text: First of all, he esteemed his fatherland as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:134
verses.text: God said, "Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:135
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:136
verses.text: ), and immediately he went forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:137
verses.text: He was not bound to his house, (or surely he would never have gone forth,) nor to his love of familiar friends, nor to anything else whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:138
verses.text: But what? glory and money he despised above all others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:139
verses.text: For when he had put an end to war by turning the enemy to flight, and was requested to take the spoil, he rejected it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:140
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:141
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:143
verses.text: )  Again, the son of this great man was reverenced, not because of his riches, but for his hospitality: not because of his children, but for his obedience: not because of his wife, but for the barrenness inflicted on his wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:144
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:145
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:146
verses.text: )  They looked upon the present life as nothing, they followed not after gain, they despised all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:147
verses.text: Tell me, which sort of plants are the best? Are not those which have their strength from themselves and are injured neither by rains, nor by hailstorms, nor by gusts of wind, nor by any other vicissitude of the sort, but stand naked in defiance of them all, and needing neither wall nor fence to protect them? Such is the true philosopher, such is that wealth of which we spoke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:148
verses.text: He has nothing, and has all things: he has all things, and has nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:149
verses.text: For a fence is not within, but only without; a wall is not a thing of nature, but only built round from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:150
verses.text: And what again, I ask, what sort of body is a strong one? Is it not that which is in health, and which is overcome neither by hunger nor repletion, nor by cold, nor by heat; or is it that which in view of all these things, needs both caterers, and weavers, and hunters, and physicians, to give it health? He is the rich man, the true philosopher, who needeth none of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:151
verses.text: For this cause it was that this blessed Apostle said, "Bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:152
verses.text: Surround them not with outward defenses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:153
verses.text: For such is wealth, such is glory; for when these fall, and they do fall, the plant stands naked and defenseless, not only having derived no profit from them during the time past, but even injury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:154
verses.text: For those very shelters that prevented its being inured to the attacks of the winds, will now have prepared it for perishing all at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:155
verses.text: And so wealth is injurious rather, because it renders us undisciplined for the vicissitudes of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:156
verses.text: Let us therefore train up our children to be such, that they shall be able to bear up against every trial, and not be surprised at what may come upon them; "let us bring them up in the chastening and admonition of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:157
verses.text: And great will be the reward which will be thus laid up in store for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:158
verses.text: For if men for making statues and painting portraits of kings enjoy so great honor, shall not we who adorn the image of the King of kings, (for man is the image of God,) receive ten thousand blessings, if we effect a true likeness? For the likeness is in this, in the virtue of the soul, when we train our children to be good, to be meek, to be forgiving, (because all these are attributes of God,) to be beneficent, to be humane; when we train them to regard the present world as nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:159
verses.text: Let this then be our task, to mold and to direct both ourselves and them according to what is right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:160
verses.text: Otherwise with what sort of boldness shall we stand before the judgment-seat of Christ? If a man who has unruly children is unworthy to be a Bishop (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:161
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:162
verses.text: ), much more is he unworthy of the kingdom of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:163
verses.text: What sayest thou? If we have an unruly wife, or unruly children, shall we have to render account? Yes, we shall, if we do not with exactness bring in that which is due from ourselves; for our own individual virtue is not enough in order to salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:164
verses.text: If the man who laid aside the one talent gained nothing, but was punished even in such a manner, it is plain that one's own individual virtue is not enough in order to salvation, but there is need of that of another also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:165
verses.text: Let us therefore entertain great solicitude for our wives, and take great care of our children, and of our servants, and of ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:166
verses.text: And in our government both of ourselves and of them, let us beseech God that He aid us in the work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:167
verses.text: If He shall see us interested in this work, and solicitous about it, He will aid us; but if He shall see us paying no regard to it, He will not give us His hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:168
verses.text: For He does not vouchsafe us His assistance when we sleep, but when we labor also ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:169
verses.text: For a helper, (as the name implies,) is not a helper of one that is inactive, but of one who works also himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 22:170
verses.text: But the good God is able of Himself to bring the work to perfection, that we may be all counted worthy to attain to the blessings promised us, through the grace and compassions of His only begotten Son, with Whom together with the Holy Ghost be unto the Father, glory, might, and honor, now and ever, and throughout all ages, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:1
verses.text: Homily XXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:2
verses.text: Ephesians vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:3
verses.text: –  "Servants, be obedient unto them that, according to the flesh, are your masters, with fear and trembling, in singleness of your heart, as unto Christ; not in the way of eye-service, as men-pleasers: but as servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart; with good-will doing service, as unto the Lord, and not unto men: knowing that whatsoever good thing each one doeth, the same shall he receive again from the Lord, whether he be bond or free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:4
verses.text: Thus then it is not husband only, nor wife, nor children, but virtuous servants also that contribute to the organization and protection of a house.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:5
verses.text: Therefore the blessed Paul has not overlooked this department even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:6
verses.text: He comes to it, however, in the last place, because it is last in dignity and rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:7
verses.text: Still he addresses much discourse also to them, no longer in the same tone as to children, but in a far more advanced way, inasmuch as he does not hold out to these the promise in this world, but in that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:8
verses.text: "Knowing," saith he, "that whatsoever good or evil thing each one doeth, the same shall he receive of the Lord," and thus at once instructs them to love wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:9
verses.text: For though they be inferior to the children in dignity, still in mind they are superior to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:10
verses.text: "Servants," saith he, "be obedient to them that, according to the flesh, are your masters".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:11
verses.text: Thus at once he raises up, at once soothes the wounded soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:12
verses.text: Be not grieved, he seems to say, that you are inferior to the wife and the children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:13
verses.text: Slavery is nothing but a name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:14
verses.text: The mastership is "according to the flesh," brief and temporary; for whatever is of the flesh, is transitory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:15
verses.text: "With fear," he adds, "and trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:16
verses.text: Thou seest that he does not require the same fear from slaves as from wives: for in that case he simply said, "and let the wife see that she fear her husband"; whereas in this case he heightens the expression, "with fear," he saith, "and trembling, in singleness of your heart, as unto Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:17
verses.text: This is what he constantly says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:18
verses.text: What meanest thou, blessed Paul? He is a brother, or rather he has become a brother, he enjoys the same privileges, he belongs to the same body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:19
verses.text: Yea, more, he is the brother, not of his own master only, but also of the Son of God, he is partaker of all the same privileges; yet sayest thou, "obey your masters according to the flesh, with fear and trembling"? Yes, for this very reason, he would say, I say it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:20
verses.text: For if I charge free men to submit themselves one to another in the fear of God,—as he said above, "submitting yourselves one to another in the fear of Christ";—if I charge moreover the wife to fear and reverence her husband, although she is his equal; much more must I so speak to the servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:21
verses.text: It is no sign of low birth, rather it is the truest nobility, to understand how to lower ourselves, to be modest and unassuming, and to give way to our neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:22
verses.text: And the free have served the free with much fear and trembling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:23
verses.text: "In singleness of heart," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:24
verses.text: And it is well said, since it is possible to serve with fear and trembling, and yet not of good will, but in just any way that may be possible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:25
verses.text: Many servants in many instances secretly cheat their masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:26
verses.text: And this cheating accordingly he does away, by saying, "in singleness of your heart as unto Christ, not in the way of eye-service as men-pleasers, but as servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart; with good-will doing service, as unto the Lord, and not unto men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:27
verses.text: Seest thou how many words he requires, in order to implant this good principle, "with goodwill," I mean, and "from the heart"? That other service, "with fear and trembling" I mean, we see many rendering to their masters, and the master's threat goes far to secure that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:28
verses.text: But show, saith he, that thou servest as "the servant of Christ," not of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:29
verses.text: Make the right action your own, not one of compulsion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:30
verses.text: Just as in the words which follow, he persuades and instructs the man who is ill-treated by another to make the right action his own, and the work of his own free choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:31
verses.text: Because inasmuch as the man that smites the cheek, is not supposed to come to that act in consequence of any intention in the person struck, but only of his own individual malice, what saith He? "Turn to him the other also" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:32
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:33
verses.text: ); to show him that in submitting to the first thou wert not unwilling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:34
verses.text: For he that is lavish in suffering wrong, makes that his own which is not his own act, by suffering himself to be smitten on the other cheek also, and not merely by enduring the first blow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:35
verses.text: For this latter will have perhaps the appearance even of cowardice; but that of a high philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:36
verses.text: —Thus thou wilt show that it was for the sake of wisdom that thou didst bear the first blow also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:37
verses.text: And so in the present case, show here too, that thou bearest this slavery also willingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:38
verses.text: The man-pleaser then is no servant of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:39
verses.text: The servant of Christ is not a man-pleaser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:40
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:41
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:42
verses.text: ) For who that is the servant of God, makes it his object to please men? And who that pleases men, can be a servant of God?  "From the heart," saith he, "with good-will doing service".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:43
verses.text: For since it is possible to do service even with singleness of heart and not wrongfully, and yet not with all one's might, but only so far as fulfilling one's bounden duty, therefore he says, do it with alacrity, not of necessity, upon principle, not upon constraint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:44
verses.text: If thus thou do service, thou art no slave; if thou do it upon principle, if with good-will, if from the heart, and if for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:45
verses.text: For this is the servitude that even Paul, the free man, serves, and exclaims, "For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus, as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:46
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:47
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:48
verses.text: ) Look how he divests thy slavery of its meanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:49
verses.text: For just in the same way as the man who has been robbed, if he gives still more to him who has taken, is not ranked among those robbed, but rather amongst liberal givers; not amongst those who suffer evil, but amongst those who do good; and rather clothes the other with disgrace by his liberality, than is clothed with disgrace by being robbed,—so, I say, in this case, by his generosity he will appear at once more high-minded, and by showing that he does not feel the wrong, will put the other to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:50
verses.text: Let us then do service to our masters for Christ's sake, "knowing," he continues, "that whatsoever good thing each one doeth, the same shall he receive of the Lord, whether he be bond or free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:51
verses.text: For inasmuch as it was probable that many masters, as being unbelievers, would have no sense of shame, and would make no return to their slaves for their obedience, observe how he has given them encouragement, so that they may have no misgiving about the remuneration, but may have full confidence respecting the recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:52
verses.text: For as they who receive a benefit, when they make no return, make God a debtor to their benefactors; so, I say, do masters also, if, when well-treated by thee, they fail to requite thee, requite thee the more, by rendering God thy debtor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:53
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:54
verses.text: "And ye masters," he continues, "do the same things unto them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:55
verses.text: The same things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:56
verses.text: What are these? "With good-will do service".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:57
verses.text: However he does not actually say, "do service," though by saying, "the same things," he plainly shows this to be his meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:58
verses.text: For the master himself is a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:59
verses.text: "Not as men-pleasers," he means, "and with fear and trembling": that is, toward God, fearing lest He one day accuse you for your negligence toward your slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Ephesianss 23:60
